												Having completed the Steam version and PS1 version back to back, here are a few things I noted:- The button layout can be confusing in certain sequences if using a controller, for example; telling you to press B2 or B5 as instructed, requiring you to remember your controllers personal button layout.- All polygons look much better in this version, obviously, but it often clashes very unnaturally with the low res backdrops.- A lot of the ported-to-midi music is noticably worse than the original, some peices sounding broken and off key- Character portraits look a lot nicer and more detailed in Steam version.- The gameplay seems to have been sped up by about 25%, which makes the frame rate APPEAR smoother, although animations still seem to be quite choppy. Particularly makes battles and traversing the world map seem much smoother!- Various scenes will load much faster, ie; card battles and the startup screen, which is a big quality of life difference!- 360 degree movement doesn't work by default, only 8 direction. I'm not sure if this can be modded.When all is said and done, I personally prefer the original PS1 version, but if you don't have access to it, this version is not a bad option either. Hope this was helpful. :)

												Hello, my old friend.Years ago, I remember walking into a local Wal-Mart to browse through the bargain bin of Psx games. There I found a green label greatest hits game called Final Fantasy VII. The blonde man on the cover holding a giant sword tore away at my curiosity. So my allowance was spent on this mysterious game I had yet to hear about. Not very long after beating it, I realized I was in love. "Where has this game been all my life?" I asked myself. A few weeks later, after saving up my allowances for a NEW psx title, I returned to the same local Wal-Mart and began browsing the sliding door glass case. "Hmm...Gran Turismo sure looks fun...Tomb Raider....maybe...", but there at the bottom in the left hand corner it sat. Final Fantasy VIII. I must've screeched from excitement. Though none of these characters on the case looked familiar..."So the games don't connect then?" I pondered...In a rush to get the game, I flagged the worker down to open the case. Game in hand, I opened the lid of my Psx, removed Dark Stone, and placed in Disc 1...Never has a game brought as much excitement as seeing this sequel that day. It was the best, is the best, and will forever be the best. Now I am no longer a child, at 25 I have 2 children of my own and hope one day they too find their "FFVIII"...

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Edit: Update to the title on 20th June 2014 added more cheats - no fixes to any of the technical issues.Before I get started, Yes I know about the mods to fix it. We shouldn't have to mod the game to get content Square Enix claimed was in the game.FINAL FANTASY VII (Yes, 7) was released on Steam a little while ago. And while many were happy, many were disappointed. Square Enix released the game with awful audio. Entire vocals were missing from some, for example, the infamous "One Winged Angel" BGM, and the audio in general sounded very subdued. A modder, Assimi, went out of his way to patch the BGM to the quality it should be. Many months came and went, and eventually, one day, Square Enix released a patch, which upgraded the audio to a better quality.We then hear FINAL FANTASY VIII will be coming to Steam, with what Square Enix claimed - PlayStation Quality Audio! Superb! They won't make the same mistake twice! Surely? Especially not after such a statement...We were wrong.FINAL FANTASY VIII Steam Edition is an almost identical copy of the original FINAL FANTASY VIII PC Port, except this time with added layers of DRM, cheats, and ruined FMVs, along side all the issues of the original port.So all the issues:1) Background music uses low quality midi. 2) Sound effects uses low quality audio (Quetzalcoatls roar sticks out the most).3) Limited to 8-way movement, rather than the 360 movement on PS14) Still uses B1 B2 B3 B4 B5 B6 button prompts if using a Gamepad.5) FMVs have been giving a horrible filter to "upscale" them. This blur removes a tonne of detail from the FMVs.6) Linear Filtering simply blurs all the textures, and makes the world map look disgusting.So let's go through these 1 by 1. Links to any mods mentioned will be put at the bottom of the review.Issue 1) Background Music. This is horrible. My main problem here is Square Enix LIED to us. When they announced FF8 Steam Edition they shouted "PLAYSTATION QUALITY AUDIO!" from the rooftops. They did not deliver. Here's a comparison:Steam Edition:


YouTube™ Video: Steam Edition Music - Unmodded (Final Fantasy VIII) 

			Views: 8,882		

			http://steamcommunity.com/id/ZergMark/recommended/39150		

PlayStation Version:


YouTube™ Video: Final Fantasy VIII - Balamb Garden [HQ] 

			Views: 946,249		

			Final Fantasy 8 - Balamb Garden [HQ]		

If you're using any decent speakers, you can hear the massive difference. My speakers cost me about £10, and I'm not even an audiophile (hence the £10 speakers) and I can tell the massive difference in quality.Thankfully - Thanks to DLPB of the QHIMM forums this can be fixed and modded out (and the BGM can be changed to whatever songs you want, just make sure they're .OGG and looped correctly). But. It shouldn't need to be in the first place. Square Enix claimed the game has PS Audio. It doesn't.Issue 2) Similar to issue 1. Unfortunately here I don't have a comparison. But again - SE Claimed PS Quality Audio. They did not deliver.Issue 3) 8 way movement. If you're on KB+M This is absolutely fine since you're inherently limited to 8 way. However many people, with this being a PlayStation game, would play with a gamepad, and if you do, think again about using that wonderful analog stick for 360 movement.Issue 4) So you'd expect, with this being a PlayStation game to use X Square Triangle Circle right, or maybe they updated it to ABXY? Unfortunately not. The game uses the possibly ancient Dinput, because forget updating the game to a more modern form of input, right? Way too much effort.Issue 5) So instead of doing a proper job of editing the FMVs too look decent at high-res, like the 1080p standard, or like me, 1440p, Square Enix applied a filter to the entirety of every cutscene. It's a blur filter. It blurs the FMVs to remove the "blockiness" that would occur from upscaling and especially when in motion. Instead of putting in effort to do this, carefully applying filters when and where necersarry, they made it global. Destroying massive amounts of detail in the progress.Fortunately, someone on the Steam Discussion forums applied a better filter, though still not perfect.Issue 6) Linear Filtering is 50/50. It looks okay. In combat, it looks good. Applied to character models, it looks good. Applied to the world map? Oh my.Just look at this mess: http://i.imgur.com/p7QGH2w.pngCompared with it turned off: http://i.imgur.com/pA9jlED.png--------So. What's better about the Steam release? Well the improved hardware compatability is nice. Chocobo World is included as it was with the original release too, so if you never got a chance to play and have the benefits of that, that's a bonus. You also get achievements if you're into those.Cheats. More controversial. The cheats this time aren't as bad as FINAL FANTASY VII. Why? It's just magic. And that's a non-issue if you read up on how to use the card game mechanics and refining to get spells very quickly, and very early. Indeed, you can get many powerful spells for junction via card refining very early on that aren't even included in the cheat. All it really does is remove some of the grind... Which I guess is okay.And well slightly improved graphics due to the higher character model polygons. But that's about it. I would not recommend this in it's current state. This is simply a re-release of the old PC port, with very minimal effort put in to actually updating it.My recommendation would go out to purchasing a PlayStation copy of the game and playing it that way. You can get it for cheaper than Steam on the PlayStation store.--------Roses and Wine BGM Mod: http://steamcommunity.com/app/39150/discussions/0/666828126495993258/FMV Replacement Mod: http://steamcommunity.com/app/39150/discussions/0/666828126807201587/?tscn=1386758049#p1Shoutout to Assimi, the FF7 BGM Modder: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198004345221/

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												The black sheep of the Final Fantasy series, Final Fantasy VIII is a game that divides opinion to this very day. Is it good? Is it bad? Does it make a lick of sense? Is Squall a sexy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? No one entirely agrees on an answer to any of these questions (except for the last one, the answer of which is YES), but I have my own take it. FFVIII is perhaps the most underappreciated games in the entire series. Much like how FFVII deconstructed JRPGs that existed up to that point, FFVIII deconstructs the wave of RPGs that followed in Final Fantasy VII's wake, mocking their tropes and characters, while at the same time telling a very unique story. FFVIII follows Squall Leonheart, a student at Balamb Garden, a military academy that trains SeeDs, a mercenary force designed for one purpose: to hunt down and destroy Sorcerresses. Squall is probably my favorite lead character in a Final Fantasy game, and that has one clear reason: he's realistic. Unlike Cloud or Zidane, he isn't a teenager who can somehow fight the forces of darkness without sweat: he's a flawed person, broken by a crappy childhood and a dehumanising education that taught him how to kill. In essence, he behaves how a real person would in his situation. Over the course of the game, we're treated to a near-constant internal monologue that tells us about the struggles he faces internally and how he deals with them. He's a great lead. The rest of the cast is more mixed, with high points being Irvine, who often reflects Squall, and Laguna, who's chipper attitude is a nice respite from the grim tones of Squall, and low points being the annoying and fairly useless Zell, the bland and boring Quistis, and the game's dumb villain, Ultimecia. The plot itself is also a bit of a mixed bag, with some really good moments offset by some really dumb ones. The battle system is a clear departure from the rest of the series too. Rather than levelling up your characters to build stats, instead, stats are built by "junctioning" magic to various stats to increase their parameters. This is a great system, one ripe for experimentation, hampered by one thing: Drawing. Magic works like items in FF8: once you use a charge, it's gone. The only way to get magic early on is by painstakingly drawing magic from enemies: an incredibly tedious and boring prospect. It's rectified later once you get access to card refinement, but it's still a hassle. Speaking of card refinement. this game comes with a very entertaining trading card diversion called Triple Triad, and it's a blast. Simple, quick, yet endlessly addictive. So, that's Final Fantasy VIII. Honestly, I love it, and it remains one of my favorites of the series. However, it's a very flawed game, so chances are, you may not like it. However, approach it with an open mind, and I think you'll enjoy what lies in store.

Posted: April 7, 2015
												If you've never played a Final Fantasy game in your life, then here's a great place to start.The Final Fantasy games have suffered from their ups and downs over the years, and VIII is no exception. If you take the time to search for opinions on the internet, you'll find a myriad of opinions ranging from one extreme to the other.At it's heart though, I've found the game enjoyable, replayable - and the few aspects I do not like are swept under the rug.As with most FF games, it relies on turn-based combat, but don't let that fool you. It is possible (and quite easy when you get the hang of it) to finish the game without levelling any of your characters at all. There are side quests aplenty, including the Triple Triad card game, which is fun for the most part, and the chocobo forest mini game.The story is quite in-depth, so while I don't recommend it for the very young, based on this, it is still age and gender friendly - there is romance, comedy, plot twists, and a story and world so rich you might just not want to leave it.The art style might take some getting used to, but the menu, and how magic and summons integrate with characters, may be the biggest hurdle for new players. Simply put - I didn't use magic. Summons are "junctioned" to characters to grant them abilities, not the least of which is the ability to link collected magicks to your stats, giving them a significant boost. This is the primary method of getting stronger. As you level, so too do the enemies, meaning you can't outlevel them. It is a unique system among FF games, but somehow it works, and works well with practice.If you're already familiar with FF games, you might have already decided whether or not to get this game, but if you haven't, it's definitely worth a look-see.

												TL;DR?: Don't buy, yet, wait for a sound mod or SE patch.I picked up this game quite eagerly after missing out on FF8 on the PS1. Sadly I was incredibly dissapointed in the poor job Square Enix had done in porting the game to Steam. First problem, I had to navigate a menu that after refusing my Facebook account, forced me to sign up to Square Enix's website. A pain, but a minor one I would have forgotten.Second problem, which damns the game and makes it unplayable, the sound. This appears petty, but the lack of the PS1 soundtrack, one of the games defining features, is lost with the MIDI versions which seriously takes away from the games atmosphere. This is especially damning when you consider how dated the games graphics are, which whilst not a problem on its own, the poor sound artifically ages the game and damages the experience. FF7 received a number of Mods and even an offical patch to fix the sound problem alone, I'd say its worth holding out for one of these until you buy.It is a shame really, as the core gameplay is fantastic, the depth of the RPG mechanics still intact and there is a lot to pick apart in the story, though the lack of a good soundtrack (Which hopefully will be improved in the coming weeks) really does lessen the quality of the package. Hold off buying this until Square Enix or some modder updates the soundtrack, at which point I would actually recommend picking this up.

Posted: November 2, 2014
												Thinking all the time, never saying a word. Looking miserable, wearing awful black clothes. Being rude to people, mood swings.Remember when you where a teenager? Perhaps you are one, and that is why Final Fantasy VIII is a hidden gem, concealed by the fact, hype and fans of 7 & 9.Final Fantasy VIII is in many ways like other FF's, its set in a huge explorable world upon which, a situation arises, threatening its existence, companions are gathered along the journey to prevent it. But what 8 has done is extraordinary although it has to be said, unappreciated. This fantasy is through the eyes of a teenager, Squall, dubbed a Leonardo Dicaprio look-alike misery guts. Which is without doubt true, and possibly a strong reason why so many detest this game, living-reliving the life of a teenager in a world that is the closest to this one than any other FF game beyond 7. Effectively taken place in a Garden (school/college) where the students are trained to be become functioning members of an elite group of soldiers known as SEED. Ok not exactly a clever or exciting plot at first glance but this is only the beginning of something overlooked. Everything about it has that youthful learning element to it, such as the SEED tests as a means of gaining regular income, testing your knowledge of enemies, magic and general surroundings, you participate in field exams where you are graded accordingly on time, battles, attitude, spirit etc. oh and you're not aloud to buy a porn mag because you're to young.Like all successful square games, it begins slow but picks up the pace by new events, addictive mini games and tugs on your heart strings with a puppy love storyline. Clearly, gamers have taken one look at the indifferent main character they must control and shake their fist in disgust that they aren't a mysterious mercenary, fun loving optimist athlete or a womanizing thief with a tail. I'll admit there are moments in the dialogue where you get annoyed at the ignorance of said character, such phrases like "go talk to a wall" are aimed at someone spilling their emotional guts and "whatever" occurs repeatedly followed by "....." making Squall an essentially unresponsive cold jerk.. what he wants you to think.. however the time I played this, I was of a similar age, disposition and could defend 'some' of his actions. As time wears on though, more light is shed as to why your guy seems so hormone ridden, a past frequently visited in game that should be cherished to understand. Ahh but Square likes messing with you and cant resist a sub-plot, cue Laguna (main), Kiros & Ward, three laughable soldiers in the Galbadien Army (who later become a threat to SEED) running around like headless chickens on a journey of old, with Laguna the exact opposite of Squall - a moronic happy-go-lucky journalist. This change of setting and character can be greeted with relief or reluctance as it occurs when things are about to get interesting.Battles are both improved and altered with the addition of a new "Draw" system, abstracting magic from creatures and specific points in the world, and simpler nice touches like summoning times with button bashing and chance (due to low health) involved with limit breaks. GF's or Guardian Forces (that's summons, eidolons, aons to you an me) are introduced in a brilliant new way, instead of merely stumbling across them all the time, you must battle them or draw them from powerful boss's. All of which is overawed by this games surroundings. When a place has a name like Fisherman's Horizon you know its gunna be weird.. in a good way. Towns like Deling resemble London with an array of shops and structures like Big Ben. Dollet seems like an old French town with cobble roads and 18th century architecture, even the score fits thanks to the genius that is Nobuo Uematsu. I could write a thesis on how spectacular the soundtrack is but I'll just say look at the soundtrack itself for reviews. Such is the realism of the setting but don't be fooled, around the 3rd disc you'll stumble across the city of Esthar, a gigantic technological wonder the size of a continent.. then you wake up as a writer in a rustic village called Windhill, magic. Shame that such an innovative, well designed game is largely considered poor, when really its similar to all the others. It still has the apocalyptic doom threat, it still has a global scourge of an adventure if you're into doing things properly. There's the giant airship that takes you there. SPACE, 7 went into space for a few minutes, 8 goes there for a while and conjures up some of the most cinematic and thrilling events that square couldn't come up with on earth, so much so they put in a song with vocals and as you know that's a special almost rare treat. Plus you can play cards with cactuars on em!Stunning FMV's accompany the key moments that all culminate into an epic journey of self discovery and destiny. It sounds cheesy but I implore you, give it a chance, this game is superb.

												For many of us, we seek to relive the nostalgia that FF8 would offer to us through steam. This review will be a juxtaposition of the PS1 version and the Steam version. I guess I'll start with a few pros:+You can simultaneously play Chocobo World while playing FF8. Chocobo World was not offered on the console version of FF8, so I thought this was a nice addition to the game.+There are much faster loading screens. I think this was one of the most notable things seeing as how I would spend 50% of my time on the console version just staring at a black loading screen between transitions.+Cloud Saving - No, not referring to FF7, but this is a nice way to save your progress without having to deal with memory cards. You will always have your non-corrupt Squall wherever you go.Now, for some cons:-MIDI files are messed up. If you're a big FF fan, you will know that the music plays a big role in the series. The fact that the MIDI files sound like garbage just tells us that Square Enix did not give a **** about the PC port. Thankfully, there is a mod/fix for this, so it's not that big of a deal.-If the Square Enix servers are down, then you're not able to play your offline single player game. I'm not sure if this is primarily because of the cloud server, but it's annoying.-You need a Square Enix account to play. This can be problematic because.. well, a lot of people experience all sorts of problems. Some have problems navigating the site, while others are still waiting for their email confirmation.-This is the PC version, but that doesn't mean that the keyboard controls will be great. If you want to fully enjoy the PC experience, I would recommend a controller for your PC. I bought one for about 20$.I actually did not swap out the music, did not have (too) many problems with accessing my account and still managed to almost get 200 hours into the game. All in all, despite a handful of annoying flaws, I like the PC port. Am I adamant on strongly recommending this game? No. In fact, I would ONLY recommend buying this if you have played a previous version of FF8 and/or if it's on sale.If you are new to the Final Fantasy series, I would not recommend this as you will probably be dismayed by the frustrating flaws of the steam version. This could potentially just leave a bad taste on your tongue overall for FF8, too.TL;DR - Buy if you're a veteran and/or if it's on sale; skip if you're new to the game.

												I must admit, after watching my father play this game on the PS1 when I was young, and then when I was older getting to play it myself on the same console, my nostalgia glasses for this game area pretttty thick. But, I'm going to give this a good review anyways, and try to be as unbiased as possible. Pros:-An interesting "Junction System" that allows customization of characters stats through their "Guardian Force" (who in the previous games were merely summonable monsters). -While the graphics aren't great by today's standards, they're definitely a step up from the PS1 version! There's new resolutions to choose from (and you can play in widescreen! Woot!) and the character models are significantly less pixelated than before! -A Fantastic story, like seriously. Even though I haven't beat it yet, this is really a cool story that I'm really enjoying. -Good characters that I've remembered throughout my entire life of gaming. Squall is just so great, and wow his gunblade is so cool! -The combat is really fun! Honestly one of my favorite things to do in this game is just waddle around on the map and fight monsters. There's just such a good variety, with such good design, plus I'm partial to turn-based combat. Cons:-The music. Okay, the music in this game is amazing, but the quality is not. Square used the original "midi" files from the old PC release rather than the good files from the PS1 release, however, there is a community mod out there that replaces the files and makes it all better! So there! I tried to look through my nostalgia glasses and give you a good review of a really cool, really memorable Final Fantasy game. I hope you enjoy it as much as I have!

												By far the Playstation version is better than the Steam version:  [PROS]-Steam achievements-Smoothed graphics or original Playstation 1 graphic settings available-Great soundtrack*-Attacking can be hands-on (Example: using Squall’s gunblade or Zell’s Limit Break)-Magic Booster available via the launch menu-Cheats are available via the Function keys-Cheats do not affect Steam achievements-Tons of creative monster/landscape designs-Triple Triad card game-Chocobo World included[CONS]-In order to play Final Fantasy VIII an account must be created with Square Enix-Save files CAN BE LOST due to the Steam's cloud syncing, so be sure to turn off cloud syncing before playing (Library>Games>Right click on Final Fantasy VIII>Properties>Update>Uncheck 'Enable Steam Cloud Synchronization for Final Fantasy VIII')-*Great soundtrack but… the sound is awful on the Steam version due to MIDI; however, this can be fixed (http://steamcommunity.com/app/39150/discussions/0/666828126495993258/#c666828126498515672)-Guardian Force (GF) summoning time can be too long such as for Eden-If you’re hardcore into grammar the typos (mostly in the beginning of the game) may drive you insane-Rinoa.  (She has always driven me insane since the first time I played this game, and the few times where you have to save her in the game I never wanted to save her)Then there's the PocketStation game Chocobo World available via the launch menu to Final Fantasy VIII.  This mini-game can be muted via your computer's sound settings (Windows 7>Speaker/Volume Control>Mixer) and run in the background taking care of itself.  Personally, I find Chocobo World boring; however, Boko the Chicobo can find items (ranked A through D), which can be useful to your saved game once you finish your first Chocobo Forest (Final Fantasy VIII 'Disc 2').  Also, leveling up Boko to certain levels and meeting certain event requirements in Chocobo World can allow Boko to use powerful attacks in FF8's main story with Gysahl Green.Keep in mind that the Steam version of Final Fantasy VIII is far from a remake; therefore, the graphics, sound, and game play are still on par with the Playstation version released in 1999.

												Disclaimer: I'm not a contrarian. At least, I try not to be. This has always stood the test of time as my favorite Final Fantasy. I don't say that lightly, as I find the era of IV-X to be one of the most impressive runs of consecutive brilliance in video game history. The characters are as well-rounded as any in the series; this is accomplished by providing the player with a cast of heroes that is less archetypal than most JRPGs. The main character, Squall, is troubled. He's not bright-eyed and eager. His compatriots provide similar contrast just when you think you have them pegged. The junction system is probably overly complicated for newbies. It takes some time to master. And while the tutorials are good at showing you how to work the system. They come at the beginning of the game and negatively effect the pacing. If you can power through that first 5-7 hours though, you are in for a treat.As a character-driven experience, it's tough to find a better entry in the series (perhaps VI?), however the story is slightly muddled by an odd duex ex machina type of plot-hole around the 25-30 hour mark. The good thing is it leads right into one of the most wonderfully action packed moments in the game, thus, in final fantasy history. If you played it and quit a when you were young, it may be a good time to give it another look. The game being sandwiched between two more beloved entries (VII and IX) probably didn't help it's place in history. For my money, it was my favorite. A flawed, but ultimately masterful entry in one of the most celebrated franchises of all-time....and that ending, whew...

												FF8 is quite possibly the most discussed FF due to how the public percieves its story and what it really means.I'll explain this game a little for players who missed this gem from back in the day. It is quite confusing to someone who's never played it before for the first time.The game uses a GF system (Guardian Force = aka Infinite Use Summons in Battle with outside of battle skills)Now you need GF's equipped on a character to use basic actions like using Summons, Drawing Magic from Monsters or using items.It's important to realize that there is NO MP at all in this game. Think of Magic like Items. Only way to gain magic is from draw points on the world or Draw it from Monsters in combat.With Magic you can Junction it onto your characters to give them a boost in Stats to greatly increase their capabilities, like putting Fire on STR to boost Damage, or stack Cure onto HP to give your characters a boost in Max Health.The more of a certain Magic you have while Junctioned onto a stat, the greater the bonus. So you'll get more STR bonuses from 100x Fire rather than just having 15x Fire. The same goes for the Level of Magic too. So you'll get even more bonuses to stats for Junctioning Higher Level Magic onto your Stats rather than Low Magics. (Like Cure vs Curage. Curaga gives much more to bonuses)Now everyone should take note that the Limit Breaks in this game are different. You don't get a limit Meter. As such it can be abused to hell if you really want it to, just leave your characters in Low (Yellow) HP and watch your Limit Breaks wreck everything for you, making the game considerably easier.This is a game EVERY JRPG player should experience once in their life. The music is top tier. Boss battles are blood pumping with the music, the story is pretty good and the Superbosses are really fun. Not to mention Squalls and Irving's limit breaks at endgame can completely wreck any boss in a matter of seconds.To sum it all up. This is by far my favourite Final Fantasy, besides Tactics of course.GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT!

												This is a very mixed bag.   First of all I recommend purchasing this release purely for the fact it is available legally, and will run without any major issues,  no hacks/mods/patches etc needed.However,  I feel like the quality of this release is sub-par, compared even to the FF7 release.   FF8 was made for the PC -after- the technical failure that was the Final Fantasy VII PC version.  One of its features was higher resolution Full Motion Videos, and it did indeed deliver on this.   But I don't ever remember them looking as bad as they do in this release.   Whereas the  FF7 videos scaled up to 720p surprisingly well for their age.    Also some videos have very clearly show deinterlacing artifacts, which is puzzling  for something that should have been progressive from the start.      Not only did they do some kind of deinterlacing on some (or all?) parts of some videos,  but they did a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor job, using cheap blend deinterlacing which can clearly be seen in some scenes.I was secondly unimpressed with the background art.   Now we know in FF7,  they were rendered in low-res and the artwork was lost or unavailable to render again at that that point in time;   did they truly make the same mistake again with FF8?    I don't have the original PC version to compare with, so I don't know.   But  some of the background art arguably looks worse than even FF7 did in some areas.   At best it looks about the same;  a pixelated mess.The most offensive act however, is one again, the MUSIC.   Square got blasted for the crappy MIDI renders they released with FF7 both originally,  and then again just recently.   They had the audacity to include the audio in OGG format;  audio of  rendered MIDI.   The finally got a clue and just recently patched the REAL  Playstation Soundtrack back into the game.So why the hell did they not do the same for FF8?   OK it clearly appears to use a slightly more non-standard  format for its MIDI music (and that's what it is.... General MIDI) but could they seriously  NOT  patch in the  OGG support like they did for FF7?   Could they not have applied fan-made  PSF hacks and included the original Playstation Music Files  and instrument samples?That is just a glaring slap in the face.   But I suppose we should be grateful that they released it on Steam from the start this time,  instead of lying to customers  that it would only ever be in the Square-Enix store, like they did with FF7.....One other minor annoyances is they appears to have changed the Overture.   The sequence of images is not only ugly and grainy (like the original PC release) but they appear to have changed the sequence and omitted one or two images, throwing off the timing,  so you are sitting at the white FF8 Logo/Title  while the Overture actually finishes.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
 Never had as much fun playing a card game in my entire life!  I would like to call myself a veteran within the Final Fantasy (FF) franchise now. Granted I am probably overstating myself, I figured it is about time I wrote a review of Final Fantasy VIII. From here on I'll refrain from using Roman numerals just to make this review easier to follow. I played FF8 near to the time it first came out on the PS1. I did not complete it, nor did I have any idea of what was going on - I was a mere child at the time dazzled by the beautiful colours, yet puzzled by the battle system and depressed by Squall’s sadness. Years later, I've returned to FF8 and I can say I have finished the game with a good idea of the actual story… But still depressed by Squall’s sadness. I confess from now that I understand why people would NOT have a liking for this game. There are a number of reasons I can and will point out which would detach the ordinary gamer from any will to finish the game, but I love this game and it is, along with FF6, my favourite JRPG of all time.*No spoilers*  Story  FF8 arguably has one of the most convoluted story's of any game I have ever played. The numerous fan theories surrounding the game seem to make more sense than the actual game! I do not take that to be a criticism of the game however - as strange as it sounds. The story is not bad in and of itself as it is very easy to follow. It is one of those games where the longer you think about whether the story actually makes sense, the less it does... So don't read into it too much is what I would say. With that aside, the story takes place in a confused futuristic world. I say confused purely due to the array of varied environments and settings, from educational institutions which feel a lot like mercenary camps, to castles and to outer space. The story itself is a good balance between being engaging and interesting enough to make the player want to be able to find out how the story concludes, whilst still being complex enough to inspire countless fan theories; some of them keep me up at night to this day!The world of FF8 has remnants of the post-apocalyptic FF7 world, whilst not being nearly as futuristic as Final Fantasy 13. The ending is extremely satisfying to the player and does not leave a feeling of emptiness. Characters To my mind, there are two main categories of Final Fantasy main characters. There is the quirky and easy-going kind (Tidus and Zidane for example), and the more aloof, lonely and emotionally confused kind (Lightning and Cloud). The main character of 8, Squall, fits in the latter category. If Cloud and Lightning had a child (which would make for an amazing game by the way), Squall would be that child. He initially comes across as blunt, cold-hearted, distant and anti-social, but over time there is a gradual change in his character as the game develops. He becomes a nicer, blunt, cold-hearted, distant and anti-social character. Despite being a character of very few words, every sentence he speaks always manages to be funnier than the last. His lack of character ultimately defines his character. The secondary characters (particularly Rinoa) provide an excellent contrast to Squall’s personality. None of the characters feel rushed or uninspired, with Zell, Selphie and Seifer standing out as my favourites (Quistis and Irvine are great too).  Music  DO NOT listen to any of the music in this game without having played it first. I say this because the OST is among the greatest I have heard in any game and explains why Nobuo Uematsu will be my favourite video game composer of all time. The music is best experienced in-game first. Whilst I do admit that there are a couple of pieces which are slightly overused, all of the pieces are memorable and unique with a persistent motif running through the whole game. Liberi Fatali, Maybe I’m a Lion, Find Your Way, Man with the Machine Gun, Eyes on Me, Fisherman’s Horizon and all of the battle themes stand out as my favourites. Eyes on Me in particular is played during one of my favourite scenes in any video game –the piece suits the scene perfectly.  Gameplay I must confess that the first time I played the game, I did not have a clue what junctioning is. I spent the entire game spamming summons until I realised using summons just wasn’t enough. To put it simply, junctioning is the system in FF8 used to upgrade a character’s stats and use magic. It is one of those mechanics which are best learnt while playing the game as it is easier learnt than explained. Nevertheless in contrast to other games in the series, characters do not permanently hold magic. Instead magic is collected by each individual character. That magic can then be ‘junctioned’ to a stat. For example, if you wanted high HP, you could collection the spell ‘Full-life’ a hundred times and junction it to a character’s HP stat. This functions alongside the usual summons you would expect to see in a Final Fantasy game. The system is slightly tricky to get your head around when you first begin playing, but with a little practice it becomes easy. It is a system which could put a player off the game, but the story, the characters and everything is worth the struggle. Triple Triad: This is easily the most overpowered mechanic I have ever experienced in a video game. It is a fairly simple card game which can be used to collect items which can then be used to buy weapons for example. I personally loved it and would love to see a similar game (albeit less powerful) in Final Fantasy 15.  Conclusion Final Fantasy 8 is easily one of my favourite games of all time, however I told one of my friends not to play this game. The reason why is that although I love it, I understand that there are many reasons (such as the battle system) why a person would dislike or even hate this game, particularly if you aren’t a fan of JRPGs in general. If you are a fan of JRPGs (particularly the older classics) I definitely do recommend trying this one out. Whilst there are many reasons to hate the game there are so many more reasons to love it. I can guarantee that you are in for the best card game in a game you’ll every play.  8/10

												Highly, highly recommend. This game is the definition of gorgeous game making.Remember, this is an old game. I believe I played it first in the late 90's. Back then I was enthralled by the art, graphics, and the breathtaking views. It shows it's age, but the chance to play it on PC at 1080p? Yes, please. One to keep forever.I'm not going to go into best games or best Final Fantasies, but I've played a whole slew of games with great stories or sparkling reviews over the years and very, very few have made an impact anywhere close to this. Final Fantasy VIII is, without a doubt, a must play for all gamers and anyone who wishes to experience great depth of storytelling and gameplay. I can't recommend this enough, and I've told so many friends already.However, it is not for those wanting an evening of mindnumbing shiny lights to forget and walk away from. It is a long game and requires thought, for both the gameplay and the story. It also requires it's share of 90's style game management skills. If this is a learning curve, stick with it, you'll get it and still have plenty of game to go.I'd recommend not using the game boosters though unless you've already played all the way through once or you have a REALLY casual relationship with good games and fine art. Seriously, they take you out of the game too much and cheapen the experience. This game rewards perserverance and draws in curiousity. Play it if you like Final Fantasy, love story games, or need to see a part of gaming history. Oh and get a good controller too, one with full synergy with Windows. You'll thank me later.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Originally released on the Playstation and then ported to the PC, the Steam copy of Final Fantasy VIII is a fairly cheap way to access one of the PS1 era classics while also getting to use the Pocket Station game Chocobo World (a mini-game that didn't come included with non-PS1 versions of Final Fantasy VIII outside of Japan, which can give items in FFVIII.)I'll get right to the negatives, not just of this port, but of Final Fantasy VIII. [ CONS ]These are pure problems.-MIDI music. There's guides on Steam for how to fix this, but the fact remains a fresh install will see lower quality music in various situations than in the PS1 version.-Square Enix DRM on the launcher. If their servers go down for maintenance, you can't play your single player game. That's stupid. -If you already have Final Fantasy VIII, Chocobo World's really going to be your only major draw to this, since cloud saves don't justify the above DRM. -Final Fantasy VIII's story requires a lot of work on you, the player's part to make it decent. This seems to stem from odd narrative choices and mistranslations, but the fact remains you might find yourself disappointed with a world where child soldiers are led by Evil Robin Williams to battle a Double Witch. YMMV. -Gamepad support is iffy. Sometimes, if your gamepad disconnects for any reason, even if you reconnect it, you're stuck using the keyboard until you close out and re-open the game. [ MIXED ]Middle of the road. +/-The magic system in this game is polarizing. Essentially, you use a command called Draw to take some magic from what you're fighting. Then you can equip that magic onto your stats via a feature called Junctioning. You can also get this magic from other sources, like converting items (cards come to mind). I personally don't get the hate for it, the system's pretty simple and lets you inch out whatever level scaled opponents you're facing with minimal thought involved, but note a lot of people don't like it. +/-With the relatively young age of the main protagonists, the ... Gunblades, and the odd direction the story tends to go in - while there's a unique identity to the world of this game, it can feel like a high school drama with magic and gun swords thrown into it sometimes. +/-It has a better story than Final Fantasy XIII. But that's not saying much.  +/-Hard to relate with the romance build up between Squall and Rinoa (two main characters), but I'm sure there's fans for that. [ PROS ]Where the game does well.+If you don't have Final Fantasy VIII and are a Steam addict, it takes three seconds to fix that Midi issue above. Square Enix sales happen a lot too, so the game's usually dirt cheap.+Triple Triad. When the world is on the brink of destruction, play card games. +You can cheat. Cheat a lot. Use the launcher to give yourself a ton of drawn magic, or use the hidden Function Keys to cheat in all kinds of things. While no Final Fantasy game is hard, this can be very useful for speed running or getting yourself up to a certain point in the game if desired. +Lots of Steam community material on where and how to mod Final Fantasy VIII into a better looking, better playing game is available. +Final Fantasy music. Always good. +Guardian Forces (this game's summons) actually level up and unlock you new abilities. This and the square button mashing damage bump when you summon them in battle makes them a lot more interesting than Final Fantasy VII's cutscene spam. +Everything concerning Chocobos, be it the Tamagotchi style Chocobo World or the overworld chocobo mining, is enjoyable.+You serve under Robin Williams, Evil Headmaster Military King who trains children to use experimental demon magic, casually hands students he wants to see die lamps that transport them to hell to fight Satan without telling them what it does. It is implied he banged the main antagonist while possessing a minor protagonist, so he was in bed with a Triple Witch. Furthermore, when the actual owner of the Garden (think flying military base) gets mad that he tried to have a political leader -murdered and fails during an already tenuous war- and attempts to placate said understandably angry nation, Headmaster Robin Williams has the appropriate response in mind after stomping off from the well mannered NORG, his lips profusely wet from screaming. "CHILDREN? FIGHT TO THE DEATH"Did I mention there's a dating hangout area for the students of this Garden, and so he has Tyrannosaurus Rex(multiple) stocked there for "training purposes?"The guy's a menace. Play this game so you can discover how Robin Williams nearly doomed the world.

												(EDIT: Due to the high level of knee-jerk downvoting I've noticed as I happily play via emulator after my steam refund, I thought I'd explain a little something: I adore FF VIII (otherwise why bother even warning people about how wretched this port is?), it's my favorite PSX Final Fantasy and my 3rd favorite, full stop. I know I use big words, but you do yourself a disservice when you don't read to the end of a document - reading is a big part of JRPGs, after all)FF VIII is a deeply misunderstood Final Fantasy, probably because it breaks with so many series traditions and has a mechanics system based around stat management. This requires more responsibility on the part of the player than a lot of JRPG fans would probably prefer; you don't just gain levels and skills, it's on you to figure out how to develop your characters the best way. But there has been plenty written about the gameplay and storyline on both sides - I would like to focus on the Steam port.You'll notice on the store page that you're also required to agree to a Square-Enix EULA. This may not seem like a huge deal, just hit "accept" and agree not to basically break down and resell the game, right? If only. You'll first be required to make a separate account, log in via their website, confirm again via email, and then enter a setup window.Here you can arrange the buttons for your controller, and here is the ultimate deal-breaker for me. Hope you arranged everything exactly as you like it, and never want to change anything, because in-game your controller buttons will be referred to by their device names, that is, B1, B2, B3, etc. This isn't so difficult until you consider that a number of characters' limit breaks and other attacks rely on timed button inputs - hope you don't ever want to play as Zell!Also, every time you start the game you'll need to use your keyboard. You cannot boot it up, grab a controller, and go. You know, the implicit promise of a console game from the PSX era.Couple this with MIDI music left over from the 15-year-old PC port and you're left with the option of spending hours installing mod after mod to (supposedly) get the game to be (maybe) playable, and I'm forced to say that once again, Square-Enix has shown itself to be the animated zombie corpse of Squaresoft. What a mess.

Teal DeerDevelopers: Square Enix Publishers: Square Enix Initial release: Feb 1999 (PSX), Dec 2013 (PC)Genre: JRPG#Worth/NotWorth: #WorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationI played and finished Final Fantasy VIII on the original PSX; In all honesty, I don't believe I truly understood the breadth of variance within the GF-Junction system. It's likely I don't understand it's subtle nuance still. This is a standard JRPG. In fact, it's THE standard or at the very least the standard for this era of gaming regarding this specific genre. This is a port of the PSX version. Meaning, all the low-res static jpeg backgrounds with your polygonal character models running around you remember are here. Complete with the pre-rendered FMV sequences that made these games stand out back on the PSX. To be fair, the switch between a static background to a FMV whilst retaining control of your characters is still impressive. Not from a technical or processing power standpoint mind you but from a purely visual effect perspective it remains immersive and effective as a story telling element. I'm not about to attempt to delve super deep into the GF-Junction system but here are the basics. You have multiple GF's (Guardian Forces) and multiple party members; You assign one or more GFs to a party member. Depending on how leveled those GF's are they allow you to Junction magic into specific stats to increase your characters abilities. Aside from this point they also allow you some leeway in drafting your own list of commands in battle. GF's can also be summoned in battle as an attack or provide buffs/debuffs depending on which you are using. Some are overtly placed in your lap while others are hidden in draw points from specific enemies and other locations. Because of how integrated this GF-Junction system is, as without it, you quite literally are only allowed to do basic attacks. Something as simple as reaching into your item bag is not feasible without them; the game grants you a fairly easy to grasp “Junction exchange” in where you can swap all GF's and magic that is junctioned without having to drag yourself through setting up each party members junction setup every time your party switches (which happens a lot). There are also auto setup options to optimize attack strength, defense or to prioritize magic should manually junctioning things prove too much to handle.Addressing more topical issuesThe game does have gamepad support. I'm aware it claims it does on the store page; I am also aware of other reviews claims of it not working. I will quickly surmise my experience with a gamepad support:  I used a X1 gamepad The D-pad was not functional without some relatively tech heavy workaround by default The opening screen requires you to press 'X' on the keyboard regardless of any gamepad setup you may or may not be using With the utility known as JoytoKey or any other keymapping software, it's a fairly simple process to setup up a gamepad to use both analog and digital controls. As well as be able to assign a face button to that pesky 'X' prompt at the title screen. It's not a big deal.THE GISTFinal Fantasy VIII is, in truth, the only Final Fantasy of the PSX era that I got past the first Disc (out of four). It remains one of my favorites to this day. Sure, it's definitely dated but at some point you might be asking for too much from a game this old.Follow my curation for more

												(no spoiler review) Final Fantasy VIII:  A pretty good RPG with some really interesting mechanics. It is now the highest number FF game I've beat, so you can tell I'm behind in the series. Even though I only just beat it, I actually owned and played FF VIII the year it came out, but got so addicted to Triple Triad that I never progressed the main story more than a few hours; so it felt really good to go back and finally beat it.A lot of the game systems threw me off at first.  Understanding Junctioning and GFs took me a really long time to figure out. Once I got used to the system, I really liked it. It was addicting to level up by GFs to get new abilities and stats on them, especially when it meant I could open up a stat to junction magic onto, which made the characters much more powerful.  However, as the game progressed, the attaching gfs and abilities to each character became probably my biggest complaint about the game. The reason for this is that every friggin' 10 minutes your party either splits off, or certain characters become unavailable, or you switch between parties, and every single time you have to switch junctions, abilities and magic to your new group (and if it affects their hp then you have to waste cure magic to bring their hp up). This drove me crazy and really disrupted the flow of the game.I highly enjoyed the Steam version of FFVIII. I read a bunch of complaints about the Steam version, but the only one that I thought was valid was that all the music was in midi format, which made it all sound horrible. Luckily, someone created a mod that replaced all the midi music files with non-midi ones, so once I installed that, I got all the regular music back again. Another bonus of the Steam version is that the game comes with a lot of cheats. They have some pretty heavy ones, like always have full health, or always do 9999 damage. The only "cheat" I indulged in was the amazing high-speed mode. By pressing F1, you could activate high-speed mode which sped everything up by a factor of five. I found this to be a great QoL feature that I used mainly during the game's ridiculously long summon sequences, grinding regular battles, and parts that I had to repeat due to me dying and reloading a save. This feature, along with the Half-Encounter/No-Encounter abilities one of my GFs learned, made it so I could cut through overly long segments and random encounters if I didn't want to deal with them.As for the story and characters, overall I thought they were good. The story got really complicated and weird towards the end, but I liked it. I had to research some stuff during the game and afterward, because the game didn't explain many things that the characters would talk about and reference, which was frustrating. I know a lot of people found Squall too moody, and he was very moody, but I really enjoyed the arc of his character. I think my two favorite characters were Quistis and Zell. I also really enjoyed Laguna, Ward and Kiros.

Late 90s Square is the greatest company of all time; they put out the following games in a between 1997 and 2001:Final Fantasy 7, Final Fantasy Tactics, Xenogears, Final Fantasy 8, Final Fantasy 9, and Final Fantasy X. Let me put it another way. In less than 5 years, old Square put out 6 of the greatest games ever made. I'm also not counting other fan favorites like Chrono Cross, Parasite Eve, and Vagrant Story. This company was a serious beast. After the release of FF12 (which was mediocre), it took the company 7 years to come out with FF13. FF13 is one of the worst games I've ever had the displeasure of playing.New Square is garbage and only their Eidos brand puts out good products. Square itself develops trash and creates terrible ports of amazing games. How many version of FF4 are there now?It's really hard for me to recommend this game. If you have no other way of playing this game, you should probably go ahead and buy it. Just know that it's not meant to be like this. I'm ashamed to even give this version a recommendation.An aside -- don't purchase Square games on Steam. Not even great Square games. Square is just looking to churn out half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ports to Steam users.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												When I was a teen, placing in my PlayStation for the first time, I knew I would be a gamer for life.  This wasn't Sonic jumping on robot creatures or the pixelated curiosities that were the original Final Fantasy's on the NES.... This was a heartwarming journey weaving an epic and timeless tale of the human spirit.I collect and play Final Fantasy games, and this one is my classic favorite.  The story and characters are more realistic than the previous games starting a trend in the series.  It hurts to relive the pixelated limits of 5th generating gaming, but if you can look past (as we all had to back then), you will see a beautiful 3D rendered world featuring elements from modern architecture, classic fantasy, sci fi, and steam punk.  This was one of the first multi-million dollar game productions, and it shows.  I'd love to see high-res versions of these backgrounds.The magic draw system is tedious to play as a completionist, but it is a fun diversion for adventurers because with every enemy encounter, there is an opportunity to draw something unique you can use in gameplay.  Also, each of your party is setup like a blank slate and you strengthen them with magic you've drawn.  So, unlike other RPGs, you can create your own jobs using any of your favorite characters.  And the backgrounds, Enemies and GFs are artistically rendered, and it's easy to feel a sense belonging to this world.  For newcomers to classic RPGs, think of a large open world game like Skyrim or Fallout 3 with quests, but with a turn-based battle system.Pro draw tips: Make every character able to draw and Mag-J if you can.  Find one weak enemy, draw with each character and hold down the confirm button.  I use Xpadder to toggle-hold it down.  If you have to draw from a stronger enemy, you can put one person on cure-duty, and I like to make Selphie weak on attack (no or weak Str-J and low level) and give her mug and put Stop on Status-J.  This is a good setup for the draw, and also a weak attack can help you bring their hp low without killing so you can finish them off by turning them into a card (which is refinable and also gains AP).  In the beginning of the game, I find galbadian soldiers (which have 4 spells) and Fish from Balamb are strong early draws.  When you convert a Fastitocalon fish to a card and refine it, you get 20 Water which is a midrange attack spell and a powerhouse on Str- J early in the game and defeating them yields 3 AP each which I think is even more lucrative for grinding than the famous cactaurs.Also, there is a chance to play the game non-violently which should appeal to some including women and girls who may also appreciate the game's romantic undertones.  Most of the enimies are not evil minions.. They are more like nature's creatures in this fantasy world.  Gaining experience from killing is not really rewarded because the enimies gain xp as you do.  However, you can non-violently draw magic.  I have a combo team: One freezes the enemy and steals items with a weak whip attack, a second draws magic, and the third heals any damage recieved.  You can also gain the coveted AP (used for building abilities for the Guardian Forces which are like spirit-assistants in battle) by turning enimies into cards (which I like to imagine is like keeping them as a pet).  Not that this release isn't without problems.  To me, the most noticable omission is analog controls.  They were a great improvement over FF 7 and brought the more realistic characters to life.  Also, it's a shame the face lift didn't make the cards in the in-game card game, Tripple Triad, higher resolution.  I also didn't like the control customizations which don't support the triggers or the D-Pad on the X360 controller; although the extra buttons are really needed.  I used Xpadder to keyboard emulate to fix that and emulating the keyboard's "confirm" key because the gamepad one doesn't work everywhere. Unfortunately, this means setting up both gamepad and kb controls in the game's settings.  I wish I could just disable gamepad support in the menu and do full keyboard emulation.  That way, I could keep it all in one place.In fact, first, the fact that it wasn't exactly the same as my mint condition Play Station 1 version infuriated me.  However, when I took my rose colored nostalgia glasses off for a moment, I can appreciate that it has HD 3D (although they had to preserve the original lo res background images).. and there are things you can do to achieve a more original look including lowering game resolution and checking the "original graphics" box in the settings.  Also, the high resolution character and GF profile pictures are a nice touch.  I found the MIDI music an acceptable with those nostalgic melodies, but I hear you can community patch it with original sound.  I imagine they had copyright issues with sony requiring them to use PC-MIDI effects.  Modern games tend to have a lot less music, so appreciate the themed soundtrack that accompanys you throughout your journey.Thank you, Square, for bringing these Final fantasy games to Steam.  I hope everyone interested chips in and rewards Square with a little fresh support for these efforts.  Not everyone can collect classic consoles like I do, and very few FF fans can collect every console every FF game was originally released on.  Even for a console collector, it can be more convenient and practical to download from steam and avoid using outdated hardware (I admit: my PS 1 joysticks are getting a bit stiff d: )  Also, we have a chance to share the classics with the younger generation.  But trust me, if you can overlook the outdated graphics, the near-futuristic sci fi and fantasy atmosphere will feel modern and timeless.

												  This is the first time I have had the opportunity to review a game I have played for years! First off for the winers and detractors remember this game was released when win98 was the hot new operating system and you had to spend a ton of cash for the great new 486 computer with maybe a 16meg video card and 4megs of ram!! Yeah guys gigabytes were a programers wetdream! The PS1 had just come out and this game was the cutting edge in graphics! Yes I played this game on such a computer.    My profile may say 11 hours played on record but I still have the original PC version installed on my system! I have played this game for hundreds of hours and have loved every second of it. Well maybe not every second cause you do have the odd OPPS! moment and there are some tough battles.    Now for the game. The port system that has been used does have it's querks like the 720p window ( what ued to be called 640 by 480) inside the fullscreen port. Starting and ending the game are a bit cumbersome as I have a cordless rumblepad so the keyboard controls do mess with me. 5.1 sound takes care of the need for ingame volume that was designed for the PS1 plugged into an old CRT possibly stero tv anyway! I did notice one graphics glitch when riding in the garden car to Balam but the sceen is short and not to important. The magic boost in the start menu was a nice touch and saves a lot of work early in the game. You still have to build up your GF levels and ablities which means your characters still get leveled up pretty fast. What I would recommend is a patch to remove the echo screen command in the sync to server message, but for the most part I can ignore it.   I have played FF1 through 8 and 12. I have FF9 but it is still on my to do bucket list YAY! Every one of those FF games has been an experiment or should I say a work in progress. Each one had a huge list of things to find make or create to advance the game and build your characters. One game does not a series make or break for that matter. This all came together in FFVIII. The side quests the card game and all the other features make this the best in the series to that date. Yes I mean way back when it came out in 98!    As for the grand expiriment that is FINAL FANTASY I can only hope to live long enough to put on the harness strap into the cage put on the VR helmet and play the game LIVE!!!   All I can really say is bravo 10 out of 10 they did not change the game during the upgrade!!!

Posted: February 27, 2016
												My absolute favorite game of all time. <3Where to begin. Hmm. //StoryI think the story is probably the most important aspect of a Final Fantasy game. The story in FF8 is, well, weird. It starts off simple enough, you are a student in a military school on your way to your first assignment. After a while things become very weird, almost dreamlike, introducing characters from different timelines and so on. This is probably one of the cons for many people, because the story doesn't really make sense. But if you read into some of the theories circulating the web (*cough* Squall Is Dead *cough*), the story starts to make sense and in my opinion becomes much more enjoyanble!//CharactersThis game has a list of lovely characters. Well, some might think the main protagonist is a bit Emo and not fit as a party-leader. And that's the beauty of it, he ISN'T fit as a party leader, he doesn't even WANT to be that, he sort of was just put in that situation and has to deal with his social anxiety and peoples problems that he can't even get his head around. In my opinion that makes this game so beautiful, because Squall reminds me of me and my personal struggles I've had. Squall seems very hounest and almost autistic in his behaviour, that makes him very real and not so much a "cliché hero" character. //GameplayWell, mostly you're stuck in cutscenes and dialogues (as sadly is the case with most FF games).The battle system is simple enough, with a gimmick, you can get a Crit attack with Squalls Gunblade if you time the attack correctly (only Squall, not the other party members). Something I almost wish they would implement on ALL characters, as it actually feels pretty satisfying.The other thing that is a heap of a mess before you really get into it, is the Junction system. Basically you Equip a GF (Guardian Force (Esper / Aeon)) in your mind, that GF in turn gives you certain Stat slots in your mind, where you can equip magic, that you gather from monsters using Draw (confused yet?). All I can say is that, it took me a 3rd playthrough as a kid before I actually fully grasped the system. That being said, I actually LOVE it now, it gives alot of customizability and you can fine-tune characters a bit more than most FF games. //MusicDefenitely one of Nobuos finest masterpieces, it suits the game very well and has several memorable pieces that sticks to me to this day, nearly 20 years later!//OtherTriple Triad is a card game in FF8 that is really good!I've played through this game more than 10 times (both PC and PS1 versions) and I'd defenitely recommend it if you have the patience, and like JRPGs in general. If not, I guess it's ok to pass, as I totally understand that this game isn't for everyone.Edit: I nominated it to " The “Test of Time” Award " in Steam Awards as it's a game I come back to very often and still enjoy.

content:
Posted: March 17
												Final Fantasy VIII is a game that was an experimental shift from the traditional Final Fantasy series. This is a game where you do not need to level and grind in order to beat the game. For that reason alone, someone can beat this game in under 12 hours if they truly wanted to. To fully embrace the characters, that is a whole different situation. To sum up the mechanics and key differences, FF8 focuses around enemies that will scale to your highest level hero. You will be allowed to have up to 3 heroes at any given time. Your main source of power comes from your summons, which act as something you can equipt in a new system called Junctioning. In Junctioning, you must attach summons and pick their respective abilities. They act as stat boosters and provide unique skills. Through this new system, you must "Draw" unique magic. These are much like your traditional spells/magic such as Fira, Cure, Esuna, only with Junctioning, you attach these limited spells like equipment and can potentially attach one spell to each attribute stat to boost them. In fact... this is your main method of powering up, not traditional grinding. Drawing magic is possible through almost every monster you encounter, or "Draw-Points" that are located throughout the game. These magic spells you "draw" are expendable and limited. If you run out, even if you have the best spells, Ultima, Holy, Demi, you must re-draw them from key locations, monsters, or through a craft system called "Refinement."A lot of people will miss the point, but this series adds a bonus method of Crafting or Refinement by means of a card game, Triple Triad. It's a simple game where you have 4 numbers for each direction, top, right, left, bottom, and you must play your strategy to beat the numbers of the previous set cards. There will be additional rules that come into play to make this much more challenging. Using these cards, you can potentially refine powerful items, some of which may make you immortal for a short duration, which is needed for the dreadful final boss.Now for the plot...You start off as Squall, who aims to pass his SeeD exam to become an official member of the most prestigious honor in the Garden. Squall and his companions take on various assigned missions, acting as mercenaries. Eventually, they are assigned a special task by Master Cid. The one who gives this task is Rinoa, our main heroine. Together, this sparks the start of a long, treacherous fight against the ambitious Galbadian Dictatorship that plans to use the Sorceress Edea to take over the world.The story will be a hit or miss for most people. Squall is your typical lazy teenager who doesn't have any plans in his life. He has a very "Why should I do this...?" attitude and does not want the burden of responsibility to rest on his shoulders. Later on, you will discover Rinoa is actually a spoiled girl from a powerful family, and everyone has a negative impression of her cause of it. She will learn to become fearful of loss as well after her first confrontation with the Sorceress. As for Squall... because Squall's "older sister" left him at an early age, he isolated himself from the world to prevent himself from being hurt. In essence, you could say these two are the most paranoid heroes you will ever come across in the FF series. But because of this, the heroes in FF8 are also the most human you will ever meet. It makes them relate-able to the average person and requires a rather mature audience to play.By the end of the game, you will discover that majority of the characters will have something personal that they struggle through. Learning about their insecurities and pasts will, without a doubt, draw you closer to loving the characters. Several parts of Final Fantasy VIII will have your heart tugged. I played this game throughout 3 very different parts of my life. Almost 10 years later, I finally got around to beating it. I appreciated it more and more each time I played it. Become the characters. Relate to them. Be prepared. This game will change you.

Posted: July 22, 2014
												Final Fantasy 8 is one of the more overlooked entries in the series. Talk to fans of the franchise and you will generally find that opinion is neatly divided on both gameplay elements and storyline. The easy to abuse Junctioning system and J-drama high-school esq plot will not appeal to everyone, but are worth experiencing if you are in anyway a fan of Final Fantasy or jrpgs. The music however is like having an entire casio keyboard ground up then forced roughly into your ear canal. Whilst the recent HD remake of Final Fantasy X had its score rearranged and brought up too our refined modern standards, with this game Square Enix seems to have taken the opposite approach and ‘de-made’ its soundtrack back to era before the original game was even created. The original PC release of FF8 featured the same MIDI chip tunes used here, possible to save space, however in 2014 I would expect the quality to be at least that of the console version from 15 years ago. Unfortunately I consider this to be a fatal issue. One of the key attractions of the Final Fantasy series has always been its music. It’s a core aspect of every game in the series and one which Square Enix’s marketing department defiantly recognises. So if you are going to go to the trouble of adding these extra features (the Japan only ‘Chocobo World’ mini-game is fully welcome) is it not worth polishing up one of the games major selling points whilst you are at it? It’s like putting sprinkles on a cupcake but not bothering to brush off the ants. In my mind the addition of an achievement system is not enough to outweigh ear wrenchingly poor music in any game, especially Final Fantasy. Unless you really really like achievements or have had your ears shaved off by a murderous barber, seek this game elsewhere.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												Bought the game for one reason......Triple Triad. Don't get me wrong FF8 is a great game, personally one of my all time favourites, however i probably spent most of my time just relaxing and playing TT. Also if you know what you're doing with TT you can get yourself a nice little headstart in the early game with some powerful magic and nice weapon upgrades.What drew me into FF8 was that it moved away from the typical FF roots and featured a setting very much like the real world. A focus was put on large cities with bustling populations, the introduction of driveable cars to the game and even a space station. For long time fans of the franchise this change in setting to a more modern day comes at a cost. We see fan favourites such as the moogles and chocobo's take a back seat and hardly feature whereas previous title had these character incorporated heavily into the game. The moogles are replaced by moombas whilst the chocobo steps aside for the more up to date method of transport the car and train.Personally i felt that compared to other FF titles the character development in 8 was pretty poor. Too many of the characters you encounter seem to fade into the background, either you don't come across them again or like some of your party memebers, seem to just be there for the ride. Other than the main characters don't expect to get to know your other party members too well.The true emphasis of FF8's combat is the Guardian Forces, or Summons as they are known in earlier titles. GF's are now vital to every aspect of combat/gameplay. When a GF is equipped or "Junctioned" GFs may be summoned. They also activate various commands such as Magic, Item, Draw, steal etc. They also allow obtained magic to be junctioned to your characters stats to give them boosts. Without a GF equipped your characters can do nothing other than a basic melee attack.The way you obtain spells is also changed for this series. Rather than buying or finding materia like you would have in FF7 you have to find Draw points throughout the world. These draw points allow you to a random quantity of a certain magic. Unlike previous titles magic acts like an item in FF8. You can hold a quantity of 99 for each spell per character meaning that unless you plan your usage out well and keep stocked up you can easily run out of a specific magic. It also makes stronger magic harder to obtain although this can be subsidised with Triple Triad if you convert cards.The thing i do like about this game is the levelling. It is possible to hit level 100 in the starting area if you have the patience, unlike previous titles you will always only need roughly 1000 exp to level up each time. The game balances this out by having the enemies scale with your level, meaning you don't have to spend hours power levelling your characters unless you enjoy doing so. Play your junctions right and you can overcome most boss fights whilst remaining a relatively low level.I could go on for ages covering every aspect of the game but it's better if you just jump in an experiment and give it a go.I would give Final Fantasy 8 a rating of 7/10 i'm basing this on:Music - 8Battle System - 7Originality - 9Plot - 7Characters - 6Replay Value - 4Visuals - 9 (for it's time)Like most FF games it's a solid title just don't expect replay value or great character development. Go in with an open mind to a different direction and setting and you will most likely enjoy this installment to the series.RIP Moogles

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Final Fantasy 8 is a black sheep in the franchise. It's got a really different battle system and a weird story.Final Fantasy 8 does away with MP and replaces it with the Draw ability! This ability makes it so you have to 'draw' magic from your opponents or from specific areas in the world in order to use that magic. Magic is now treated like an item, you can only use as many 'fire' spells as you have stocked. In order to use magic (or any ability that isn't 'attack') you have to junction GFs. These GFs are the equivilant of Eidolons from the other Final Fantasy games and can be summoned during a fight. It can be a real pain to grind on enemies to obtain magic, but fortunately, the Steam version includes a 'magic booster' which gives you 100 of a few spells.Now onto the story. Squall is... a strange character to say the least. If you thought Cloud Strife was dull, you're in for a surprise. Squall is silent, calculating, and has more internal dialogue then external. He has issues relying on people which becomes quite apparent throughout the game. The plot of the story is weird and confusing and has led to may theories on what actually happens during the game. The beginning is a lot more normal however. You are Squall Lionheart. You are a SeeD (pretty much a mercenary) in training and are about to perform in an exam to become fully ranked. You have a rival (kind of like pokemon) and you have a love interest later in the game. After the first disk, things that border the ridiculous start to happen, although they can be completely 100% explained.I liked this game because the farther you got into the game, the more you found yourself enjoying it. This game has, in my opinion, one of the hardest final boss encounters in Final Fantasy. The ending's pretty dope too.

Posted: December 16, 2015
												The mandatory account sign-up rubs me the wrong way. If we could use a star system here on Steam that would certainly cost this purchase a star. It doesn't take away from the game itself, though. I had no technical issues with the installation, account sign-up, or the game itself.FF8 is an underrated title in the series. I see a lot of people saying it was the beginning of quality downturn for the series, and I mostly disagree. The "draw" system for acquiring spells is a bit monotonous at times, but that's the only flaw that could have been thought out better. I may not like every feature of the game, but I chalk all of my other issues up to simple taste preference. You can't please everyone.Where this game fares well is storytelling, and that's really what these games are known for. Relatable characters on journeys that pull you into the game, and almost make you feel as though you have a personal stake in defeating the antagonist(s). The length of the cut scenes may seem a little excessive at times, but I enjoyed the vast majority of them.The mini-game is card-based, for those concerned with making this game last as long as possible. It isn't as repeatable long-term as Chocobos from FF7, but on the plus side you can start playing cards a lot sooner in the game, and most rare cards are attainable even if you choose to skip the task (or miss it) originally. Like I said, it's not as fun as breeding and racing Chocobo from 7, but they were never going to top that for my enjoyment anyway.Overall it was well worth the purchase. I have the original discs for PS, so I waited until I saw a nice sale on it.. but for those who are looking to play for the first time, or play again and no longer have it on Playstation, I think it's worth the full price.
