General info~Genre: Japanese roleplaying game (JRPG), belongs to Final Fantasy series~Number of players: 1~Completion time: 45-100 hours~Partially enhanced (HD) version of already existing titleStrong points+Story: A tale about the coming of age, the fear of loss, the acceptance of responsibilities, the need of expression, the importance of friendship and the warmth of love. Younger gamers might find the aforementioned topics quite boring, as I did back in the day, but as I grew up I understood why the developers chose to enrich their product with such thematology.+Content: A game suitable for both young and mature audiences.+Music: Don't take my word for it; just listen to the complete soundtrack (uploaded on youtube by TantrisOST)


YouTube™ Video: Final Fantasy VIII - Complete Soundtrack 

			Views: 1,624,510		

			Music from the video game Final Fantasy 8 from 1999, by Square Music by Nobuo Uematsu ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Musique du jeu...		

+Tradition: Many well known figures and themes of the Final Fantasy universe make their appearance in Final Fantasy VIII: Prepare to fight Malboros and Tonberries, summon Shiva and Ifrit, cast Reflect and Ultima and ride chocobos. Also, many artists already involved in previous installments are back: Yusuke Naora, Kazushige Nojima, and composer Nobuo Uematsu.+Team spirit: Create teams of three characters (from a total of six) and face challenging foes in a turn based battle-system. Experienced Final Fantasy players will tread on familiar ground while newcomers will adapt gradually thanks to the game's instructional early stages.+Not another grinding fest: Final Fantasy VIII introduced the juctioning system with which you may team up with various summoning entities and enhance your stats, abilities and defences. Thus, instead of killing enemies for hours and hours in order to level up, you are able to apply various combinations of spells to enhance your characters. You can actually finish the game with your initial level (steam achievement) thanks to this innovative progress system.+Road to the riches: You don't have to worry about buying your expensive equipment in FFVIII. Most items will be dropped from slained monsters or they can be crafted by collecting various ingredients with the help of your summoned creatures. +Along came Behemoth: Enemies level up as you do. It's your choice where and when to increase your level of experience as well as how to fortify your team in order to overcome enemies who change attack pattern as your levels go up.+Characters, NPCs, companions with interesting background and distinctive personalities. Most of them answer to the principles of japanese manga and anime culture; if you have played any other Final Fantasy game you know what to expect; and that's not necessarily a bad thing.+Environment: Both urban and rural. You can visit cities, ports, schools as well as beaches, deserts and the infamous chocobo forests; by renting a car, riding a chocobo or exploring on foot!+Chicobo: The famous pocketstation game Chocobo World which accompanied the original title is back! Train your little chocobo to the highest level, slain enemies and transfer all acquired loot to your main saved game in order to aid your team with powerful items.+Rich background: Despite starting the game "in medias res", the complex background of the game will be revealead to players piece by piece as they progress. Visit the in-game Information section often to learn new things about the world you are exploring.+Controls: Customizable in-game settings, controller support.+For seasoned adventurers and newcomers: You can level your characters up to the maximum or stay at  a low level and depend on your juctions and individual skills only.Weaknesses-Problematic PC port: This port suffers from a few issues which can be fixed with various mods or community unofficial patches. The two major problems can be found on the sound and graphics department:  Despite the fact that characters, spells, summons and vehicles are graphically enhanced , the background remains in low resolution. Click  here for an example. As for the sound, the main issue is its bad quality. You can fix this problem by downloading a mod called Roses and Wine. Consult the Steam guide section  for links. SquareEnix could have spent more time improving their product.-Juctioning: Ironically, one of Final Fantasy VIII's best features is at the same time one of its flaws. Juctioning can make your team almost invincible and it's quite simple to comprehend as long as you have spent time on the tutorial understanding how the system works. Unfortunately, while the game extricates the players from many hours of useless killing, they must still draw spells from various enemies at large quantities for maximum junctioning effect. This can be time consuming as well.-Spam this sword: Although the juctioning system gives a lot of choises as to how you wish to develop your team, in the end you might end up saving your acquired spells and magic for stat enhancement only and just spam the attack command to dispatch your enemies. This issue might frustrate or disappoint some players who prefer to play with mixed teams (fighters and mages) or the older fans of the series who prefer variety and strategies during boss fights.-Smithing: Final Fantasy VIII features limited character costumization. Your characters' appearance cannot be changed since you do not have access to armor or other protective equipment. The only item you can actually costumize is each character's weapon. Ironically, weapon enhancement is not advisable until the latest stages of the game due to the the fact that enhanced weapons feature negligible upgrades compared to the initial weapons equipped on each character. Long story short, upgrade your weapon to their ultimate forms only.Neutral ground±Price: Preferably buy it during a sale.±Permanently missable content: Meticulous players who enjoy searching every nook and cranny of the world, won't have serious problems finding most items in the game. But for the rest of you, it might be a good idea to consult a detailed guide if you want a perfect run with all the achievements unlocked on one playthrough.My rating4/5Final Fantasy VIII was cursed to grow under the shadow of its predecessor. Up to this day, many gamers form an opinion about this game without having played it themselves. It might not be as flashy or fancy as VII or IX but thanks to its thematology, soundtrack and juction system it deserves a spot among the greatest games of its genre. Concerning the issues I mentioned on the “Weaknesses” section, try consulting Steam guides on how to surpass the low quality sound or graphic issues you may have.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												  FF8 is a good game. For those new to FF this would be an odd start. Each FF has a little gimmick within their gameplay. FF8 introduces a "junction" system which can be confusing at first. In actuality it's pretty lame, but a cool concept. In previous FFs magic would drain MP, but in FF8 magic is drawn(upto100) from various points in game, and from monsters. All while requiring a GF(gaurdian force) to be "junctioned" to that character. In order to actually buff your characters, junctioning magic is required. Unlike in other FFs leveling hardly boosts stats. It is required to draw a lot of one spell just to buff a character efficiently. What makes plain leveling useless is the fact that enemies are level'd according to the party's average level. People have beaten the game low level'd with proper junctions alone.   Also... you can find yourself mashing GF summons early on... which means watching a cutscene, damaging enemy, and continuing fight. Not only is combat a bit dull compared to other installments, there doesn't seem to be much enemy variety. The final area's random encounters are monsters that you fight throughout the game. Although the little summon cutscenes are pretty great for 1999.   Other than the combat the game plays like a novel. A very nice story, and smooth character developement. Even with a story that is all over the place, literally, it is shown beautifully. Oh, there is also extra things like "Triple Triad". It's a card game played with cards collected while progressing. There's a whole bunch of other things involving the cards, but no need to mention it. Just more things to do rather than blowing through the story. Never bothered playing any card matches(or using cards) in my playthrough.   Like I said in the first sentence... FF8 IS a good game. IMO not the best FF, but definitely better than some of the  recent releases. ON THE SUBJECT OF THIS PARTICULAR PORT: It has some issues.   The sound isn't on point  Takes a bit too much space. Apparently not compressed well.  Square Enix has an annoying requirement of making an account for their servers. Bad enough it's on the steam DRM. Feels even more distant.... BUUT it doesn't intrude much and y'all can still play offline, I believe.

And it really is worth playing; it's the black sheep of the Playstation FF games, but that makes it interesting. It's broken, has an even more ridiculous plot than usual, dungeons are very often literally copy-pasted together, and the ever-present card game brings the pace to a crawl. But, it also has a great cast, interesting changes to the typical FF ruleset, the card game is fun, and the settings are varied and beautiful while creating a more consistent universe than its immediate predecessor.THAT SAID...If you have a Playstation/PS2 hooked up to a CRT TV/XRGB-type scaler, or an emulator with a good CRT TV simulation mode, you will have a vastly better experience. The game is designed around the limitations of the Playstation, and the PC version makes no attempt to hide the "strings", such as they are.  The backgrounds are 320x240 scaled up with nearest neighbour scaling, while the characters are rendered for native resolution and filtered, and it creates a distracting mismatch - only exascerbated by "crowd scenes" where the crowds are baked into the backgrounds, designed to match up with low resolution Playstation models but completely out of place with the smooth, detailed characters.It's actually kind of fascinating to get a the behind-the-curtain perspective on the game like this, it gives you an appreciation for the craft and cleverness of the developers - but it takes you out of the game, looks like crap, and that sucks.  Games designed for low resolutions should be played in low resolutions.Also, by default, the music uses awful general MIDI versions of the soundtrack.  There are mods to fix this, but it's kind of unacceptable to put out a rerelease of a game praised for it's music with a general MIDI soundtrack in the year 2014.  My god, you don't have to fit it on 4 CDs anymore, you can distribute it with a recorded soundtrack!I recommend it because it's good, but the presentation is awful.  Step up your game, Squeenix.

Posted: February 18
												Final Fantasy VIII was one of the first Final Fantasy games I ever played (along with VII), and even after all the years that have passed since I first picked up this game and have played more and more Final Fantasy games in the series, I always find myself coming back and playing this game. This game was something special for me, maybe it was because it was one of the first RPG's that I ever played or some other reason, but this game has not lost its luster to me. I absolutely love this game and I very much recommend to anyone who is wanting to start playing a game in the Final Fantasy series. A lot of the things that I love about this game is the story (the only few complaints that I may have is for people new to this game, the story may be a little hard to follow at certain points, and people like to complain about how much of an emo that the main character happens to be which kind of turns some people off to this game), the cast of characters range from emotionless to flameboyant, the magic system is a good change of pace from the typical MP system that had been a part of the games before for a very long time, and overall is a nice change of pace from a lot of the other games in the series as this game tries to blend fantasy with realism (the cities for instance show many signs of fantasy and realism in them), plus the soundtrack is beautifully composed. However the one major complaint I have about this port is the butchering of said soundtrack (which I recommend to anyone to go and get the Roses and Wine mod which replaces the butchered soundtrack with the original). Overall, this game is something special and I think for anyone who is either new to the series, or someone who's played Final Fantasy games before but has never picked this game up, I highly recommend playing it, it's a game that can be played over and over again, either trying to play seriously, or waste away playing Triple Triad.

Posted: June 23, 2016
												I remember playing this game in the early 2000s I think I played it the most out of all the Final Fantasies. I was searching YouTube one day and I came across some game theories so to get a better understanding of it I decided to get it on a whim. The game is as great and enjoyable as I remember it even though I played it all the time I always feel like it is a brand new experience. I grew up with it and have always loved it and my appreciation for it only grows as I get older anyway enough gushing you clicked this for a review so here we go.Graphics: The game does look good it always looked good however sad to say upscale pre-rendered graphics do not hold up well the art though really well done does show its age as they can be blurred and through the sharpened quality you can see errors in the textures a lot easier. Character models however are very well done the pre rendered cut scenes are well made and are well shot and the in game sprits are smoothed out almost flawlessly (blocky Rhinoa legs anyone). Despite these gripes it in no way takes away from the full game. This is my first review so please give me your feed back so i can give you all better ones in the future.Music: It's final fantasy nuff said the music is excellent and fits the game perfectly. There are scores that strike my nostalgia cords as well as my feels and never fail to get me invested.Characters: Again it is final fantasy the characters are genuinely likable and compliment the story well except you Irvine stay away from Selphie you fiend she's mine!Story: It is a well done story however around the second story arc it gets confusing but again what final fantasy doesn’t the story takes you on a journey that will have you locked in place until the very end though some of the story aspects seem clichéd by today’s standards they are however clichéd because they work.Challenge: The enemies in this game scale up with you so as you grow stronger they will become more dangerous this is a welcome change or a really hated change from previous Final Fantasies depending on who you are. It takes a very good understanding of the Junction system to keep up with the difficulty curve you will undoubtedly find yourself getting smacked around with if you do not prepare well. SAVE OFTEN I can't stress this enough because sometimes this game can be downright frustrating and brutal at times but the payout is rarely not worth it.Overall: This game was an excellent piece of work in 1999 and the port is an excellent piece of work almost 17 years later it holds up well and is very enjoyable to play with it has a romantic story and plentiful side quests as well as super bosses and hiddend summons that come with their own abilities that you can learn you will not regret playing this I give this game a solid 8/10 despite the clichés the brilliant twists, the musical score, the likable cast and a solid world to explore at your leisure make up for it. The game has flaws just like any other but it is well worth its asking price.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												I first played this game when I was around 11 years old. I hated it to be honest, the game was too confusing for me at the time and the system was weird, nothing like the almighty Final Fantasy 7 that I loved. Naturally, some years later I wanted to make a better judgement of it, and I did, and I absolutely loved it. Now that the game is on Steam, I can make a review with my memory completely freshened up after beating the game for the 3rd time, after many unfinished playthroughs.Everything from this game seems to be way above and beyond of what gaming was at the time. The game is modern, it feels modern and even the system is unlike any other title. The way you build your characters is very unique in the sense that you can costumize every single detail and no character is like any other, the choices are also limited so you can't have a character doing absolutely everything while the others do nothing, which makes the concept of a party much more likely to happen. Aeons or Summons have always been a big part in Final Fantasy games, but never like in FF8, not even in FF10 are Aeons as important as Guardian Forces in FF8, this makes the amazing GF cinematics in FF8 much more wanted, which for me was an issue in other games, they looked awesome, but physical attacks just cut it better in FF7, for example.The characters all have a big role in the story (which will be the last part I'll talk about), and they're all well crafted, none of them are spot-fillers, they're there, they're unique in their personalities and traits and they're just not annoying. In other titles I've always felt there was this one character I didn't like, but I think it's the fact that in FF8, there's only 6 characters that makes it so much easier to like them all.The side-quests are bad and few. And this is all I should say about this, but it won't be. The only ''side-quest'' you should be partaking in is the Card Quest, but unfortunately even to obtain all the cards you have to complete most of the other boring, dull, hard to find and hard to complete without guidance side-quests, this is the biggest flaw in the game in my opinion, the game barely gives any hints on how to find or complete most side-quests and you're forced to search the internet for most, such as the PuPu quest (after the 3rd occult fan, no more hints are given), or obtaining the Tonberry King GF (There's one mention of it in Trabia Garden, but one would only get so far to getting the GF by sheer persistence and guessing.And before we move on to talk about my favourite part of the game, let's talk about how I love the draw system. Many people hate this system, some think it's unfair, some think it's boring, I personally think it can be whatever you want it to be. I have a system when I play that I get the magical and the defensive character do the drawing and have the offensive character do the killing. It works because it raises the stats equally and it's not boring at all, so I reach the middle of the game with all my characters balanced and even the ones outside the party get to have spare magic. And it's also super fun finding out magic from monsters.Now, the story. The perfect, yet flawed story that makes me think this is the best game I've ever played (I've never have a game that I wanted to replay right after finishing it). The story is incoherent? Maybe. Maybe the story is confusing and has a lot of twists and weird happenings throughout the game. But it's all resolved in the end... Or is it? There are 2 theories to the story of this game that I love to discuss about, and they both make a lot of sense, but they're just theories, because the story allows for them to exist, the story isn't vague but it has this open space for creativity that's just right. I won't go into many details because of spoilers, but when certain things in the game come together and you start figuring out certain things, it just makes you go "wow...", and everything unfolds and makes sense in front of you, it's brilliant.Also, Selphie is adorable.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Final Fantasy VIII is a bit ridculous.No, really - this game had a huge impact on me when I was 12 years old, so when I saw it up for grabs on Steam I acted fast. And you know what? Holy cow is this just goofy as hell. Of course, we should all be willing to admit that cliches are what FF is all about, and that's not a bad thing. It's just that VIII attempts to be a deconstruction and the story is frequently tripping and falling on its own "and now a twist!" approach that gets a tad bit tired by the "disc 2" segment. That being said, I do enjoy the  settings as they're consistently well-rendered and imaginitive. I'd expect nothing less of the team from this era.The characters? Pretty damn bland. There's a certain backstory that ties in importantly, but it doesn't really explain why (with the exception of a couple) these characters are all so ridiculous. Only Squall, the mainest of main characters, has a degree of depth and even then it falls into borderline-woe-is-me nonsense. The models are certainly worth snickering at (to be fair, that's the age showing).As for the gameplay itself - it's pretty fun! It's also pretty easy to manipulate if you know what approach to take with the juncitoning system. Putting the right spell on the right stat makes things so quickly breakable that it blew my mind how much trouble I had as a kid. Still, it's fun trying in mix and match what element you're going to smack what enemy with. And that Eden summon never gets old. Stuff like this is why I've avoided strategy guides ever since I turned 14. It's going to be fun if you don't know exactly what item does what function.In summation, this is certainly a game that can be fun to play if you've never played it before... Just know your tastes.

The areas are super pixelated, but that's understandable since it's a PSX port, but the world map is a mess, and comparing with the PSX version, you clearly see that they just blurred the world map textures to not give that pixelated feel, which results in a huge fail of nice textures.For three: Controls. I mean, yah this is a PSX port and those controllers had only the directional pad, but it had full joystick support, meaning that you can move in any direction freely. This though, if you use a gamepad, you can only move in the 8 directions, D-pad or Joystick. This game is hard to get around without the freedom of moving in any direction. Even when using a controller, it's Button 2, Button 5, etc, not giving Xbox 360/PS3 controls. That just shows how rushed and lazy this port is.Don't buy this port. I am really disappointed with this.

												Final Fantasy VIIIRPG-Developed by SquareSoft / Square EnixYear 1999/2000 The Story  8/10You are Squall Leonhart an orphan and SeeD of Balamb Garden. SeeD is a mercenary group trained to fight the sorceress. You awake in the hospital wing after your training session with your fellow student Seifer. As your progress you go on your final exam to become a SeeD and be deployed around the whole world. Your first mission helping out a resistance faction. Sets you on a course that will change the entire world.Grahpics 7/10The graphic are better than Final Fantasy 7 fewer blocky textures. More movies they transition seemlessly between gameplay. The way monsters die is cool. Some will turn of stone or explode. Most just fall over and die I like that more than them turning red and dissappering like in Final Fantasy 7.  There are graphics mods that will improve the game if you can install them.Music 0/10  after JunkyBiggs music mod 10/10The music on this release of the game is poor... not of worry though it's a simple fix after you install the game just replace the muisc files with the converted ones thanks to JunkyBiggs. It takes less then 1 mintue to do this. Just look in the Guides section you will find his and many of music mods there.The music in the game is amazing all the songs "Eyes on Me" The Man with the Machine Gun" those are my favorites. The opening theme "Liberi Fatali"  The battle theme "Don’t Be Afraid" and the nice "Waltz For The Moon" all amazing. The songs all fit and game and fit what you are doing at the time.Gameplay 10/10The gameplay I love as it makes you have to think about what you are doing. In Final Fantasy 8 the monsters all level along with your party, Their level is ramdonly decided as a few levels higher or lower than your average current partys level. If you had say Squall at level 100 and Zell at lvl 8 than monsters you run into would be from lv60-80. Summons or Guardian Forces / GF The GF play a major rule as they allow you to junction. The Junction system allows you to junction magic to your stats to makes yourself more powerful. Monsters do not level with your GF. It's really the base of the game it's easy to figure out and the in game tutorials explain it very well. The animations for the GF can become repetitive over time. Otherwise I really like this system myself it's fun and allows you to play the whole game without leveling at all.Money / GilYou are paid in this game based on your SeeD rank. Your SeeD rank is really based off of how many monsters you kill. There are a few other times in the story where doing your job right will up your rank but, not many. What I didn't like about this is that your rank falls after a short time. There are tests you can take to up your rank they as well. Making money becomes very, very easy once you get GF tonberry. So don't worry about money after you get him and train him you will never run out of funds.Chocobo WorldMake sure you start using this as soon as you get boko from your first forest. Boko will make getting items very easy. Do not start chocobo world while Boko is set to Home. You will gltich the game and have to start over with a new boko. Just remeber to close chocobo world bring him home get his items and send him back before opening it agian. I'll save you some time the best ID is in fact "211" use the do over button till you get ID 211 it'll make the game much easier as boko will be a total pwnage machine.The Card Game Triple TriadI found triple Triad to be fun not challanging though. You are providing with cards of insane power by the time you get the GF brothers. Don't mix rules as they are very hard to get back to normal. The game is played on a 3x3 size board. You and your npc opponent start by selecting 5 cards and using the number rating and rules to flip and cards placed down. It's very simple and enjoying as long as you don't mess up and rule system. I'll say this again do not ever mix rules!Chocobo ForestsI didn't like how they used chocobos in this final fantasy. After 7 had such fun with them all you can do in this one is ride them around the map. I would have liked to have had another race track or something along those lines sadly chocobos fall short in this game. I give the Chocobo Quest in this game a 3/10 it was boring. I give this game a 8/10 I recommend you play it if you love RPGs

content:
Posted: March 9
												While it may not be the best in the Final Fantasy series, FF8 holds a big place in my heart. This is the first time I've played the game, so I'm not speaking with feelings of nostalgia here.Gameplay: Initially, I was turned off. The Junction system wasn't something I was used to. MP doesn't exist here with magic being a consumeable item. It's just something you draw from enemies or synthesize. I rarely casted magic against monsters and used it as a stat upgrade, which left a bad taste in my mouth. Eventually though, I learned to like the system. Once you get the hang of it, it's like a fact of life that you don't put much thought on. It's also easy to power up your party, making this one of the easier FF games.Sidequests: Not a lot. Plus most of the sidequests are not difficult to accomplish. They are just time-consuming. To note a few challenges, there's a Steam achievement called "Contrived Victory"; you may have to play through the game a second time. Card collecting is also a big hassle.Story: I really enjoyed the story even if it was presented in a confusing manner. For a game that had schools training teen soldiers, warring factions, and a time compression scheme by a corrupt sorceress, I didn't feel the gravity of the world's situation until the middle of Disc 3. That's just something funny to observe. You could tell that the game's theme was about friendship and love being the most precious thing that surpasses past, present, and future. Cheesy but endearing. (Squall and the gang are #squadgoals; Laguna and the gang are #squadgoals)Music: Memorable. There are strong pieces in the game that you will download and listen to on repeat. They go very well with the various places scattered in the world. My favorite scene was when "Compression of Time" started playing. To me, that will always be an iconic moment in the game.(Just make sure to replace the bad steam port music with the orginal PS1 version!!! It makes the gaming experience significantly better!)All in all it is highly-reccommended you play FF8. The whole game plays like a sentimental memory because time is what brings this whole game together. There's a lot to be had in FF8 that will give you a great experience despite its' imperfections.

												Final Fantasy VIII: HD, Triple-Tiad and MusicWell, I finally bought Final Fantasy VIII for my PC and I'm glad I did, but there's one problem. After playing 7 and 8 for the first time on the PS3, I was so impressed by how these old games made me fall in love with its worlds and characters, it proved to me that AAA graphics, Sound design and even voice acting doesnt make a great game. By todays standards, these game are dated. When i first played FF VII last year I laughed at the terrible graphic, cheesey music and blocky characters. after destroying the first Mako reactor, I was hooked: The pre-rendered backgrounds looked beautiful, The music was emotional, and combat was rewarding and fun, the blocky characters still look bad. In short terms, I no longer look at these games based on their graphic's or age. FF VII is one great game, even by todays standards. theres a reason why everyone calls it the best. which brings me to FF VIII. Just like VII it was an excellent game. Not as mind blowing as VII, but still great. Playing the mini card game Triple-Triad was a blast. Can you believe it? I was playing a game......within a game (that was actually fun). Yes these games where so good, I decided to throw my money into Gabe's face and buy them both on Steam. FF VII = perfect PC port. HD graphic's, same music from PSX and achievements. The same could be said about FF VIII, everything is great, but the MUSIC!. Seriously, what the hell am i listening to? everything is a note too high or too low, it sound awful compared to PSX music. Its a real shame, because if you've already played the thing on PlayStation, then the music will stick out like a sore thumb. Apart from the sound issue, this is a great game to play. I just hope SquareEnix release Final Fantasy 9 on steam to make yet another game that much better. Just dont touch the sound. Kupo.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												The game is one of the under-appreciated game of the series. This game suffers being in the shadow of FFVII which in the time was a masterpiece. This game excels itself and I actually prefer this game to FFVII. One thing that FFVIII excelled over FFVII is the lead character.IMHO Squall is a much better protagonist than Cloud and he's one of the best of the series. You know what he's always thinking, and he's actually human compared to the other lead characters in the series. Throughout the game you can see his conflict in life caused by his troubled childhood. He wants to be alone because he's lost so much, he's not tough, deep inside he's weak and he cant accept losing anyone important to him, which is why he prefers to be alone, so he never has to lose anyone. The plot has many holes, but the overall story and the characters more than make up for it. The battle system is nothing like the other FFs. Drawing system to stock magic is a nuisance, and frankly it deters me from using magic completely, only for the sake of junctioning. The junctioning system has always divided opinion, but it is easily mastered if you put some effort into it and I really enjoy experimenting with each character's stat.Overall, this is a great game but the port is quite poor. The music for some reason is ported poorly and that is the main highlight of this game so if you do pick this game up,do something about it.

  A great buy    Category Score   Gameplay 8/10   Music 8/10   Graphics 8/10   Controls 5/10   Replayability 10/10  Overall Score 7.8/10    Perks	  This game is a great port. Escellent in fact, but nothing is without flaws. Thank fully this game doesn't have too many of them. First lets look at some purchase perks. The game comes with baked in cheats, mods, acheivements, and chocobo world. To thouse who've played the original Chocobo World on it's own should be enough to want to purchase this remake as previously the only way to play it, and take advantage of the unique to the game items, were through cheats/hacks, or having a playstation pocket, and a playstation that could read it, so for this content alone you might be getting your money's worth. Next square enix has included acheivements. I don't have to tell you how achievements (or trophies if you think with a playstation mindset) didn't became mainstream until around 2005, so they are new and it gives you something to do along the way while playing, although there is plenty to do without them. The mods, are great. most importantly, the speed mod is great. If you've ever been pressed for time and not a lot of time for sitting through un-skippable cutscenes, or watching about 3-4 mins of traversing a map it definately comes in handy. Lastly the cheats. The game comes with some cheats built in such as the 100 spell cheat where you can draw a spell, and either press the cheat button, or save the game and run the cheat and you will have 100 of that spell. I haven't actually used any of the cheats, because I don't want to deprive myself of the bits of grinding here and there, but It's there if you need it.  Gameplay Lots to love here. This game gives you options. No you will not have a different ending, but you have options to give yourself a different playthrough. The game levels itself up as you do, so you can play it a stratight shoot, or you can withold your level and work on crafting and farming items. You can grab the first magic that comes to mind, or you can be selective to carry the best magics. A lot of people will drill that the stat's suffer from using your stronger spells, but it's perception. I think of it as it expends energy to use the stronger spells making you weaker with use. With no GF challenges, or other self made playing challenges you can replay the game and have a whole different experience.  The cons You've heard the positives now here are a few sour spots. The music. As you may have heard plenty beofre the musing isn't the best. It's heavily synthesized and sounds like a fan did all the music in their favorite mid player. It's the same as it was in the original game but with the concerts put out, most have grown acusomed to the higher level of music. It's a minor setback, one that could have been corrected by square enix much like the visual updates. The magic system. It is unique, and has a lot of give and take, but just as much as I applaud the using mgic drains your stats idea, the magic just isn't that strong. There aren't that many powerful spells, and because of it you're likely not to try creating any mages, or see your characters have much in differentiating stats. The controls for this port are bad, you can change your controls, but I haven't found out how to succesfully setup a controller, even with an xbox controller and support for them in the game. Even worse you can't turn off (or I haven't found out how to) controller controls and as you use your keyboard. In any dialogue that involves the controls the control controls display until you press, and/or hold down your keyboard keys. it's very frustrating.  Conclusion As the title imples the game is defeinately a great buy due to the many perks, and how they way outweigh the cons.  If you want a very engrosing story, amazing cutscenes, music you will catch yourself humming to, Interesting gamign mechanics that offer plenty of replayability and hours upon hours of standard gameplay. Plenty of secrets, so much that you may need a guide or two to find them all. Lastly, the mini games chocobo world, and triple triad are good enough to be spinoffs of their own, and are beneficial, albeit optional, to the game. If you've been on the fence about it, or you have wanted to try it previously but haven't yet pick this one up or regret it.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												This is still one of my favorite Final Fantasy games, and the PC benefits over the PS1 are pretty nice. I love the ability to speed up the cinematics to 60 fps, which make the scenes look fantastic, although everything is moving at twice the speed, thus making it a much shorter cutscene, which is the closest thing to being able to skip it. But if you've already sunk hundreds of hours into it before, then it's definitely worth checking out, especially when it's on sale. If you havent played it before, its still definitely worth the money. The cutscenes still look good (for the time they were released, especially) and the overall game doesn't look too shabby compared to others from its time. The ability to summon GFs  (basically pets) and unlock loads of skills for then as well as everyone in the party is awesome. The magic/GF/Ability junction feature is also one of my favorite implemented systems, making it much easier to help overcome more powerful opponents once you've gotten used to utilizing it. Only downside to that is that you constantly need to stock magic in order to keep your stats as buffed as possible, which can take awhile and becomes a bit tedious. But overall, the mechanics are very smooth and simple. The story is very well done too. It's enough of a driving factor to keep people who may not like grinding very much to stay interested, although there's no journal or anything of that nature to keep you focused on where to go next, which may become a problem if you decide to stop playing for a while and resume later. That's one of my only real problems with this game. Most adventure/open world games have some sort of journal or objective list in case you forget where you're supposed to go next, or at least who to talk to. That aside, I'd still highly recommend this game to just about anyone who loves the old school RPG style of game play with some unique mechanics and a good storyline.TL;DR Buy this game. It's a great part of the FF series.

												Final Fantasy VIII seems to exist in a crossroads. The game is either loved by fans or dismissed as being not of Final Fantasy norm. Due to some changes in its core mechanics and its reliance on much more realism in the characters and worlds compared to other Final Fantasy games of the era, many prefer its predecessor Final Fantasy VII or its successor Final Fantasy IX that utilize more fantasy driven environments and characters. Final Fantasy VIII however is a title not to be missed by any story afficianado or RPG enthusiest. The story is of top notch quality and the depth to which you will find yourself emersed is unparallel.Having purchased and completed Final Fantasy VIII twice on the original PlayStation I decided to purchase it again to relive one of my favorite games of all time on the PC with its slightly better visuals and increased resolution.  I still have yet to play a game with as much emotional connection to the characters as this game did back in 1999. The controls are a little awkward and take time to get used to but other than that the game as a whole has been running flawlessly for me. Load times are MUCH faster as compared to the PlayStation version, and the sounds are intact with no glitches for me. If you’ve never played the game before, you’re in for a ride that you won’t forget.

content:
Posted: March 9
												While it may not be the best in the Final Fantasy series, FF8 holds a big place in my heart. This is the first time I've played the game, so I'm not speaking with feelings of nostalgia here.Gameplay: Initially, I was turned off. The Junction system wasn't something I was used to. MP doesn't exist here with magic being a consumeable item. It's just something you draw from enemies or synthesize. I rarely casted magic against monsters and used it as a stat upgrade, which left a bad taste in my mouth. Eventually though, I learned to like the system. Once you get the hang of it, it's like a fact of life that you don't put much thought on. It's also easy to power up your party, making this one of the easier FF games.Sidequests: Not a lot. Plus most of the sidequests are not difficult to accomplish. They are just time-consuming. To note a few challenges, there's a Steam achievement called "Contrived Victory"; you may have to play through the game a second time. Card collecting is also a big hassle.Story: I really enjoyed the story even if it was presented in a confusing manner. For a game that had schools training teen soldiers, warring factions, and a time compression scheme by a corrupt sorceress, I didn't feel the gravity of the world's situation until the middle of Disc 3. That's just something funny to observe. You could tell that the game's theme was about friendship and love being the most precious thing that surpasses past, present, and future. Cheesy but endearing. (Squall and the gang are #squadgoals; Laguna and the gang are #squadgoals)Music: Memorable. There are strong pieces in the game that you will download and listen to on repeat. They go very well with the various places scattered in the world. My favorite scene was when "Compression of Time" started playing. To me, that will always be an iconic moment in the game.(Just make sure to replace the bad steam port music with the orginal PS1 version!!! It makes the gaming experience significantly better!)All in all it is highly-reccommended you play FF8. The whole game plays like a sentimental memory because time is what brings this whole game together. There's a lot to be had in FF8 that will give you a great experience despite its' imperfections.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Final Fantasy VIII is my all time favorite RPG. Why? Because it's one of the first video games I ever got into, so naturally I have some sentimental value. That being said, I'll give as unbiased of a review as I can on this game.StoryThe story of Final Fantasy VIII is somewhat strange and can be hard to follow at times, but, it's Final Fantasy. I wouldn't consider any of the games normal story wise. I find the characters to be very individual and personable. While Squall does start out as somewhat cynical and brooding, you, as the player, slowly watches him grow and develop into a new person in a very natural way. Not to mention he has one of the most badass weapons ever created, though it's nowhere near as interesting as Selphie's comically large nunchaku that everyone is just kind of okay with.GameplayA lot of people gripe about the system in VIII. Truth is, you aren't understanding it. If you think you have to sit for hours and draw magic from random monsters, you aren't playing the game right. Learn the system inside and out and you can make absolutely insane characters. I tested just how strong you could go, and ended up soloing most of the game with Selphie. More so, the battle system is fun, and a little bit more interactive than just hitting Attack over and over again. The GF's (Summons) are powerful, and completely infinite use, and the center of the whole system. While the animations for the GF's can be somewhat long, if that doesn't bug you, it can make for pretty epic battles visually, with respects to when the game came out. Magic works like Ammo, with no MP system, and you can obtain more through various ways. There are a lot of extra abilities you can learn as well, which can help specialize each character.VisualsAgain, it's a PSOne game, and while the character models recieved a nice upgrade, the field took a pretty serious hit. I honestly have no idea why they couldn't upgrade everything on a PC but I'm not gonna complain too much. The art of the world is very sci fi and quite beautiful in my opinion. There is a lot of realism, which both characters and field. While a bit futuristic, it's very believable to see these towns as places that could actually exist (barring Esthar).AudioUnfortunately, all the music in the PC version of this game is in the MIDI format. It's not nearly as good as the original soundtrack, but if you can get over that hump, it's still the same music, just crappier quality. There are ways to patch it if you really want to, but it doesn't bug me enough to want to change it. Oddly enough about 90% of the sound effects stayed the same. There are some minor differences, most notable in Quezacotl's summon sequence, but for the most part, they are all the same. Force Your Way will forever be my single most loved video game song ever.BugsSo far, I haven't encountered any serious bugs. If you tab out of the game, sometimes all of the music will stop playing, which is weird. Incredibly weird. Final Fantasy VIII with no music makes for an odd and awkward experience. Everything just kind of feels... empty.OverallI would highly recommend this game to anyone really. Hell, I bought this game for a good chunk of people for the holidays. If you are an RPG fan, give this a shot. It might just be your next favorite.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Truly an incredible game. I can't say tho which one is better, this or 7 ... but I'm sure this is one of the most underrated Final Fantasy game. Maybe because it was released almost instantly after 7? I don't know but you really won't go wrong if you start playing this. Also Squall was kinda closer to my heart than Cloud. His personality is something I can relate to but also the fact that character development has a bigger focus in this game than in 7.It's hard to talk about the story without any spoilers but I've really liked it. Even the ending which is something "controversial" or at least heavily debated by the fanbase.Obviously the game is almost 20 years old so the graphics are a bit dated but that doesn't take away anything from the experience. But it's highly recommended to use some mods to make the game better. Here are the ones I've used:1. Tonberry: Ehanced. You need that for modding. http://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=15945.02. SeeD Reborn. Full menu overhaul. http://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=15320.03. Roses and Wine. Full high quality PSX music instead of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ MIDI music we got with the PC release. http://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=13715.04. Xbox360 controller icons. That's optional ofc but I recommend to play with a controller. http://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=15905.0Also this is not a hard game but it can be difficult! The game is kinda vague about what you should do (there is no quest system!) so I highly recommend to use a non-spoiler walkthroughhttp://jegged.com/Games/Final-Fantasy-VIII/Walkthrough/Disc-1/01-Balamb-Garden.htmlThat leads to the biggest con of the game. It's not the story, the art, or the characters... it's the fact that the game is mechanically broken. Basically imbalanced. By the end of disc 1 (which is still the early game) you can max out your GFs, all your party members can have 5k HP and one shot every enemy. And don't even mention the infinite money glitch. I don't say it's bad but in the end it makes the game really easy (much easier than 7). In the other hand you can ignore these things but it's in the game, in front of your eyes. Hard to pass it when otherwise you would need to grind the same NPC for hours just to get the desired loot. It didn't take anything away from the game for me but it has to be mentioned.Also don't ignore the Triple Triad card game! Collecting cards is fun and the game is also fun to play. The best game inside a game ever.I recommend to use Gamer Corner FF8 database for researching items and cards (what to refine to what, where to find X items and monsters etc.)http://guides.gamercorner.net/ffviii/Also it has a nice Junction Workshop where you can optimze your GF setup http://guides.gamercorner.net/ffviii/workshop/What else to say? A great game. Just go and start playing it. Now!

Posted: March 3, 2014
												At first, this game took me a while to get into due to the strange magic and stat system as well as the general world of the game, but I ended up surprising myself by how likable it ended up being.In this game, you can gather magic spells from enemies via battle command, and then recast the spells, or equip them onto your stats to make them increase. This felt like a very weird system, having to gather and collect spells just to cast them later, as well as how slow you'd gather the spells. I later learned that the higher your magic stat, the faster your magic gathering would become, and I also learned that magic generally wouldn't be used a lot in normal combat anyways, so you'd rarely touch your huge pile of magic spells unless a boss or healing.What really makes me like this system is equipping the spells to your stats, since the more magic you have of that type you're attaching to a specific stat (maximum 100 stack of any spell), the higher boost that stat would recieve. It also takes into account what kind of magic is being placed onto the stat, so placing something like... haste onto your speed stat would give it a massive boost. Casting spells equipped to your stats would cause that stat to lower, due to a smaller stack being there now, so you might end up finding a use for many spells you'd never even give the chance in other FF games.I've personally only played FF4, 5, 6, and 7 (as well as this game), but I find this manages to be my second favourite, even beating out games I have a nostalgic feeling for. A well-written and interesting story, wonderful soundtrack (even though I think this port has a different one, but I haven't heard the original), and a cast of characters I ended up warming up to the same as the protagonist. If you haven't played this, I strongly recommend you give it a try if you're into "turn-based" RPGs, since it was a wonderful experience for only $12.

												After FF7 I was rly excited to play FF8 on steam after unbelievable 15 years :D I remember having loved this game and I was curious what I would think about it after so many years.As in all Squaresoft (Square Enix) RPGs you can spend A LOT of time playing this game and some sidequests are rather annoying but if u dont ant to play them then just dont :)The game itself isnt rly difficult...well obviously it depends on your characters skill but I got through without any big problems. Though there are some tough enemies which you dont have to kill but u will feel great after defeating them.Again the battlesystem is quite goood. You should speed it up in the menu though then u wont have to wait ages for each character to have a go. Magic isnt used by junctioning special materia to your character like in FF7. Here u have to collect the spells. U can either draw them from enemies or refine them (quickest way is refining them). U will have access to the open world pretty fast and can go exploring. Story takes place in pretty calm and colourful world. You can use magic for the battles and have the possibilty to summon Monsters to help you out. You are a soldier of SeeD a special force who fights against witches. Yeah... witches... but luckily not the medieval witches :D They r just mean rly mean women with exceptional power who always want more... (sounds familiar?). Main focus, next to saving the world, is the rather complicated relation between the main character and one of his clients. Yes! This is an epic lovestory :DThe characters can be annyoing from time to time but after long speeches u will be rewarded with awesome cutscenes :D All in all I enjoyed playing the game after 15 years and it is the second best RPG Squaresoft (Square Enix) has developed :D

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												This is the ultimate love/hate game for me. I'll begin with the negatives. The junction system can be a chore to set up since you have to draw magic from enemies and casting it by the amount you have drawn instead of having the traditional MP (mana) system.  The story is pretty shallow and some characters just seem unnecessary. The soundtrack is pretty hit or miss. Lastly, the game can be pretty easily beaten by spamming Aura+GF combos from a certain point onward.Now with the good. Despite the rather shallow story, Squall and Rinoa's character development is pretty neat to watch unfold. Once your junctions are set up, the battle system can be pretty fun at times. There's plenty of fun sidequests and of course, there's the well known card game: Triple Triad. The game does have a certain charm to it and big part of it are the cohesive and well-timed cutscenes. The cutscenes were ahead of their time when this game was released and graphically still hold up very well. The final boss fight also rivals that of Kefka (FFVI) and Sephiroth (FFVII) in terms of epicness and challenge.To keep it short, this game is worth playing as long as you can accept it being very different from the traditional Final Fantasy game. Don't try to play through it as if you're playing VII or IX. Learn the junction system and use it properly. I've seen so many others try to play the game and end up not enjoying it because they didn't ever learn the junction system and played by just pressing 'Attack.' It's not worth getting if you're looking for a story that'll keep you wanting more. IV, VI, VII, IX, and X will provide much better stories than this installment. If you can accept its flaws, it can prove to be a good game with a certain whimsical charm to it and will provide you with plenty hours of playtime.

content:
Posted: April 2
												Nice story and character moments, and the visuals hold up surprisingly well. Aside from modding potential, this release has 2 specific advantages to simply emulating the original, getting in on PSN, etc.1) Hi-speed mode. This is like unlocking the FPS limit on an emulator, but the music doesn't get warped. Since you will spend a lot of time either in the field or an unskippable cutscene, this could save you multiple hours in a single playthrough. Also, during certain timed segments the timer will not be sped up - this is kinda cheating, but arguably justified since you're dealing with some annoyingly long battle animations. I think you can use this hotkey (F1), avoid the rest (F2-F5, which are unquestionably cheating) and still feel like you are playing legitimately.2) Magic Booster. This is a built-in hack that gives you 100 copies of every spell in your inventory, for each character. But it does not give you spells you don't have. This is definitely cheating, but if you've played the game before, you might see this cheat as acceptable compared to max Gil/damage/etc... you can easily farm 100 copies of most spells, but it is very time-consuming.That said, this game has some design issues regardless of what platform you're on. The Junction system is kinda broken, and the game ends up becoming very easy once you've obtained enough spells (which takes time and/or effort, but not skill). For me, one particular character could completely demolish every boss with little to no strategy involved. It's not awful, but it's not great either, which is why I think stuff like the magic booster isn't a big deal. Overall, this is one you'll enjoy for the story over the gameplay.

Yes I reccomend this game to Anyone that lieks the Final Fantasy Series, The Originals that is. This game is turn based, and it comes in the format of somewhat of a romantic novel between a Soldier and a Faction Leader. I Highly reccomend that You take your time reading and please for your own sake DO NOT RUSH, you will miss out on a breath taking story and its world; And i do mean this DO NOT RUSH. This is my favorite Final Fantasy in the series, and yes i played 9, 10 , and reasonably 7 [i will get back to it]. Anyway here it goes:The Graphics.. don't give a damn about it, this isnt a remake is re-release of the game. Still love the original one on PS1The Audio: It was very interesting to hear the MIDI structure Nobuo Uematsu put together, I was able to tell how he approached the themes, and where he could have possibly had trouble playing. [ Check out EDEA's Theme i believe is called sucession of witches, or the sucessor. Also check out Balamb's theme you would hear a  dissonant sound from both themes. So from musician to musician it was very exiting to hear what the next track would sound like in MIDI :D. Though I like the MIDI version in its own way, the orchestrated versions of the OST is by far better, and i mean waaaaay better. The Gameplay: Turn based, OR NOT really. There is  ATB which is Active Time battle and you can basically bump this all the way up and it wont feel turn based. what this does is that it makes the battle waiting faster, and as you level up so do your sorroundings so it will be even faster! The magic in this game is not learned as an ability but drawn from Draw points and or monsters, and they do not take away any magic power, or MP, but they are stored in Quantities. To some this might be an abomination BUT to me this feels a bit interesting and maybe, challenging, because you will then learn not to waste magic, lets say you have for instance 10 curagas or 5 Meltdowns....ehheheh. you best use them wisely. I also love the Junction system because this gives the characters and the GFs more uniqueness, enough said. One con, and this is a big one for me, I DO NOT LIKE THE MAGIC BOOSTER, i think that takes away from the game, and also encourages people to cheat, which in my opinion  is a bad thing to do, because it takes away from the experience & who would want to cheat with such a good game? this turns off people. On a side note if they were to do more Final Fantasy remakes' they should add an option that Filters the graphics of these games, they arent demanding anyways, to give them different tones.. that would be very very very cool. I will highly reccomend this game , dont worry about what people say about this title, everyone has their own taste,10/10 - Personally.. Oh yeah & PLEASE IF YOU ARE A FF NEWBIEGO PLAY CLASICS LIKE THIS FIRST.

												Why I like Final Fantasy VIII more than most: (Warning contains major spoilers to the plot)1 - The music. Sure every Final Fantasy has a few good songs out of their soundtrack, but Final Fantasy VIII, almost every other song is excellent!2 - The Characters. Yes, sure most say that Final Fantasy VIII has the weakest character selection and is a cliche. And the student/teacher relation plot is overused. But it's not the relationship, it how you relate to them. Everyone can be like Squall; quiet, sticks to themselves, and puts themselves first. Say you don't have any of those qualities, I dare you! If Squall isn't you then you must be Zell (Jock) or Irvine (Playboy)?3 - The Secondary Plot Line. Sure, I'm not big on the whole war thing... But hear me out. It's not really about fighting the sorceress from the future who corrupted the sorceresses of the past and today. Well, it kinda is. But the back plot is: As much as Squall looks quite on the inside, he really want's acceptance. Most orphans are like that; stick to themselves because they don't want to get hurt again. 4 - The Story. Now I'm going to the primary plot line. Squall is a SeeD (a mercenary) who's sole job is to defeat the Sorceress Edea along with the other SeeD cadets to ultimately gain peace. Though the story to Final Fantasy VII was a bit better... But this is about VIII! But then... Squall finds out that Edea is/was the lady in charge in the orphanage (What a twist!) along with the other party members, they all were orphans together (except Rinoa) And now Squall want's the Sorceress to live. Fights her hoping for the best, then Rinoa gets possessed. Later in the game, he will forgo all he knew and lived by if Rinoa wasn't cured and become a Sorceress' Knight. That's what makes this story so compelling and an emotional journey. The emotion put in this game is stronger than VII.5 - The Side Quests. Triple Triad was the best side quest out of every Final Fantasy. Sure Final Fantasy IX had a card game... But there were no REAL rules or at least none that were explained in depth. In VII you could raise Chocobos which was fun to a point, but very repetitive! The card game in VIII if you got one of Quetzalcoatl's abilities you could mod the cards into items. That made getting a perfect 100% hard!6 - Sis, come back to me... I'm all alone (Ellone). She is the key to the whole game. She doesn't get much screen time. But is a very key character! She takes Squall and gang to 'The Dream World' where they see through Laguna, Kiros and Ward's eyes. To understand the sorceress and what went on before the war. But that wasn't really her motive. Her motive was to make Uncle Laguna stay with her. This is where Rinoa comes into play. Laguna was madly in-love with a singer at a bar named Julia. And Julia's song 'Eyes on Me' (voiced by Faye Wong. That song makes me want to cry...) was all about Laguna. But since Laguna kept getting called all over the world (since he was a soldier and all) she married another, General Caraway. Even though her last name is Heartilly (Presumed to be Julia's last name). So that would make Laguna a very key part in the story... Well he is! He put a stop to Sorceress Adel (Though... Adel looks like a man...). But I guess where I'm going with this point is: Knowing the past, is the key to the future. He then became the President of Esthar (who was the very enemy when he was a Galbadian Soldier). All in search of his little Elle. Ellone was searching for Laguna, whilst he did the same. Well, I can go on-and-on on how perfect Final Fantasy VIII is, but I won't. I'm probably boring you all to tears. Well I guess "It's like killing two pigs with one stone. I'm just so awesome... Genius, I tell you..." "Pigs? I think you mean birds." Well no... I was just trying to get a point across! Final Fantasy VIII is one of the most unappreciated Final Fantasies of all time!

												I think this game gets overshadowed by its predecessor. This game is inventive for the seventh sequel of any game. I may just have bad taste, but I'm impressed by this game.7/10 I think that for the price, it is worth experiencing the last in the trilogy of SquareEnix's best games.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Final Fantasy VIII, on steam, just as in 1999, fails considerably to equal its predecessor and yet still manages to be one of the best RPGs ever created. The graphics, in a different style, seem to have aged terribly on our HD monitors today. But this can take little away from the beautifully crafted world and pretty interesting (if rather unnecessarily confusing) storyline. Cards are still a blast to play and remain one of the best side-games to this day. Final Fantasy VIII is well worth another look on PC, although the mods are neither as plentiful nor as comprehensive as those for VII, this is perhaps also due to the fact that it was released much more recently. If you're looking solely for a nostalgia trip to 90s Final Fantasy, the 8th installment of the series is a very, very solid title, but I'd still always recommend its predecessor. 9/10.

												A classic to play again.  The graphics have been improved upon, I'd say more but for those of you who played this when it was brand new, I will save the description so that you can see for youself.  A personal favorite of mine of all of the final fantasy story lines.  Game play seems a little simplified from the original game play version in that commands for the gunblade as well as other small functions in the game and it is enough of an improvement that it makes the game much kinder to a first time final fantasy player.  Final Fantasy is hard to get wrong, especially the originals but if you're new to the final fantasy experience I would recommend getting into it with these older versions as learning how the game works in these versions is easier and allows you to learn quickly when moving on to the newer versions of the game (you dont feel as lost when you know what you're doing).  Final Fantasy VIII's story line is one of the more light hearted ones so if you're looking for one that is feel good, this is one of the few.  I would recommend this game to any one and especially to RPG fans out there.  If you have not played it yet you really are missing out.  The game is fun, chok full of 90's jokes/referances and of course as with all Final Fantasy games, look forward to the grind ;).

												Having played this game when it first came out, I decided to go for the nostalgia bomb and try it on computer. I must say the designers (or whoever prepared this version) did a really nice job making the controls computer-friendly. As for the game itself, I love it. It's a great addition to the Final Fantasy series and allows you to tailor your characters any way you want. None of them have a predisposition for a type of activity (black magic, white magic, thief), so it's up to you to decide which stats they gain. I'm also impressed how well the graphics have held up. I suppose the resurgance of 8-bit homage games have helped, but it's always easy to tell how the characters are feeling. To me, that's such a great part of this game.

												To preface, this is now the third time I have bought FF8.  I own a disc version for PSX, a digital classics for PS3, and now this for Steam.  This rerelease is basically a very very minimially touched up rerelease of the original PC version.  Graphically it's mildly better, the audio sounds mildly worse (although I believe there are mods to get the psx audio installed,) and they have added cheating to help deal with the magic grinding.To anyone who has not played an PSX generation Final Fantasy (7, 8, 9) they're all worth the time to play through and generally all have their own faults.  FF8 is generally very easy to beat, but does require substantial grinding, so the built in "Magic Boost" is a nice touch to make the game a bit less of a chore.  In general, if you like JRPGs, give this one a shot.  For all of its plot holes and grinding, it's a game that offers quite a few hours of play for not a whole lot of money.  For me, its a trip down memory lane, one of my favorite childhood video games, and a reminder of what an emo kid I was back in 1999.

												Look, this was my first and favorite Final Fantasy. I love everything about the core game, the fighting system, Junctioning, GFs, the story, the music, the characters, all outstanding. content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Final Fantasy VIII is a wonderful throwback to the multi-disk, open world RPG's of the Playstation Era. It has an interesting (albeit somewhat convoluted) story, multi-dimensional characters that have compelling motivations behind their actions, and a world full of incredible environments and enemies.No game is without fault. The experience system of the game is flawed in that it actually rewards the player for NOT leveling up, and the Draw system (which allows you to stockpile enemy magic for junctioning) can become tedious at times, but with the inclusion of the Magic Booster modification and playing enough Triple Triad (the trading-card minigame within the FF8 world) you can bypass the more tedious parts of the game. Final Fantasy VIII, like any other Final Fantasy game, has 100+ hours of playability, is chock full of quests and side missions that take you around the world, into outer space, and deep, deep into the dark ocean depths. For veteran players looking for a nice piece of nostalgia or players who want to experience a classic RPG, Final Fantasy VIII is certainly a good buy.

												For the Final Fantasy fan (especially the hardcore fans), I highly recommend buying this.  To everyone else, if you enjoy the old JRPG style gameplay, I, again, recommend this and even if you arnt a big fan of that style, the story alone is enjoyable.  While they have -not- upgraded the background, kept the original music files (yeah, it's a repeat of the FF7 release), nor adjusted the CG movies for widescreen, or done very little for resolution... the character models are MUCH better than the original blocky pixelated monstrousities of it's original release.  The big negatives for myself are the obvious music and horribly blocky background.  The positives are nostalgia and a great story with some fun old schoolish gameplay.  Hopefully the fans who enjoy making mods will make them (if they havnt already) to improve the negatives, should Square-Enix not do it.  Which they should.  Overall, worth it to fans of the series and to the old school RPG gameplay fans as well.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
PC Port ReviewThis is a re-release of the original PC port from 2000.GameplayIn terms of gameplay, original glitches and exploits are still here. The game itself however is not fully representative compared to it's PlayStation version, read below for more info.Controls- Xbox 360 controller is supported.- Cannot use dpad or triggers (bumpers work, but not triggers.) - Due to lack of triggers, clicking the thumbsticks is used to escape from battles.- Original game has rumble support, this does not.- Very playable, but does not perfectly emulate the PlayStation version.- Keyboard support only.- No mouse. - Not all keys are bindable.- Binding other keys like Enter, Tab, CTRL, Spacebar, etc. is possible but requires trial and error.- Playable to a certain extent.Controls note: In-game control prompts are also buggy with misplaced buttons or displaying the keys NONE if you manage to bind certain keys like tab, enter, shift, ctrl, spacebar, etc. This will lead to certain sequences like entering passwords for the train napping sequence being harder than usual and possibly lead to a game over screen.GraphicsPros:- Can be played in a higher res compared to PlayStation version.- Models do not look as jagged compared to PlayStation.- Character models are much more sharp in this version and look decent for a PlayStation title.- FMVs (while compressed) have aged pretty well.Cons:- Game battles are locked in at 16FPS, world map at 30FPS.- World map framerate is good, but looks HORRIBLE with blurry textures.- Pre-rendered backgrounds while upscaled are very pixelated.- Would recommend playing on a TV or a Window for those that do not like pixels.Graphics note: While the game has a "widescreen option" I would highly recommend playing the game in its original 4:3 aspect ratio with your regular screen resolution, playing this game in widescreen will only stretch the image and make it look worse. Edit: The world map looking horrible is due to a glitch that reduces the textures to it's lowest quality when bringing up the menu, going into a battle or a town fixes this. I have also noticed a major FPS drop when summoning the GF Eden and going up against the final boss. My PC itself meets the requirements and should not be an issue.SoundThis game DOES NOT have the original PlayStation soundtrack and uses the original PC Midi mix which does not compare to the original PlayStation soundtrack, would HIGHLY recommend using third party mods to fix this as it is very easy to find and implement. Some original sounds are changed or missing but not a major distraction.Would I recommend this?Yes but with CAUTION! Soon after downloading the game I had to:- Install third party mods to make it closer to the PlayStation version.- Rebind controls in notepad which took time due to using number codes for each key and actions not being labeled correctly.- The game also minimizes when first launching, very annoying when playing on TV with Big Picture mode.I am enjoying playing Final Fantasy VIII on PC, but first time setup is a pain and should not be necessary.Edit: also Triple Triad is a good game.

content:
Posted: April 2
												Nice story and character moments, and the visuals hold up surprisingly well. Aside from modding potential, this release has 2 specific advantages to simply emulating the original, getting in on PSN, etc.1) Hi-speed mode. This is like unlocking the FPS limit on an emulator, but the music doesn't get warped. Since you will spend a lot of time either in the field or an unskippable cutscene, this could save you multiple hours in a single playthrough. Also, during certain timed segments the timer will not be sped up - this is kinda cheating, but arguably justified since you're dealing with some annoyingly long battle animations. I think you can use this hotkey (F1), avoid the rest (F2-F5, which are unquestionably cheating) and still feel like you are playing legitimately.2) Magic Booster. This is a built-in hack that gives you 100 copies of every spell in your inventory, for each character. But it does not give you spells you don't have. This is definitely cheating, but if you've played the game before, you might see this cheat as acceptable compared to max Gil/damage/etc... you can easily farm 100 copies of most spells, but it is very time-consuming.That said, this game has some design issues regardless of what platform you're on. The Junction system is kinda broken, and the game ends up becoming very easy once you've obtained enough spells (which takes time and/or effort, but not skill). For me, one particular character could completely demolish every boss with little to no strategy involved. It's not awful, but it's not great either, which is why I think stuff like the magic booster isn't a big deal. Overall, this is one you'll enjoy for the story over the gameplay.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Final Fantasy VIII is one of my favorite entries in the series. And it holds up incredibly well for a game released in 1999. Visuals don't look that great on modern HD screens, but everything else is as good as it was in the original release.Characters are involving and exciting, and they all take part in a mature and complex storyline to stop a sorceress from the future from compressing time. But they are not base archetypes or generic "heroes" found in many games.The main protagonist is Squall Leonheart, a recently graduated member of SeeD, an elite mercenary force. He starts as an introverted, grumpy and cold teenager who pushes away those who would otherwise be considered his friends and doesn't seem to really care about anything or anyone else but himself. You'll probably hate his guts until halfway through the game when you find out why he is the way he is. Squall begins to change when he falls in love with Rinoa Heartilly, a cheerful member of a resistance group from Timber, and also Squall's employer on his first mission as a graduated SeeD. As you progress through the game, you see Squall rethink his choices in life and accept the support and friendship of his comrades which in turn makes him step up into his role as a leader - something he never asked for.You travel all around the world in your journey, and the locations you visit range from the the peaceful harbour city of Balamb to the busy capital of the Galbadian empire. You ride trains and drive a Garden, you take part in an elaborate assassination plot during a parade. Hell, you even go to space! Sadly you don't have access to a submarine this time around, but the Ragnarok makes up for it pretty well - it's probably the coolest airship of the series!Character customization is done through Junctions - you basically join a Guardian Force (summons in previous games) with one of your characters to have access to specific abilities and in-battle commands. Junctioning different GFs allow you to build your characters with the right skills to face each battle, and it becomes something crucial to master if you're gonna kill the Weapons.Wrapping it all up, these are the pros of this Steam re-release:- Lots of challenging achievements- Chocobo World minigame included!And the cons:- Lower quality music compared to the original PlayStation release- Bad controller support - buttons are displayed as B1-B12 and you can't map anything to D-Pad or triggers (X360 controller)
