content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Let me just get this out of the way, this game is fantastic. In fact I rate it higher than that other Final Fantasy that seems to get more attention. Maybe you agree with me or maybe you disagree but let me at least give you a couple of reasons that you shouldn't shy away from this gem. This game is unique and it is that same uniqueness that makes this game shine. Forget all the bad stuff people say about this game. Lets instead focus on the good that this game does.	Final Fantasy 8 did some wonderful things that no other FF title did. One of the most basic of JRPG principles, grinding battles. Well in short you don't need to really fight anything. I mean you can level up your charactors but there really isn't any real incentive to do it. For starters you are a student and you take a test early in the game. This test determines you pay or salary. Plus if you don't do so hot on the test you don't get a high salary. You can retake the test to do better and get paid more as well. So no need to really grind mobs for money as you get paid at regular intervals just like a job. I believe this is a plus as it allows for me to explore the world and without the need to stop and fight over and over. Also note, that bosses do not give out EXP at all. So theoretically, you could go thru the game at the starting level if you really wanted to.	So lets talk about the leveling system in the game, another plus to FF8's formula. The game uses a scaling system, which means the higher level you are the mobs scale to always give a challange of sorts. Which in every other game is a bad. I truely despise level scaling. It defeats the purpose of leveling to get stronger but this game bring a happy medium to play. FF8 intruduces the "Junction System". This entails a few things. One you "draw" magic from a couple of places. You can also "draw" from special points that refresh every so often to aquire more. You can "draw" from mobs as well. Now you can use these spells in battle which is fine, but let me say this game isn't really about magic as the other Final Fantasys. If there was a "grind" in the game its from drawing magic to aquire enough of it. So what is the point of magic if you don't really want to use them against mobs? Well as I was saying earlier, FF8 uses a "Junction System". This allows you to "Junction" magic to your main attributes. Your Hp, Mp, Att, etc. Doing this augments your abilites and makes you pretty damn strong. This is also how you overcome the level scaling to make your character stronger. You can level up but remember, mobs scale with you so this allows you to overcome this "handicap". If there is a "grind" in FF8, this is it. Which if you ask me, its far better "drawing" for magic than spending more time to grind for EXP for hours on end. I also told you that you could beat the game at the starting level. Which sounds bad but honestly beating the game at a lower level is way easier than a high level. Using the Final Battle as a reference, without spoiling, beating it at a low level was hard but certianly not difficult. But i will say beating it at max level was one of the most challenging battles I have ever done in a game before. It took me close to 2 hours to beat that battle. With the active battle and max level I was on the edge of my seat the whole time. Note that it took me many of times to even succeed in doing this. It was simply a rewarding feat to acomplish. I can also atest to this being the hardest boss I have fought from any of the other Final Fantasy titles.	Some tweaks have been done to the actual battle system. The main charactor uses a weapon called a gunblade. In battle you can attack like you normally would with no problems. But it has another feature that allows for it to do more damage. If you press a certain button at the precise time, you will pull the trigger and shoot as you attack. This effectively adds more damage to your normal attack. It uses a turn base battle system that is active, which means you have to think fast on your feet. No planning your attack like chess for the best move, you have to be quick and do something or just keep getting attacked over and over. Some might see that as a turn off which I can understand just be aware its there. Summons are back in this game as well. They will be mighty helpful. They also learn abilites as well. Most noteworthy is the "boost" ablity. This allows you to push a button repeatedly to amplifiy the damage done. Its a nice to be able to do that but after the bazillionth time it will get old. Still to this day I would have like to have a final ablitiy to just do max damage without that button mashing marathon. Also the animations for the summons are top notch for its time. Truely amazing but some are really long and overdone, would have been nice to be able to skip them. Annoying yes, dealbreaker no.	  	Probaly the most agreeable positive about FF8 is its included "card game". Triple Traid is its name and it is crazy fun that I am suprised was never given its own game. It sorta starts out slow but as you collect more cards you really start being sucked into it grasp. I personally have logged into FF8 just to play the card game and nothing else. So simple, but yet so much depth and strategy. Traveling to new areas brings about new rules to the game. Some of these rules are good and some downright brutal. Also there are "rare" cards to win from certain people. Some you might only have one chance to aquire so maybe using a guide isn't a bad idea in this area.	To talk about the story would ruin alot of it. I won't mention it but I'll hit on a few high points. I kinda throws you right into the middle of everything and you'll feel like you understand what's going on. Then you'll go from knowing what going on to not having the slighest clue. That formula happens multiple times in this game. But each time it happens the story gets deeper and more seems to be happening. It gets dangerously close to being to long. When I first played this on the Playstation 1, I was  wondering what was on disk 4 for the longest time. Even when I was at the end of disk 3 I felt like I had done so much I couldn't believe there was still a whole other disk to run though. Although in hindsight, disk 4 felt almost out of place and to this day I still believe it was only that way because the amount of data on a cd-rom wasn't enough to do it the way it should have been. I works but only like hitting a foul ball 1 foot away from being a home run. 	Other worthy mentions are the locations. The cities are big and give a feeling of being alive. The music sets a nice tone to the atmosphere. Still some of my favorite music in the series, not that any really stand out but they fit the games vibe. They are rendered backgrounds but still beautiful to look at. Throughout the world you can use roads to navigate around. You also gain access to cars to drive around the overworld. These greatly help speed up travel times. There are a few other ways of travel but I don't want to spoil any crazy details. Although I will say the "airship" in this game is the freaking best of all the FF games. 	What else is there in FF8? Quite a bit more if you ask me. For one it feels more like a world than past Final Fantasy titles. Or maybe I should say a little more grown up. This game as a whole seems more mature. But its overall experiance that makes it shine. The story goes up and down. There are high points and low points. But you are doing yourself a disservice if you pass on this up. Final Fantasy 8 knows its not like the rest of the series and its proud of that fact. If you give it a chance, you might be pleastantly surprised that you wished played it sooner.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Final Fantasy VIII is one of my favorite entries in the series. And it holds up incredibly well for a game released in 1999. Visuals don't look that great on modern HD screens, but everything else is as good as it was in the original release.Characters are involving and exciting, and they all take part in a mature and complex storyline to stop a sorceress from the future from compressing time. But they are not base archetypes or generic "heroes" found in many games.The main protagonist is Squall Leonheart, a recently graduated member of SeeD, an elite mercenary force. He starts as an introverted, grumpy and cold teenager who pushes away those who would otherwise be considered his friends and doesn't seem to really care about anything or anyone else but himself. You'll probably hate his guts until halfway through the game when you find out why he is the way he is. Squall begins to change when he falls in love with Rinoa Heartilly, a cheerful member of a resistance group from Timber, and also Squall's employer on his first mission as a graduated SeeD. As you progress through the game, you see Squall rethink his choices in life and accept the support and friendship of his comrades which in turn makes him step up into his role as a leader - something he never asked for.You travel all around the world in your journey, and the locations you visit range from the the peaceful harbour city of Balamb to the busy capital of the Galbadian empire. You ride trains and drive a Garden, you take part in an elaborate assassination plot during a parade. Hell, you even go to space! Sadly you don't have access to a submarine this time around, but the Ragnarok makes up for it pretty well - it's probably the coolest airship of the series!Character customization is done through Junctions - you basically join a Guardian Force (summons in previous games) with one of your characters to have access to specific abilities and in-battle commands. Junctioning different GFs allow you to build your characters with the right skills to face each battle, and it becomes something crucial to master if you're gonna kill the Weapons.Wrapping it all up, these are the pros of this Steam re-release:- Lots of challenging achievements- Chocobo World minigame included!And the cons:- Lower quality music compared to the original PlayStation release- Bad controller support - buttons are displayed as B1-B12 and you can't map anything to D-Pad or triggers (X360 controller)

												I always loved the way this game scaled to your level and rewarded you for understanding the draw and junction systems (you can truly be overpowered early on if you understand how to best use them) But beyond that I rather enjoyed the story itself and the way they framed more than one narrative via "dreams" through which the party experienced the history of other characters. I found the game enjoyable doing runs of both those styles. Also of all the "minigames" Final Fantasy has given us over the years, Triple Triad is still my favorite... I honestly would have payed the price of this game just to play Triple Triad on my PC. So all in all I would definitely recomend this game to fans of the series, and doubly so to those who might have been on the fence because of angry opinions they may have heard... try it, if nothing else you will enjoy the card game.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Fantastic game on par with Final Fantasy VII. The Final Fantasy series has been around since the dawn of the gamer age and many RPGs have been modeled after the success of this series. Final Fantasy VIII is no exception. It is to this day a masterpiece that  captures the imagination and brings one into an epic and unique universe.Pros: Great gameplay - The junction system allows for magic and summons to effect the stats your characters have depending on how strong and what type of magic is placed into which stat slot. There is an open world to explore, which can allow access to towns and secret locations. This feature was removed from Final Fantasy X onwards.Unique Story - When this game was on the Playstation 1 it was 4 discs long. The game starts off with a cut scene followed by putting you straight into the action where you must complete a trial to obtain your third (you gain the first 2 from the computer room) Guardian Force. The game does an excellent job at character development and allows you to literally read what the protagonist, Squall is thinking.Cons: Dated graphics: While its true this is an old game, the graphics are still respectable and wont burn your eye lids off looking at.No voice acting: You have to be ready to read a lot of text because theres no voice acting.Conclusion:Overall this game is a GEM and must have for anyone who enjoys Final Fantasy or classic RPG's.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												This game defined my childhood, it was also one of the only reasons i ever turned on my PS1. The soundtrack is probably the best of any game i've ever played, the gameplay was exactly what you'd expect of an FF game with a battle and junction system that is one of the best in the series but above all that the story is what makes this such a standout in the series, i haven't found many RPG's outside this era where i actually gave more than half a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the story or the plethora of poorly developed one dimensional characters that came with them. This version is kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ with the MIDI music. The DRM is not an issue as you just need register once for a SQE account and you can play offline, mod, cheat and generally do whatever you want afterwards. It also looks a hell of a lot better than the original PC (and PSX) release, the backgrounds obviously aren't improved but the character models, attack, GF and spell animations are all greatly improved by the increased resolution support.I played this when it was first relased on steam and at the time there weren't alot of mods available besides Roses&Wine which is a must for improving the audio but some of the mods that are available now make the game look a hell of a lot better and i'll definately be using them next time.

												This game is a classic from the Final Fantasy franchise. It doesn't always get the attention it should, while being overshadowed by the FF7 and FFX, and so on. However it is one of the vastest FF games of its generation. Being a PS1 game, on 2 discs, it had some of the best (and sometimes laggy) cut scene vids, and it has enough side missions to keep you busy for many days on end. To have it on PC in a version that will hopefully not have the old bugs, and so far (in my early stages of playing the game) has the same great game play as the original release.I would fully recommend this game to anyone that enjoys RPGs, and especially to those old FF fans. And if you have steered away from this game because of the lack of public attention, I encourage you to check it out! It’s a classic.

												Great classic with a decent port for PC. Playing this on controller was fairly difficult though as all of the buttons are labeled as B1, B2, B3, etc. This is not my favorite Final Fantasy game, but it is still a great game worth playing if your a fan of the franchise. content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Amazing game, full of original ideas for its time, epic story line with loads of side quests and hidden bosses. Between the story, the beautiful graphics, music score, and the insanely enthralling card game mini-game, Final Fantasy VIII does the series proud. This is the RPG that proves if you got a great story and solid characters it can still be a damn good game despite some glaring flaws. This is the best and most memorable game i have ever played, and everybody who loves RPG games will without doubt love this game. First laid eyes on this game on my 11th birthday, my dad got me a ps1 and this game. Grew up playing it. This was the game that would spark my love of gaming and the rpg genre. You probably think that you can't trust my review since I'll be blinded by nostalgia but I played this game again recently and loved it. Played, loved and obssessed on it as a child. Played, loved and obssessed on it as a manchild.It has a good mix of humor and seriousness, the combat system works well. This game is LONG, taking over 50 hours just to get to the middle of the game, if you haven't played the game before. Must buy.

It's that epic of a game.

												The PC port of Final Fantasy VIII is rock solid. Though it's been weathered a bit by time, but almost eighteen years since it's release can more than forgive the fairly rough graphics which have been improved in the PC port. It may not seem like much, but for the sake of it I booted up my PS1 and did a side by side comparison, the port is polished. Nothing amazing, but enough to take the edge off. Otherwise though the art design of FF8 is still quite lovely and has that certain feel to it back when games had more of a showcase feel to them, showing off the developers ability to push the limits of the machines available. The battle system by todays standards feels slow and the draw system, depending on how you play the game, still leads to those rather odd ten minute battles when farming spells. Though the PC port, like some of the other Final Fantasy titles have had on PC are built in trainers for things like max magic, leveling and other options. Not my bag, but it seems to be for people who don't have an immense amount of time to put into gaming. But ifyou're familiar with the typical J-RPG game, this won't be anything new, if anything possibly nostalgic.Like other Final Fantasy games, there is plenty of late game secrets littered throughout, some of which are extremely difficult to accomplish and others can be missed entirely depending on some of the most inane decisions you would've made twenty hours beforehand. I suppose that is one of the charms of FF8, some of it's nuanced action and consequence bits. Nothing that effects story at all, but unique dialogue, ultimate items and challenges that would otherwise be hidden. I will note however (spoilers free) the end game area of FF8 is an absolute nightmare for the uninitiated. But I won't say much more about that.As for the junction system, the unique gimmick of FF8, allows you to equip guardian forces, AKA GF's or summons and "junction" different types of magic to your abilities to improve everything from health, attack, elemental attack/defence and status effects. I will note that this system can cause you to become vastly overpowered early on in the game, making much of the game something of a cake walk. I will note, all enemies in the game scale to your level. There's even an achievement to finish the game with one of the main characters as his starting level if you can believe that.And the story. It's confusing to say the least and ignores just about any and all ideas of how time travel and dimensions work and runs blissfully through a field spewing a story of love, rebellion, loyalty and an evil beings overly complicated plan to rule everything. I will note, most of the characters never feel fleshed out and come across as bland, serving only a few key plot purposes and become nothing more than an extra character who fits in because whomever wrote the story was struck in the head with an encyclopedia containing nothing but deus ex machinas. It's not a terrible story, but it's full of enough plot holes you may mistake it for moldy swiss cheese from a distance.All in all, Final Fantasy VIII is a fun game with a confusing story with a few memorable characters but plenty of memorable events. If you like a decent J/RPG you'll have fun with this classic, though it may take either numerous plays or the Final Fanasy Wiki to fully understand the rather odd story and plot. But as said, I'll bet you'll have some fun.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Final Fantasy VIII in my opinion is one of the most overlooked in the series. It had a intriguing story and cast of characters that was unlike others before it. It also has the distinction of having one of the most interesting and perhaps outlandish weapons ever created, the gunblade. Final Fantasy VIII on steam shows its age but the gameplay mechanics still remain compelling. As with other traditional FF games, the game features a turn based battle system. A few notable differences however is the junction and draw systems. By junctioning a GF (Guardian Force) You can summon a powerful entity like Ifrit, or Shiva or cast magic. The draw system allows you to 'draw' magic from enemies, etc. to store on a character. You play as Squall a cadet of the Balamb Garden military academy. During the course of the story you will meet a varied cast of characters as you experience the growing conflict between Balamb and Galbadia. The PC version of FFVIII is largely the same as the PS1 classic. However it does have a few little bells and whistles. FFVIII on Steam has some graphical updates which cleaned some things up. The downside is that the touchup makes some flaws more apparent. In the skyboxes, and the world map you can see noticeable seams or grid lines. Its not a game breaking issue but serves as a perfect example that making a older game look pretty is not as straightforward as one might think. If you haven't played this game or are looking to revisit it; the Steam version is a great way of doing just that.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												FFVIII was the first Final Fantasy game I ever played when it originally came out on the Playstation v1.  I loved the plot and the game as a whole.  The concept of SeeD (essentially mercenaries) and the Gardens (their Command Centers) was very interesting to me, as was their hidden/seemingly-lost origins.Gameplay/Combat: The world is fairly free-roaming and open, which is really nice and a particular favorite of mine. I loathe games where you can't have the freedom to move about as you wish.  This makes it very nice to grind and earn your money/EXP.I really liked the combat system being a sort of real-time and turn-based system. Random load/ready times to take action for each participant, but you can change attackers (as most RPG's allow) or do nothing while the enemy team still takes action. It's also interesting that you have to draw all potential magic from a source other than one's self - Either Monsters or Draw Points, making magic a fairly limited item since you can't be sure of what you get except in battle where you can seemingly just keep drawing it from enemies as long as you're willing to take damage to do so.Using magic to enhance the attributes they're assigned to is also a really interesting idea and can help make/break some combat situations.Individual limit breaks, or each character's special skill/ability, was almost completely useless to me, personally.  I got Squall's to work any time I wanted, but the rest were hit and miss, usually miss. Dunno if it was my timing or what.Interface/Graphics:The interface wasn't bad, but bland and static.  For the time the game came out, the graphics weren't horrible, but they weren't great, either, and could have been enhanced.  The budget just didn't seem to be there for it.  When I compare this to games that came out about the same time ("Legend of Legaia", "Star Ocean: The Second Story",) I'm disappointed, though Star Ocean was very similar.Plot:The protagonist of the story, Squall Lionheart, irked me as a character.  I didn't really like him.  He's a cynical, emo brat and we're given no indication as to why that is or his history at all.  He just assumes everyone looks at for themselves and is a non-responsive♥♥♥♥♥the majority of the time.  Music: Pretty good.  There's a fair amount of music and it's pretty nice most of the time and fits the situations.There is no voice acting at all and, other than one song, no voice work of any sort.Pretty good if you wanna go old school for a bit, but more for the RPG element than true enjoyment of the story.

You won't miss much, but the music makes a lot of difference.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Short version: 90%Final Fantasy VIII was the point where the series reached a whole new level, thanks to small changes like the focus on the romantic story elements and the more realistic character design. The Steam edition includes a few additional features over the old PC release, making it one of the best ports of the game so far, recommended for old fans or newcomers who would like to experience one of the gems of the golden age of Final Fantasy.Long version:Final Fantasy VIII was sort of a trailblazer when it came out. This was the first Final Fantasy game where we said goodbye to the traditional NES/SNES era cartoonish characters in favour of a more realistic design, and where the romance plot-- which is normally a secondary or tertiary storyline in similar games-- is promoted to be in the focus.This won’t turn FFVIII into a romance/dating game, far from it: your main task is still to save the world/universe from the ridiculous-haired main villain. To do so you’ll have to gather friends and allies, explore much of the planet, and of course slowly discover a rich backstory told in two separate timelines, which will eventually (with a little guess work) uncover one of the most confusing, yet best-written stories of the genre.Gameplay-wise FFVIII is a bit of an odd one out in the series with the large amount of gameplay changes it features. Although a lot could be said about these, the length of a Steam review simply cannot hold this much information, so let’s just say that some of them, like the expanded Limit Breaks, are favourably looked upon and work well; while others, like the junction system, were met with great opposition and never returned in later games. The Steam version can be considered a well enough port of the original PlayStation release, with a bunch of really nice technical features, including better display compatibility and more user-friendly controlling. Sadly, like the Steam version of Final Fantasy VII, it features a subpar version of the original PSX music tracks, the same ones that were used in the original PC version.Overall, the Steam Edition is Final Fantasy VIII may not be the HD remake lot of people still want, but it is a good port of an excellent game, well worth of owning and playing, even if you have the original PSX disc somewhere.

Posted: December 6, 2013
												People who have been rating this down because of the music don't care about the game. As a matter of fact, if they're letting some sub-standard music get in the way of the game, they probably don't even like the game to begin with and should be disregarded entirely.First of all: the music isn't that bad. It's not bad at all, in fact, and certainly not enough to make people NOT reccomend the game. It has a retro feel to it, which, for any other game, people would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ing over because #RETROISAWESOMELOL.Second of all: yes, there is a second layer of DRM. Squeenix's login thing. I haven't had issues with my internet in long enough to accurately remember whether or not you actually NEED a constant stable connection, but I seem to recall that with FF7, you could play offline just fine as long as you had an account, which isn't difficult to create (and fake, if you so desire).The game itself remains one of Final Fantasy's most underrated titles. People ♥♥♥♥♥ed about the need to "grind" magic for the "unintuitive" junction system, but how is it any worse than grinding hundreds of millions of XP in any other title? I find the Junction system is laid out very simply and is easy-to-use. But then, I have at least two functioning brain cells to fire neural impulses between, so it wouldn't have taken me much effort to figure out even if I didn't understand it at first.The characters are deep and relatable, to an extent (I mean, how well can you actually relate to a bunch of teenagers who were riased to be elite mercenaries during their childhood). The story is engaging, if somewhat generic, but they genuinely tried to mix it up. The love interest plot developes naturally, though it gets somewhat rushed at one point late in the game when Female Love Interest (tm) goes into a coma and Male Love Interest (tm) who had previously been pushing her away constantly suddenly and abruptly realizes how much he needs her. Overall, it's a very good game. I look forward to when Squeenix releases FF9 for the PC *coughcough*hinthint*cough*getonityoulosers*cough*.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												My personal favorite of all  Final Fantasy  franchises. Played this in 1999 with my brother when I was around 7! If you never played this game, you wouldn't believe how rich the story was, and how wide the range of the conflicts really are. Game is set in the future, but somehow post-apocalyptic after what happened in Centra around 4000 years ago, a Lunar Cry, where in current time people rebuild Centra into what is called a Garden. Relationships in this game are two of the most contributing factors, while others include politics, war, sorcery, and just massive destructions.The game's background arts look ethereally.. poetic. It is just simply stunning. They're all 3D environment, just rendered into 2D and made it into a background where the 3D low-poly (characters) move accross the 3D space that have been motion-tracked to the background. The designs are mostly steampunk (architectural elements of Greek and French) combined with futuristic elements (try to observe the 3D models, colors, sounds, and advanced technology in the game).  Best battle system of all time. Indescribably cool. Junctioning GFs and Magic, draw, limit breaks, elements, statuses, real-time turnbased, weapon forging, student exams, and tons of other stuff. Just get the game and play it. And play its card-game, it's fun as hell.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I played this game on the Playstation back when it came out and decided to buy the Steam version for old times' sake. Sorry to say that the PC port of this game is absolutely horrendous. It's not worth the purchase even on a deep discount.The foremost problem is the controls: the button/key labels in-game are indicated using B1, B2, ... B10. Sure, you get shown the button meanings when the game boots, but it's not very useful when you can't remember the key combination for 'escape from battle' (required for the plot in the first game mission) and the in-game comments are useless. Also, don't bother with the controller support for this game. I attempted to use my wired 360 controller and found that the left and right triggers and the directional pad aren't detected -- you can't specify them in the custom configuration screen. (Also, there goes Zell's limit break.) On an aesthetic note, you should probably just mute the game instead of trying to tolerate the lo-fi, MIDI quality music. It's a shame, because the Dollet music mission is one of my favorites. Also, 'Magic Boost'? Seriously? Drawing magic was a HORRENDOUS idea to begin with, but Magic Boost is pretty much game breaking if you use it early on (it gives you 100 of the fire/thunder/blizzard, fira/blizzara/thundara, firaga/blizzaga/thundaga, all the status effect spells, and a few others... but fortunately it doesn't give you 100 of the top-tier spells like ultima, aura, etc) The game wasn't hard, there's no need for this kind of cheat.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Final Fantasy VIII is a somewhat controversal entry in the Final Fantasy series. It is also my introduction to the franchise and the first Final Fantasy game I ever played.And to be honest, it's easily one of my favorite FF games.FFVIII was the first game in the series to mix reality and fantasy as well as science fiction elements. It featured a new (somewhat confusing) junctioning system, Guardian force summoning, and a new cast of human characters. For all extents and purposes, it is a divisive title in the FF franchise. Yet it was the game that introduced me to what would become my favorite gaming franchise of all time.Personally, I found the story to be a little weaker then some entries in the series. But it has a human element that was lacking in many of the previous games in the series. Based on the theme of love, FFVIII has a very human cast of characters and I found each one of them quite likeable in some regard. Main protagainst Squall is often portrayed as cold and shallow, but learns trust and respect throughout the course of the game. The supporting characters are all interesting in their own right. You will learn to care about them and relate to them over the course of the game as you help them in their struggles to defeat the Galbadian army and the Sorceress Edea. This PC remaster includes the full game “Chocobo World” featured in the original PC port. It also includes 45 unlockable achievements and a magic booster feature.Final Fantasy VIII has it's critics, but it is a welcome entry into the FF franchise. Featuring a beautiful and moving story, a cast of uniqe and human characters, and a exciting battle system. It is easily among my favorite Final Fantasy games.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

content:
Posted: March 31
												Final Fantasy 8 is one of the first games that I remember playing, and I got hooked and it currently sits as my second favorite game I've ever played (behind Baldur's Gate 2). I've played it many times, read all of the criticism, and just recently completed all of the quests, so I'll attempt to address the main points on every side, bad stuff first. Overall, TL;DR What this leaves us with is a fantastic junction system that is built on the power and versatility of GFs, but is crippled by the forced grinding that is inherent in the broken Magic stock system. A small handful of characters shine, while the side characters prop them up and then fall to the wayside.Final Fantasy is a deeply flawed game, and is not very forgiving to newcomers, but has some deep complexity with several rewarding points, both in combat and side quests. Negatives  Progression System The biggest complaint I've seen for FF8 is how your power level progresses, specifically the Draw + Junction systems as well as level scaling. The Draw system is the magic system in the game; each character has 32 total slots for magic and can "draw" magic from enemies or draw points, or have magic refined through a variety of abilities, with a maximum cap of 100 total stock of each spell. The Junction system works in conjunction with GFs (Guardian Forces, equipable summons that give you a bunch of skills and such) and is reliant on the Draw system in that you junction magic to your stats (HP, strength, magic, vitality, spirit for health, physical attack power, magical attack power, physical defense, magic defense), as well as more rare junctions like hit %, speed (how quick your turn comes up), evasion, status and elemental attack and defense junctions. Sounds all great and dandy with tons of customization right? And it is!  The problem  is that the effect of junctioned magic is directly related to how much of said magic you have stocked. 100 fires will give a lot more health than 10 fires, and the system very much encourages sitting in a super boring battle for 10 minutes to fully stock up on magic.  Even worse  is that using magic will deplete your stock, therefore reducing their effectiveness as junctions, and thus meaning that there is never a good reason to use good spells, which is sad considering all of the crazy interesting spells, from Maelstrom (reduces physical defense to 0), to Double or Triple (allows you to cast 2 or 3 spells in a turn, respectively) to more traditional stuff like haste, regen, meteor, etc etc.The other problem that arises where power levels are concerned is level scaling. Every enemy in the game (with a handful of exceptions) has a scaling set of stats, skills, and draws that corresponds to what level your characters are, and they scale much faster than your characters do respective to their levels. That's right, you're better off never leveling up anybody, as using the roundabout ways to acquire junctioning magic will make you much stronger relatively speaking than gaining EXP. Story Character Progression As far as the story goes, the problem here is that the side characters have little to no character progression. Outside of the main ~3 characters in the story, the side characters just don't have much going story wise to flesh out their personalities, introduce conflict, or provide any meaningful way for them to grow as characters. Personally, I like Squall (the main character), but the fact that there are so few developed characters means that 1) seemingly interesting characters are mostly wasted and 2) there is less of a chance for the player to bond with any of the characters (see: FF9 with its varied cast of characters), so unless you like Squall, Rinoa, or Laguna you probably won’t like the game from a story perspective.*Note* I’m not touching the plot, as I feel like it is good not great, with several somewhat questionable choices throughout, but it neither makes nor breaks the game in and of itself. Positives Woohoo, stuff that makes the game worth playing! First up, Guardian Forces! Guardian Forces (or GFs) are summons that give you command abilities, let you junction magic, and refine stuff from stuff to give you more stuff! And you can summon them in battles to fight if you want, but that’s far from their most useful function (with the possible exception of the coolest of them all, Doomtrain). Why are GFs so cool? Because they tie everything together! They can help you in battle in a pinch, can be mixed and matched to get the right junctions, command skills, and support buffs you need, and can learn refining skills that will turn the useless junk you find into stupidly awesome magic and weapons! On top of that, many of them are new. Quezacotl takes Ramuh’s place as the lightning summon, while mainstays Shiva, Leviathan, Ifrit, Carbuncle, and Bahamut, in his best form of the entire series, all make appearances. New characters like Diablos, Pandemona, and Eden, and recurring characters that get their first appearance as summons in Cactuar, Tonberry, and Gilgamesh, all provide unique skill sets, as well as interesting ways to hunt them down (good luck with Ultima Weapon, Bahamut, Eden, and Tonberry without guides).Next up, Triple Triad! Yes, it’s a mini game. Yes, it’s the easiest (and frankly, only realistic) way to become a God, but it’s much more than that. It’s a simple game with a 3x3 grid where each player has 5 cards with 4 numbers on them, one for each cardinal direction, and you flip cards but having a higher number than the one you place a card next to. Simple, right? But that doesn’t include a rule like Plus, where you have to calculate what they can do with their cards so you don’t get your super cards flipped. But then there’s the Elemental rule which turns your only safe play into a losing play. Triple Triad is fantastic fun, working on the winning formula of easy to learn, hard to master (until you hit the Queen of Cards quest or random rule, screw that garbage).

												The Port: The Steam port is a mixed bag. It has some pretty glaring flaws. First of all, you can't change the controls in-game (only in the pre-game menu). Secondly, the pre-game menu has a very big CHEAT HERE!!!! sign that allows you to bypass all kinds of things you'd normally have to earn yourself (money, spell inventory, etc.). Thirdly, the music they included are the awful MIDI files that are terribly low quality. You can fix this (one of the top-rated posts includes the link), but it's a needless hassle. On the plus side, the graphics look pretty good and the game includes ChocoWorld, which we PSX users never got. So like I said, it's a mixed bag. If you still have this on the PC with ChocoWorld, there's absolutely no reason to get the Steam release. If, however, you had it on PSX and would like to play ChocoWorld and use the items/characters from that side game in the main game, you might be interested in picking this up when it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												I am basing this review on both port & game quality.First, the port is very poorly made, there is no real attention to detail. Some examples include:* The game minimizes itself when it starts and you have to re-focus the window.* The game blocks you from using a gamepad right away and requires you to press a key in the beginning to proceed, bad UX.* The battle transitions look terrible compared to the PS1 version.* The game uses midi files for music when it is easily modded to play high quality OGG music. They were just lazy with this and it really takes a toll on the game's atmosphere if you don't use a mod for it.* There is a constant distracting message "achievements synchronized with server" every time you draw magic from enemies, just because there's an achievement for it, but you can't turn this message off.* When you have to do button prompts (there's a few quicktime events), the gamepad buttons appear as B1/B2/B3/B4 rather than icons, which can get confusing visually, if the event requires swift response. * After you finish the game, you get a black screen, the devs made no effort to reset the game data and return you back to title screen, you have to manually exit the game via Alt+F4. It shows that they were not willing to do changes for better UX on the target platform.Now for the game itself,The environments look great for its time, but the game suffers from a "short area" syndrome. There are many times that you'll enter a specific area that an interesting background/area caters only for plot and gives you no chance to explore. It is first apparent when you enter shops, you are greeted with the shop menu rather than an extra screen, so you can admire the aesthetics, which older games did, and this seems rather lazy.There's also the opposite happening sometimes, like with the few sidequests, the game will start describing the area/scene with plain text instead of providing some more interesting visuals.The dungeons are very few, with very little screens in them, often repeated and the game justifies it that it's a "maze" (Tomb of the Unknown King / Sewers) but feel rather linear. In one of them, you battle enemies every single step you make, and the dungeon screens repeat, making it extremely tedious & feeling like padding. There's no real sense of progress or reward. The World Map looks interesting at first glance, but you'd have explored the 1st half by Disc 1, on Disc 2 you'd be running around past locations and a few new small ones. And by Disc 3 you'd finally reach the other Continent only to be disappointed that the place is nothing but a seemingly huge city with nothing interesting to do in it, and a few tiny dungeons that serve just for plot and an item.One huge downside is that once you enter Disc 4, the game blocks you from going back to any city. It tries to justify it with plot (and probably PS1 CD limitations back in the day to fit those large cutscenes), but that really takes out of the close-endgame aspect. In previous Final Fantasy titles, you are free to revisit past locations, find new secrets in them, do sidequests and other interesting things (battle challenges, play minigames, chocobo breeding etc.).As such, there is not much exploration to be done. Forget field treasure chests with valuable items like in the previous games. There is only around 5-6 Items to be found, instead there are some Draw Points here and there that you can mine magic in set intervals, but nothing that feels truly rewarding.Side quests are very few, you have your extra GF sidequest, a treasure hunt, a "find the UFO" quest, and a cute but tedious tamagochi-like Chocobo minigame. Most of them are really not interesting and feel forced so that "the game could have sidequests".The game has gameplay pacing issues. Enemies now level up along with you which is an interesting concept, but not executed very well and often nullifies any grinding done to improve your characters' stats as the enemy level will always stay higher. On the flip side it is very easy to break the game by stocking up magic and junctioning them to your characters for big stat boosts.Another issue is that the game does not guide you well through gameplay, a hint of this is that the very first shops in the game already offer you items that you won't need for a good while, like the item "Soft" that cures petrification status, which doesn't happen until much later in the game. A worse, more apparent problem is that the game relies on lengthy tutorials to try and explain its mechanics rather than putting the player under tests.A major battle system change, which I am personally not a big fan of, was that now Magic are expendable and act like one-use Items (they do not require MP to use). As such, there is a lot of grinding to steal Magic from enemies that you end up junctioning to your characters and don't really want to expend. However it is now entirely possible to just spam GF (The game's Summons) and win every battle as there's no need for MP for them either. This change was unnecessary and breaks the balance/strategy with resource (MP/Item Stock) management as the player feels like he has infinite amount of resources for a battle, as long as they just grind for Magic.Money is not earned through battles. You can sell item drops/steals from monsters, but they don't sell for much til you reach Disc 3 portion of the game. The game relies on a Salary system which is based on your party's rank (how many battles you do, story choices, written tests), which leads the player not caring about buying any items from shops much having to wait all this time to get paid.There is also a nice distraction minigame in the form of a Card game, named Triple Triad, which I have nothing bad to say about the game itself, but it is very easy to accidentally spread the "Random" rule around regions, which makes your cards in your hand random & kinda omits the fun factor, making the minigame frustrating.As for the story, it's a pretty basic one, even for Final Fantasy standards it appears to look rather bland, and really a shame as the previous 2 titles had rather complex & interesting ones.The game's story starts off really slow, then picks up a little, then by Disc 2, it nosedives into boredom. Then it tries to do a twist which is really predictable and doesn't really do much to keep your interest. The villain's motive for being evil is also generic and without real purpose/context other than "I am evil by nature, so I must kill you all". By Disc 4, the game stops trying and it is just "lets just kill the bad guy and go home". The protagonist is totally non-relatable and one-dimensional. The romance, which the main story revolves around, between him and his interest also seems rather forced at times. The other characters often do some dumb stuff/decisions throughout the story, which you wish the game gave you the option of choice being an RPG and all.The protagonist's adversary also has no real-or-just closure, which seems lazy and all that time in the beginning spent to establish his character feels like a total waste of time.When the game first came out, it was hailed as an eyecandy & tech miracle. And for its time, it was. Great detailed graphics, great soundtrack. But the game really suffers from too much experimentation. There were some gameplay/storytelling formulas the previous game, FFVII, established that should not have been changed.Fortunately, the next iteration of the Final Fantasy series, FFIX, reverted all these poor design choices for the better.I sadly, cannot recommend this port to anyone looking to either start with Final Fantasy or looking to play the next classic Final Fantasy.Get this game only if you want it on your collection or for nostalgia reasons, otherwise there are much better JRPGs/FFs on Steam.

content:

												Quite possibly one of the greatest stories of all time. The artwork and CGI of the Final Fantasy games during the late 90's was some of the best displayed in a video game during that time. This game was confusing, surprising, and captivating from beginning to end. There are secrets around every corner, not quite as much as Final Fantasy VII, but even more so when you consider the content provided with the card system and spell system. Some complain that the spell system is confusing, but a simple google search for a guide or video explination will solve confusion issues these days. The graphics upgrade provided with the PC version is really only an upgrade of the 3d modeling in the game. Fight scenes look a bit cleaner but it is clearly apparent that no improvement was made in regards to textures or higher texture sampling for the higher resolution options. This actually creates a very ugly full screen appearance when traveling through areas in towns. I am completely confused at Japan's approach to PC remakes of their console games. The lack of video options and the requirement for a launcher brings me back to 1998 when I was playing 'Redneck Rampage' on my Pentium III. If you really MUST have this game for PC like me, or if you insist on experiencing this game for the story, get it. Otherwise skip it.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Warning: Review is not proofread, as I am a lazy human being. Final Fantasy VIII is a somewhat underdog classic in the Final Fantasy franchise. It was controversial in it's release for being vastly different then any Final Fantasy, or for that matter, RPG on the Playstation platform. Though critically acclaimed, alot of fans felt that the game derived too far from it's traditional JRPG roots. This is somewhat of a comical criticism in comparision to modern Final Fantasys, but at the time, the game had a shocking effect primarily for it's less cartoonish appearance, it's different take on equipment and item systems, and of course, who can forget the controversial junction system. The story as well, recieved much criticism for being overly melodramatic and at times feeling complete. The characters can come across as quite hokey at times as well. All this to say, that this is probably my favorite Final Fantasy game. I played it shortly after finishing FFVII, and while I do echo the esteem afforded to FFVII, FFVIII reached me in a way that game failed to. I found at the time, I could relate very much to the game's main protagonist Squall and his journey to venture outside of himself and into this bigger world of responsiblity. In a sense, it was a story for me as an adolescent, trying to make sense of love and the world. Sure, it does have a bit of a hokey love story element, but the thing that gripped me the most about this game was Squall's inner mental dialogue, and of course the unforgettable world in which the game takes place. I have to say it, I love the world of FF8. It is very much less steampunk and more sci fi, but its full of beautiful villages and vistas, and the people who inhabit this world are interesting. The story may feel uneven, but there was definite intention here to bring a lively world that spoke more then what the actual plot could, and I love the plot. The music is written by FF veteren Nobuo Uematsu, and it is as expectedly incredible. Every song fits so well with the environment; Nobuo has a rare talent of telling a story within a story. More could be said about Nubuo, and much has, but for the sake of room and time, just take my word for it. Concerning this version: this version of FF8 is wihin the same sort of rerelease as the FFVII rerelease. Keyword here is rerelease, NOT REMAKE. I can't emphasize that well enough. This is a RERELEASE. If you buy this game expecting a fully fledge HD remake, you will be disappointed, and you should be, because this is what SQUARE has made clear since the beginning. That said, for a rerelease this ain't bad considering that unlike FF7, the PC version of FF8 was considered somewhat inferior to the PS port. This was because at the time, the release was buggy and there were certain elements that made the game feel more like a port and less like a pc game. Much of that is retained in this version, but now we have the added benefit of actually being able to customize the game's graphics to your native resolution without the burden of modding. That is essentially what you are paying for here. The cinematics are fine, and cleaned up. The actual ing game graphics look nice, and you can see now clearly just how smooth this game was designed to run. The animations are much smoother this time around. Because of the clearer graphics however, you will notice some inconsistent fragments (pixelated people and backgrounds) that were not intended to be seen with a modern screen resolution. But I find this to be not a deal breaker. Also the music is sadly, the original chopped up midi from the pc release. Hopefully Square will patch in the glorious PS original score at some point. So in summary, FF8 is a flawed but still great game and one of my personal favorites. If you are expecting something more then a release of a game that is more then 10 years old, you will be disappointed. If you are like me though, and have fond memories of the game from your childhood, then you may find yourself surprised just how well things translate.

												Outside of your scope of the Final Fantasy series as a whole, this game is awesome. People constantly complain about the music and.. It could be better. It is the original music, but it gets the job done all the same. Most games i play, i tend to try not to take a guide to play it with me.. This game and FF7 are the exceptions. The game itself is huge and fun to play, although it does get repetitive after some time. There are secrets in the game which you cannot find until the very end of it, so its important to know where those are and how to access them, although they are not needed.The leveling system in this game is unique. The creatures level with you. You can get to level 100, like the traditional Final Fantasy games allow, however you could also defeat the end boss @ level 20. It's like that. There is no need for grinding and will allow you to experience the story without need for the grind. The story is great. Many say it doesn't make much sense, but thats because there are elements of it that you need to explore for yourself. Those elements will not reveal themselves to you, you need to search for them! Or use your guide.Overall, i would recommend this game, if for nothing else, the nostalgia value it brings. Great game.

												Final Fantasy VIII is my favourite game not only in its own series, but jRPGs as a whole. The characters, more modern/realistic tone, romance centric plot, Nobuo Uematsu's music (man with the machine gun? force your way? the extreme?) and a heavy dose of nostalgia earn it that. So you would think I was excited when I heard that it was coming to Steam - and I was - until I heard it was just a port of the original PC release. I don't mean to be that person, but the graphics aren't doing so well either. Gamepad support isn't all there. You need a Square Enix account to play the game. And before I find something else to complain about, if you have a similar experience as me, you might have incompatibility issues with more recent Windows releases, or the Steam overlay/achievements.But hey, it has Chocobo World. That's nifty. Just buy the original game, whether that's on the PS1, PS3, or PSP. If you absolutely have to have it on PC, look into mods to fix the music and menus, at the very least.

My nostalgia goggles are massive for this game:So PLEASE take my word for it when I say this is the worst game in the series and 100% skippable. The music is great, some of the aesthetics are interesting, and the junctioning system is neat to play with. That's as far as it goes. It has the most contrived and incoherent story of the whole series. It has the least memorable characters by far. Squalls favorite line is "What ever..."A big part of any Final Fantasy game is the story, and Final Fantasy 8's story is pretty atrocious. If I had to give a score I'd honstly give the game a 5/10. It has good enough gameplay, but when it comes to long turn based RPGs, the story is too important to not consider when reviewing the game. The story alone takes the 8/10 gameplay down to a 5/10 over all game.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												You probably heard about this game before, so I'll go into the details about this version first.This is basically the PC port from 1999. That means it has poor quality midi music. I recommend installing the playstation music pack, which is provided in the guide section. You can turn on graphical enhancements, which I find awful. They mess up the textures so you see the geometry clipping or floating, which are seamless in the original version. You'll have achievements, too. They are a little uninspired and seem just mandatory for the most part.You can't just start the game and lay back on your couch with your gamepad - like with big picture. You absolutly need to put in some keyboard commands first. I find this annoying at the beginning of every session. Also, the in-game button prompts don't use the Xbox (or psx) names and that's confusing. If you're told to quickly press the B3 button, you'll know why.You have theoretically unlimited save files, which is nice. And you can play the built-in pocketstation game Chocobo World. That feature was useless in Europe back in the day, because the pocketstation was only released in Japan. But that minigame is not that good. For the most part it plays itself and you just have to hit enter every couple of minutes, so it continues. Now think about how long it takes to reach LV 99 there. That's just preposterous.The game itself is highly unconventional, which can be curse or blessing. You can't deny it has top-notch production value and incredible presentation, thanks to the pre-rendered backgrounds. That's always Squeenix' strong point. The thing with "changing the formular" is, that it feels like done for its own sake. Elements of typical jrpgs like character levels, money, magic, equipment and so forth don't have that much of a pay-off as if they were changed just for the hell of it. It is extremly complex and begs you to first familiarize with it. There is a lot of depth to the micro-management but it is overwhelming for a beginner. Plus, the menu interface is unappealing to look at, though you spend a lot of time arranging your stuff. It is best you don't even start to wrap your head around the meaning of all of this or you'll go crazy how "gamey" and nonsensical the entire system is.One thing I can't just easily criticize is the music. I know tastes are different and you can't just call it good or bad. But from a quality point of view I think the music is a little uninspired and underwritten. I get the role of these jazzy tunes in this more realistic universe. The composition uses much more natural sounding instruments and percussion, but it sounds way more flat and shallow than other works of Uematsu.I don't mind the card game. Not at all. Sometimes it's unpredictable and frustrating and it takes long to complete but for the most part I find it intriguing. If you don't, ignore it. You can just transform the cards you get without playing into items and will be fine.Then there's the drawing. You can finish the game with no problems without ever drawing magic. But I agree that it's initially counter-intuitive. Here's why. When you are introduced to this feature, you have nothing stocked yet the urge to be as good as possible. You can already see the ceiling. The more you have, the better you are. The only thing standing in the way is your investment. You will have to have the dicipline to say "I may not be maxed out right now, but eventually I will be. Let's move on for now!" Don't let it bug you. The game is balanced well enough.You can be forgiving with the mechanics but I think we'll all agree that the story is the weakest part. It is just contrived and incoherent and it doesn't know where it's going with all its set pieces. Plus there are plot holes and deus ex machina which are a sign of poor and lazy writing. It is pretty cheesy and schmaltzy, too.Bottom line, this is a real Frankenstein's monster. It is impressive, elaborate and stuffy but still an abomination you're puzzled about it even lives. It has much love to give but will always be a manifestation of ambition gone wild.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												I wanna make one thing clear: I love Final Fantasy (and RPGs in general). I have played the heck out of FFs 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, and 14, and loved every one. I really, REALLY want to like 8. Square decided they wanted to do something different. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it came crashing down in this instance.Side note: Credit where it's due, this game has a great soundtrack. The boss theme and Man With the Machine Gun are just two tracks I enjoy having stuck in my head. Nobuo Uematsu has never disappointed.Anyway. Lets go down the list of reasons this game doesn't want me to like it.-The Draw system: Lets be fair; I was prepared to tolerate the draw system. Magic is a limited resource in all RPGs, and frankly, this seemed considerably less limiting. In itself, I don't mind the system of "draw magic, cast it later". It's everything attached to the system I don't like.-The leveling system: FF8 is the only FF game to implement enemies with levels themselves. Your characters can level up as you adventure -- that's just standard for an RPG -- but unique to FF8, the enemies you encounter have their levels set to roughly match yours. Long story short, this means that leveling up is actually detrimental, because the enemies level up too. Oblivion is another game that does this (and it's one of the few flaws with an otherwise dang-near-perfect game), which causes players to just never level up because doing so would be stupid. Leveling up is a key component of any FF game, but it's butchered in FF8.-The junction system: Good God, talk about complex character customization. I won't go into all the details, but this is one of the main reasons I just can't enjoy this game. You can boost a character's stats by "junctioning" magic to that stat. This boosts it by a value that's unique per spell, per stat, multiplied by the number of casts you have of that magic. You can stock up to 100 of each spell. Here's where my big problem comes in; you stock this magic up by "drawing" it from enemies. It's a combat action on its own that does nothing to the enemy, and gives you an average of 5.5 casts of the spell you drew. That means when you find a new spell to draw, you need to draw about 18 times to get a full stock of 100. PER CHARACTER. Of which there are six. I probably spent over an hour just drawing up a full stock of about six different spells for about four different characters. Just...no. That's just ridiculous. To the PC version's credit, it comes with a "magic booster" that lets you get a full stock of a whole bunch of spells for all characters any time you want, but that feels like cheating. It's giving you a bunch of spells much earlier than you could otherwise access them. I just can't feel right by cheating in such a way.There are several different ways they could have made this system suck less. Capping at 10 instead of 100, for example. That still doesn't change the fact that the junction system as a whole is easily the most convoluted RPG system that exists.-Lack of character identity: FF7 had this issue too; your characters' combat abilities are defined primarily by the way you've set up their junction system (or materia in 7). You can set up Squall as a bruiser and Rinoa as a mage, then swap their junction setups and have them both perform the other role just fine. This limits the personality that the characters show -- and the issue is only compounded by the immense amount of time you'll spend in combat just spamming draw. This sounds nitpicky, but other FFs reinforce their characters through their combat options. In FF6, Edgar felt like the machinist because he was the only one that could use an autocrossbow. Sabin felt like the brawler because he was the only one that could suplex a freaking train. Shadow felt like the ninja because he was the only one that could hurl a shuriken. All those varying combat options reinforced their character.-Renzokuken: My last little nitpick that makes the game an absolute joke. Squall's limit break lets him smack an enemy upwards of five times, each for standard attack damage, and the only requirement to use it is to be low on HP. Theoretically, you could make mincemeat out of the entire game just by keeping Squall's HP low and spamming his limit break on anything that moves. Honestly, Square, what was wrong with FF7's limit break system? That worked just fine, and would have easily suited Squall's insane limit break.So yeah. I really, really wanted to like this game. I gave it several chances. I just...can't. On the other hand, FF7 is available on Steam, go grab that! And/Or the remake coming soon!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												FF VIII is a title I missed out on as a kid, so I bought it now to finally experience this story.It will definitely offer much content for the player to go through. As with all FF titles there are plentyof mini-games and side-quests, which all grants valuable and powerful items, so there will be many hours invested in this game. One of the new elements, is that FF VIII do not follow the casual road of the series and is very different in some areas.There are no level system as we are used to, instead every character always need 1000 exp in order to level up, where in previous titles, the required exp would gradually increase per level. The level system in this title is used to determine which level the monsters are, and what SeeD missions you can undertake (one of the side-quests).Players will instead rely on a new system called Junctioning. A system where character equips and buffs themselves with magic, summons and moves.Magic is not learned, but 'Drawn' from monsters, which makes it possible to stock up on 100 Triple + 100 Curaga. Stocked magic is then used as usual, with the character using the chosen magic move.Summons plays a big role in this title and has it's own system, where you have to spam X to increase it's % damage output.Also there is only about 2-3 chests in the game...PROS:FF VIII offers almost infinite amount of gameplay. You will be busy getting the best gear, solve all mysteries while you adventure together with a friendly crew. The graphics are alright and I had no issues what so ever with how it looked. I liked it. Battles are always a challenge, unless you prepare yourself properly. So you will never get bored of killing bosses too fast. I ran into trouble with both Bahamut and Griever, even though I thought I was well equipped.You will experience a new, more modern take on the Knight & Sorcerer tale, which is interesting and kept me asking questions throughout the game. The characters had GREAT dialogue and the bonds that happens between them is a joy to watch and follow. I was really fond of Zell and Selphie, who is two great characters that really adds to the game.You of course not be cheated of the chance to capture a chocobo, which has is its own little (big) mini-game. Get busy and train that chocobo, so you can get some delicious items. I really enjoyed the chocobo part, even though it got tedious sometimes, but I can't have a game with no chocobo training.At a point, when you have more time and the tools to explore, you will have a lot of things to do and stuff to get.Again endless amounts of things to keep you busy.This is purely my opinion and you should only read this when you have finished the game yourself. It is worthy buying, despite these cons.CONS:I personally did not find the cast of characters too interesting. They had great personalities and dialogue, so this is based purely on how they look. Boring. I hated Zell's stupid tattoo, but I really enjoyed his personality and he got to be one of my favourite characters. Yet when I play a FF title, I really look forward to their appearances. Sadly few characters stood out, and most had little fantasy elements and more a stale citizen look.I absolutely got to hate the GF system. Every single time I had chosen and equipped my fav team, I had to change characters out and re-arrange everything. In all FF titles you will most likely loose a teammember for a certain amount of time, but in FF VIII it just happens ALL the time. Some will certainly love this system, as it grants them much control of how exactly to buff their characters, yet I did not enjoy this.I really missed the chests in the game.SPOILER ALERT!For the FF Nerds only:I really liked the story and found it very interesting, yet I really found it rushed and some points in the game made zero sense to me at all. For example when the Sorcerer kills the president in front of all those people and they just cheer at her. I know it is her mindcontrol and such, but I really think the plot was rushed and had holes in it. FF VII or FF IX had just as good stories, but they were told and experinced much better, and I felt I knew exactly what was going on and it all made sense. Like the bond between Squall and Rinoa happens extremely fast. Like in the beginning she is not that visible, and suddenly she is extremely important and so on.All in all: Buy the game!

The setting enchanted me - I wished I could be Squall and have a girl like Rinoa on my Side. He is strong, independend, a Leader - And, in the beginning, a jerk.His development and the characters where what impressed me the most. For the first time, I felt like having to deal with real human beings - Not just fantasy characters with fantasy problems. They felt ... real. I loved it. Since then , I played the game dozens of times. Everytime I started it again, I couldnt stop until I finished it. It put me under a spell, everytime I touched it. for a reason.The game itself has some major flaws, like the fact that monsters are equal to your own level and the battle system includes hours of spell drawing, which can be really annoying. that you lose Seed Rankings for using G.F. is another thing that bothers me, I never used them after my 1. playthrough. it just doesnt pay to do so. using magic is bad either - Your junctioned stats decrease. what a bummer. So, for me, all that was left was Attack and Item - Not a very enjoyable Battle System. But well, you don't have to play that way and can use Magic and G.F. I just didnt.But what got me was the story. The Game has BIG parts that feel really epic - even today. Sure, the graphic didnt age very well but hey, the cutscenes are still really enjoyable. If you are ready to dive into the story and respect the love behind all the details, you will just fall in love with the characters. Probably even with the Villains. Its a more grown up story, its about love, loss and taking responsibility. its about friendship and obedience. well, its probably just about life - and the fact that everyone has problems.I enjoyed the game now for 16 Years and I will probably do so for the next 16 Years. If you have ever played an FF Game, you should grab it - Even if you just played the abominations FF13 and sequels. 10/10 !

												It's a good game, one of the earlier well known uses of a scaling levels. The PS version is definitely better if you have no interest in modding or using the steam exclusive boosts .There are select people that will tell you you're wrong for using them and to that I say whatever. The tools can be used in positive ways that make the experience more enjoyable by removing the artificial time lengthener of draw grinding. Simply turning on speed boost and activated god mode, until you max 100 draws will cut the length down to a reasonable 50 or so hours to complete. Of course you'd want to shut both off and complete fights as normal after you do so. I'd argue this + mods trumps the PS version. People are often polarized on this for several reasons so without getting into too much here are some pros and cons.pros:unique leveling system for its timemusictime travelingvideos still look goodfeelsRagnarok flight themeLaguna (You'll meet him.)cons:unique leveling systemgraphics might push some new gamers away (this CAN be fixed with modding)Squall (main char), he's a melodramatic drama queen, I love FF8, hate him. draw system, I urge you to use the speed boost+god mode for farming, but shut them off for normal fights if you're new.I like the game, maybe watch a video of the gameplay first?

												I'm a hardcore fan with FF8, so many times I would even try to escape reality with lucid dreaming, I would be in Balamb Garden where I would often train with Zell in the training center and help Selphie with the Garden Festival, but one day as I was talking to Selphie, we went to my dormitory for a private talk. She immediately said, "You know you could live with us forever.." I gave her a confused look and she continued, "We understand that you live on earth and you REALLY wish to live here". I then said "How..How did you know?" She then giggled and said "Because we've been watching you, silly!"This was a dream come true and I almost cried right there. She then said, "I talked with Headmaster Cid and he agreed that you would be PERFECT for SeeD, you just have to do...one thing". She then held my hand and looked deep into my eyes and said "...You have to kill yourself for the transfer to work correctly." I then gave her some questions, "How long do I have before the deal expires?" She then said "Cid said 3 months.." I added by saying "What's the most painless way?..." She giggled again, "Suicide will require pain buuut...if you want it quick...Get a gun and a nice shot to the head works.I then agreed and she gave me a kiss on the forehead, "I know this will be tough but once it's over and done, you'll get to live here!" I then woke up and this was last week and i purchased a gun. I might actually kill myself because that dream just felt too real to be fake and my life isn't doing so grand.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												I wanna make one thing clear: I love Final Fantasy (and RPGs in general). I have played the heck out of FFs 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, and 14, and loved every one. I really, REALLY want to like 8. Square decided they wanted to do something different. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it came crashing down in this instance.Side note: Credit where it's due, this game has a great soundtrack. The boss theme and Man With the Machine Gun are just two tracks I enjoy having stuck in my head. Nobuo Uematsu has never disappointed.Anyway. Lets go down the list of reasons this game doesn't want me to like it.-The Draw system: Lets be fair; I was prepared to tolerate the draw system. Magic is a limited resource in all RPGs, and frankly, this seemed considerably less limiting. In itself, I don't mind the system of "draw magic, cast it later". It's everything attached to the system I don't like.-The leveling system: FF8 is the only FF game to implement enemies with levels themselves. Your characters can level up as you adventure -- that's just standard for an RPG -- but unique to FF8, the enemies you encounter have their levels set to roughly match yours. Long story short, this means that leveling up is actually detrimental, because the enemies level up too. Oblivion is another game that does this (and it's one of the few flaws with an otherwise dang-near-perfect game), which causes players to just never level up because doing so would be stupid. Leveling up is a key component of any FF game, but it's butchered in FF8.-The junction system: Good God, talk about complex character customization. I won't go into all the details, but this is one of the main reasons I just can't enjoy this game. You can boost a character's stats by "junctioning" magic to that stat. This boosts it by a value that's unique per spell, per stat, multiplied by the number of casts you have of that magic. You can stock up to 100 of each spell. Here's where my big problem comes in; you stock this magic up by "drawing" it from enemies. It's a combat action on its own that does nothing to the enemy, and gives you an average of 5.5 casts of the spell you drew. That means when you find a new spell to draw, you need to draw about 18 times to get a full stock of 100. PER CHARACTER. Of which there are six. I probably spent over an hour just drawing up a full stock of about six different spells for about four different characters. Just...no. That's just ridiculous. To the PC version's credit, it comes with a "magic booster" that lets you get a full stock of a whole bunch of spells for all characters any time you want, but that feels like cheating. It's giving you a bunch of spells much earlier than you could otherwise access them. I just can't feel right by cheating in such a way.There are several different ways they could have made this system suck less. Capping at 10 instead of 100, for example. That still doesn't change the fact that the junction system as a whole is easily the most convoluted RPG system that exists.-Lack of character identity: FF7 had this issue too; your characters' combat abilities are defined primarily by the way you've set up their junction system (or materia in 7). You can set up Squall as a bruiser and Rinoa as a mage, then swap their junction setups and have them both perform the other role just fine. This limits the personality that the characters show -- and the issue is only compounded by the immense amount of time you'll spend in combat just spamming draw. This sounds nitpicky, but other FFs reinforce their characters through their combat options. In FF6, Edgar felt like the machinist because he was the only one that could use an autocrossbow. Sabin felt like the brawler because he was the only one that could suplex a freaking train. Shadow felt like the ninja because he was the only one that could hurl a shuriken. All those varying combat options reinforced their character.-Renzokuken: My last little nitpick that makes the game an absolute joke. Squall's limit break lets him smack an enemy upwards of five times, each for standard attack damage, and the only requirement to use it is to be low on HP. Theoretically, you could make mincemeat out of the entire game just by keeping Squall's HP low and spamming his limit break on anything that moves. Honestly, Square, what was wrong with FF7's limit break system? That worked just fine, and would have easily suited Squall's insane limit break.So yeah. I really, really wanted to like this game. I gave it several chances. I just...can't. On the other hand, FF7 is available on Steam, go grab that! And/Or the remake coming soon!
