												Here is another review on a Final Fantasy game. I love this game. The junction system was confusing when I first encountered this game. I admit I gave up on the game the first time I tried it. My first impressions back on the PS1 for this game were nonexistent. I eventually got around to playing it, and I was very surprised. I played this game when I was younger and thought it was fantastic, though it was confusing in terms of storyline. *Spoiler Alert* Years later I stumbled upon a theory about Squall being dead. This peeked my interest and so during the summer of 2014 I purchased this game again and played it once more. Without a doubt the theory only made me like Final Fantasy 8 even more. The thought of our hero falling into a dreamlike state and seeing his life flash before his eyes as the premise for the game was amazing. This is how I choose the story of Final Fantasy 8 to be for me.*End Spoiler*Of course if this isn't true, I still love the game for what it is in terms of music, characters, adventure, and exploration.I guess you can say that over the years I have grown to appreciate the masterpiece of some of the older titles, this being Grade A vintage quality. The game is fantastic.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												Final Fantasy 8 tells the story of teenagers who are taught to be a special forces for hire called SeeD, based out of their respected regions schools called Gardens. Using the best in weapon training, Magic and Guardian Forces (Summoned beasts that devastate opposition), they are hired as security, front line combatants, support and all around imposing presence. The story follows several of these students as they stumble away from being mercenaries, to being in the middle of a plot of a powerful Sorceress bent on ending reality. With all the talk about how good Final Fantasy 7 is, its easy to overlook the next in the series. Final Fantasy 8 was the third Final Fantasy game I played. Final Fantasy 3 was the first one I played off a second hand copy that Blockbuster got their hands on some 20+ years ago. By the time I got to Final Fantasy 8, I had played though FF 7 and enjoyed it. I was hoping to find another fun RPG to play, and I was not disappointed.FF 8 was the first one to make me feel for the characters. I transitioned from a story, that was for the most part ok, but very little else, to a story that had me feel. For that, this game ranks above FF 7.The game gives you tough boss battles that are very risk vs reward heavy. With the way you gain your Limit Breaks, you can go down several options with each boss; Full health, Full health and use Aura, or keep your characters at critical hp levels and burn down the boss fast. It may seem like these are fairly simple, but that's what makes it so solid. Its not complex, its not jumbled up, but it still requires you to think for a few seconds about healing your character, or hoping they survive to let lose their Limit Break.As far as the Final Fantasy games go, I give this a solid 9/10.Its not perfect, no game is, but its a damn good one.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												FF VIII is a title I missed out on as a kid, so I bought it now to finally experience this story.It will definitely offer much content for the player to go through. As with all FF titles there are plentyof mini-games and side-quests, which all grants valuable and powerful items, so there will be many hours invested in this game. One of the new elements, is that FF VIII do not follow the casual road of the series and is very different in some areas.There are no level system as we are used to, instead every character always need 1000 exp in order to level up, where in previous titles, the required exp would gradually increase per level. The level system in this title is used to determine which level the monsters are, and what SeeD missions you can undertake (one of the side-quests).Players will instead rely on a new system called Junctioning. A system where character equips and buffs themselves with magic, summons and moves.Magic is not learned, but 'Drawn' from monsters, which makes it possible to stock up on 100 Triple + 100 Curaga. Stocked magic is then used as usual, with the character using the chosen magic move.Summons plays a big role in this title and has it's own system, where you have to spam X to increase it's % damage output.Also there is only about 2-3 chests in the game...PROS:FF VIII offers almost infinite amount of gameplay. You will be busy getting the best gear, solve all mysteries while you adventure together with a friendly crew. The graphics are alright and I had no issues what so ever with how it looked. I liked it. Battles are always a challenge, unless you prepare yourself properly. So you will never get bored of killing bosses too fast. I ran into trouble with both Bahamut and Griever, even though I thought I was well equipped.You will experience a new, more modern take on the Knight & Sorcerer tale, which is interesting and kept me asking questions throughout the game. The characters had GREAT dialogue and the bonds that happens between them is a joy to watch and follow. I was really fond of Zell and Selphie, who is two great characters that really adds to the game.You of course not be cheated of the chance to capture a chocobo, which has is its own little (big) mini-game. Get busy and train that chocobo, so you can get some delicious items. I really enjoyed the chocobo part, even though it got tedious sometimes, but I can't have a game with no chocobo training.At a point, when you have more time and the tools to explore, you will have a lot of things to do and stuff to get.Again endless amounts of things to keep you busy.This is purely my opinion and you should only read this when you have finished the game yourself. It is worthy buying, despite these cons.CONS:I personally did not find the cast of characters too interesting. They had great personalities and dialogue, so this is based purely on how they look. Boring. I hated Zell's stupid tattoo, but I really enjoyed his personality and he got to be one of my favourite characters. Yet when I play a FF title, I really look forward to their appearances. Sadly few characters stood out, and most had little fantasy elements and more a stale citizen look.I absolutely got to hate the GF system. Every single time I had chosen and equipped my fav team, I had to change characters out and re-arrange everything. In all FF titles you will most likely loose a teammember for a certain amount of time, but in FF VIII it just happens ALL the time. Some will certainly love this system, as it grants them much control of how exactly to buff their characters, yet I did not enjoy this.I really missed the chests in the game.SPOILER ALERT!For the FF Nerds only:I really liked the story and found it very interesting, yet I really found it rushed and some points in the game made zero sense to me at all. For example when the Sorcerer kills the president in front of all those people and they just cheer at her. I know it is her mindcontrol and such, but I really think the plot was rushed and had holes in it. FF VII or FF IX had just as good stories, but they were told and experinced much better, and I felt I knew exactly what was going on and it all made sense. Like the bond between Squall and Rinoa happens extremely fast. Like in the beginning she is not that visible, and suddenly she is extremely important and so on.All in all: Buy the game!

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Just finished my first Steam-FF8 Playthrough.The first time I played this game I was 12 Years old. The setting enchanted me - I wished I could be Squall and have a girl like Rinoa on my Side. He is strong, independend, a Leader - And, in the beginning, a jerk.His development and the characters where what impressed me the most. For the first time, I felt like having to deal with real human beings - Not just fantasy characters with fantasy problems. They felt ... real. I loved it. Since then , I played the game dozens of times. Everytime I started it again, I couldnt stop until I finished it. It put me under a spell, everytime I touched it. for a reason.The game itself has some major flaws, like the fact that monsters are equal to your own level and the battle system includes hours of spell drawing, which can be really annoying. that you lose Seed Rankings for using G.F. is another thing that bothers me, I never used them after my 1. playthrough. it just doesnt pay to do so. using magic is bad either - Your junctioned stats decrease. what a bummer. So, for me, all that was left was Attack and Item - Not a very enjoyable Battle System. But well, you don't have to play that way and can use Magic and G.F. I just didnt.But what got me was the story. The Game has BIG parts that feel really epic - even today. Sure, the graphic didnt age very well but hey, the cutscenes are still really enjoyable. If you are ready to dive into the story and respect the love behind all the details, you will just fall in love with the characters. Probably even with the Villains. Its a more grown up story, its about love, loss and taking responsibility. its about friendship and obedience. well, its probably just about life - and the fact that everyone has problems.I enjoyed the game now for 16 Years and I will probably do so for the next 16 Years. If you have ever played an FF Game, you should grab it - Even if you just played the abominations FF13 and sequels. 10/10 !

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												I honestly love and hate Final Fantasy VIII at the same time.  I love the Draw ability but I hate that you’re punished with lower stats for using magic you’ve Drawn and Junctioned.  (Maybe percentages would have been better?)  I love upgrading weapons instead of buying/finding new ones but hate the lack of armor and the fact that monsters level with you.  I love refining magic and items from other items and making lower magics combine into bigger items, but turning monsters into cards to turn into items was somewhat tedious.  I love the music and the character designs, but by GOD I want to slap each and every one of them.The plot runs all over the place and reminds me of those assignments in writing class where you write a paragraph and pass it to your left.  You’re mercenaries, you’re assassinating a political figure, you’re a soldier in the past, you’re dealing with the moon and time travel...  perhaps a better translation would help.  It just feels disjointed and thrown together.As an older teen/young adult I felt Squall was a whiney, unsympathetic character.  Quistis was manipulative, Selphie cute and cliche yet harmless, Zell had SOME character development, and Irvine?  Screw him.  If you KNOW you’re going to freeze on a mission to save your home you better ask someone else to go!  And sharp shooters do NOT work alone, I hate that trope.  I didn’t like Rinoa but I didn’t hate her.  As an adult I thought I’d play the game again, and I understand Squall better, but I pity him now; poor kid’s got PTSD.  Would I recommend this game?  Sadly, no.  It’s just too tedious for me to play though so much I can’t stand to get to the parts I do like.  I’m not going to tell anyone not to play it, though.  Lots of people love this game for legitimate reasons, and more power to them.  It’s not a horrible game, just one I didn’t like.

												Today's Review: Final Fantasy VIII Let me start by telling that i don't actually review old games but this is an exception because this is my favorite game of all times, so i'll start with story of the game itself and then i'll review the game.The name Final Fantasy actually comes from the last idea when the company was still Square, the whole company was about to be broken and they only have money for 1 more game, after that it would be the end, so they use the remmain of the money to make this "Final Fantasy". Was a big surprise for Square that they sold so many copies, revitalizing the whole enterprise, the only trouble was that they didin't think the game was gonna be a success so the first game didin't have an end to make a sequel, thenfore they came up with an idea of telling a complete different history for the second one, other characters, another world, enemies, etc. That's the reason why all FF games have different characters, enemies, a different world (with the exception of final fantasy X and X-2).Final Fantasy VIII (8) tells the story of Squall, the "lone wolf" an student commited to become a SeeD, the elite group of mercenaries that work for the 3 Gardens arround the world (Balan, Galbadia and Travia), having forgotten about his past, he believes to sort his problems alone, keeping people away from him as he revalizes with his nemesis Seifer. The game is set in a world with 4 continents (Balamb, Esthar, Travia, Centra and Galbadia), as the story developes Squall creates a bound with his friends and understand the meaning of life, trought this a story of War and Love it's the background for this game. The release of Final Fantasy 8 was in 1999 and even for that era the graphic quality it's overall exellent, soundtrack it's made for battles, cinematics and some other moments that determinates the tense situation by the music. Gameplay it's rol based (like most RPG characters lvl up, they can store and use magic and of course like any FF they have summons or eidolons here called GF or "Guardian Force")Metascore: 100/100 "Best RPG game ever made, a solid buy and a beautiful work of Square"

Which at the time they only had midi format, and that would be used for the pc port of Final Fantasy 8. And also needed to use a program that generated music that the computer was able to use.The score itself was legal. Odd...And downloading, or patching the original music to this port can be what some say illigal. Suikodien, Parasite Eve... you get the drift..Do it the right way and you will feel more rewarded!  But keep an open mind! Posted: June 20, 2015
												Squall is a badass.  That being said, there are some tonal issues in this one.  It seems like they thought maybe with the once again widespread popularity of Final Fantasy (after the greatness of FF7) they should cater more to kids...so we have a band of mainly high school aged nutcases and very little real drama (and where's the blood?).We watched Sephiroth slaughter an entire building of people in Final Fantasy 7 and stick a sword through Cloud's true love...here the most controversial element is that the main villain is married to the good guys' high school principal (which also just doesn't make sense).  And oh yeah, dumb spoiler alert...our heroes have all known each other since they were toddlers--but they all forgot!They were on to something with Laguna hitting on the chick at the beginning but they totally dropped the ball with story after that.  And what is with Squall's shunning of Rinoa, my God.  She was dangling from that ledge for like an hour...  If Shinji from Evangelion got together with Squall you'd have two of the most emotionally confused individuals in Japanese popculture.  The forever wimp and the mother of all angsty yet shy dark horses.The good?  Character design, some challenging battles, when Squall gets bulled by the jetpack-riding Galbadian soldier and they both fly out the emergency exit, Triple Triad, when Rinoa and Squall book it past a schoolyard full of soldiers and students throwing down, a few examples of gnarly music, once they reveal that Ultimecia jazz the story starts to pick up again...

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												Note: My recommendation (or lack thereof) is based on the game itself. If you liked FFVIII and just wanted a port of it, then I can say I haven't had any issues with how it runs...although there was some stuttering in the ending cutscene.I really couldn't get into this game. I couldn't stand the characters from the get go, and on top of that the battle system is tedious as hell. Not only is there level grinding, but you have to actually manage your magic/stats inbetween characters on a very frequent basis. Repeatedly drawing magic from enemies over and over to make your units more powerful and if you actually use the magic you have pooled your characters become weaker again. It actively discourages the usage of magic which is so obnoxious. Everyone is also incredibly varied in terms of what stats you can assign magic to, so that's another thing that adds to the frustration. Overall I just felt like the battle system was too restrictive and unnecessarily complex. I don't mind if things are complicated if they can lead to battles where you really had to think, but honestly you just had to junction magic correctly and then just spam normal attacks, limit breaks, or summons. There's little to no variety required when fighting. To give you an example of how unvaried it is, I fought through every boss and enemy in the game solely by using summons over and over again until I got to the final boss...then I just spammed Zell's limit break to kill it. It was incredibly boring.On the note of the game being boring, my 160 or so hours of playtime for this game is a gross exaggeration. The reason it's there is because of how many times I'd fallen asleep trying to force myself to finish it.

												It's Final Fantasy VIII. It's dumb and mechanically broken, but, like me, you love it and want to buy it anyway. You probably shouldn't. Regrettably the emulation of a decade plus old game that is not sold commercially is packaged with incredibly intrusive DRM which prevents one from playing without a stable internet connections, and prevents one from even attempting to play whenever Square is experiencing server issues, such as, for example, right now. The game was purchased but cannot be played until Square sort out their end. A brief foray into the community hub makes it clear that this is not an isolated incident, and is rather something that keeps. on. happening.Unlike most of the internet, I don't have a problem with DRM. I'm not convinced it works, but it's not my money being lost to piracy, so if a company feels differently and wants to attack pirates this way then more power to them. However, when your DRM renders legitimate, paying customers physically unable to play your game then you've crossed the line into immoral practice. I have bought, and will now return, a game which cannot be played. It is not because of my computer or errors on my end, and it is not a problem unique to me. This is a widespread, known and recurring issue that Square have actively imposed upon their game.

												This is a bad game.  It is by far the worst Final Fantasy game and has almost no redeeming qualities.  The story is nonsensical and requires huge leaps of faith to follow. Junctions are confusing and require you to constantly be in the menus changing your junctions around.  GFs are mostly useless and I hardly ever summoned them in my playthrough.  Perhaps since I played this game for the first time just recently it was hard to appreciate the nuances of this game and when it came out but it certainly does not hold up like the previous Final Fantasy games. Overall, I am fairly dissapointed with this game and I hope that Final Fantasy 9 will be a better experience.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												inb4 fanboys mark this review as unhelpful because I didn't give it a 10/10.Bear in mind that I am reviewing this game from the 2015 point of view, having not played it back in its day, and I have zero nostalgia for it.Giving a review for this game is extremely difficult. It has a lot of interesting systems that make it one of the most interesting Final Fantasy games in the series. On the other hand, everything that is good and interesting about the game is opposed by a nearly equal ammount of convoluted or just plain terrible design decisions that will frustrate a modern player to no end. Some of this stuff may have been able to fly on the PS1 back in 1999, but in 2015, this stuff can grate your nerves. So let me try to point out the good and bad.DRAW SYSTEM - THE GOOD: The draw system refers to the fact that characters don't have personal magic on them at all times. Instead, magic is reduced to consummable items (e.g. to cast Blizzaga, you will need to use 1 blizzaga item). To get more spell items, you have to "draw" them (i.e. steal them) from enemies. The number you get is random. Sometimes you get zero or one, but a lot of times you'll get 5 or 6 at once. Each enemy has a menu of spells you can steal from. More useful and powerful spells can only be stolen from mini-bosses, bosses, and rare enemies. Once you've stolen the spell items, you can use them in combat or you can fuse them to specific stats to boost a character's parameters, like boosting fire def, or adding fire to their attack, or increasing HP or vitality, etc. You have the option to either steal the enemy's spell (add it to your inventory) which just gives you the item and ends your turn, or you can cast the enemy's own spell at the enemy party immediately.DRAW SYSTEM - THE BAD: As much as all of the above is interesting, you may find it frustrating that spells are essentially just items. You may also find it frustrating that, in order to stock up on specific spells (especially more rare ones), you just waste a lot of turns usings your characters to steal, steal, steal, etc etc 100 times. Stealing the spells is primarily useful for boosting parameters. The guardians (who we'll discuss in a moment) are so powerful that actually using the spells in combat is only sometimes---but rarely---useful.GUARDIAN SYSTEM - THE GOOD: The game calls them "guardian forces" for some reason, but let's call them what they really are: summons. So this game decides to make summons front and center. You collect new summons as you go through the game, which can be assigned to any character. Every summon has its one powerful spell it can cast, but if you grow each summon (like a pokemon!) it can become more powerful, boost the parameters of the ally using it, give the user more skills/abilities, or allow the user to summon it into battle more quickly. The summons are powerful, and you will want to use them a lot.GUARDIAN SYSTEM - THE BAD: The summons are so powerful that you will want to use them almost exclusively. Physical attacks and magic attacks are, on average, so pathetic compared to summoning that you will only end up using physical/magic attacks "just for fun", or in the rare circumstances when you need to beat some enemy's gimmick. (basic attacks get better over time, but do you really want to wait 60 hours for them to get better?) What about elemental weaknesses? Yeah, enemies have them, but if its a choice between casting firaga or summoning Ifrit on them, what are you going to do? You'll spam Ifrit. Managing the guardian forces is also laborious. It's about as exciting as meticulously shifting all of your materia gems around in FF7, only it involves an even more convoluted system of sub-screens, and sub-sub-screens, and even sub-sub-sub-screens. If I were new to RPGs, I would have quit this game out of frustration just on account of its dogpiled menus. Also, even though the game has TONS of summons to find, you will absolutely miss the vast majority of them unless someone tells you in advance that most of them can only be stolen from bosses (via the "draw" command) or under special circumstances. You essentially need a strategy guide opened up as you play, if you don't wanna miss a ton of them. Also, the summon animations are sooo long. They are painfully long. And since they are the focus of the game, you have to sit dumbly and watch them a lot. This is slightly improved when they level up enough to learn "boost", which allows you to play a button tapping mini-game to pass the time during the animation and raise the attack power of the summon, but 1) you'll have to check a strategy guide to learn how boost works, because the game can't be arsed to explain it; 2) they are sooo long though.CHARACTERS - GOOD: In-game character models look much better than the dopey FF7 ones, although their faces do look kinda pinched and weird. Squall always looks cross-eyed, but I accept that because it amuses me. The characters and story get more attention and are overall more appealing than FF7 in my opinion.CHARACTERS - BAD: A lot of cliche (but that's typical of JRPGs). Squall is a stereotypical angsty and brooding I-hate-everything-and-have-a-bad-attitude-leave-me-alone-and-get-out-of-my-room emo teenage boy type. At least at first. As a teenage boy I would have thought he was the coolest. As a grown man, I find him immature and irritating. He gets better. Oh, and as much as other FF8 fans have told me they like the segments, you also will have your game and story progress continually interrupted by a "Biggs and Wedge" sequence, where you have to play through a complete dungeon and story sequence as some characters you don't know. After you play a lot of them, they will start to tie into the main story more and make more sense, but for a long time they are complete non-sequiturs. Who are these people? Why do I care? Can this just be over so I can go back to Squall and friends? What is the point of this? Maybe you'll dig it, but these felt like disruptions (or interruptions) to me, so I didn't care for them.OTHER - BAD: Convoluted menus. Fails to explain some game features completely or gives very poor explanations of other features (there is a tutorial/guide available, but its helpfulness varies). While the draw/guardian (aka steal/summon) systems are interesting in a lot of out-of-combat ways, they also make the inside-combat part of the game feel lopsided and weird. Plus they require an inordinate amount of fiddling in menus---as bad as fiddling with materia gems or worse (but, hey, some people love all of that fiddling, so if that's you, have fun). The game also some very bad dungeons in it, such as one dungeon consisting of 15 copy-pasted floors of the exact same doughnut-shaped room you have to run completely around (i.e. poor design trick used to make you trip more random encounters while not caring enough to make the dungeon any more interesting). The game is also a completely clutz when it comes to save points. Don't be surprised if you are made to sit through 30-minutes of unskippable story sequences and then ambushed with a boss fight you had no way of knowing was coming. No saves. If you die or forget to steal the guardian force, prepare to do that entire 30-minute boring story sequence again. This doesn't just happen once. It is a repeat problem. The game tends to suck at save point placement in general.Steam only allows thumbs up or thumbs down, when what I'd like is a pair of shrugging shoulders that says "mixed feelings". You might like it! But for me personally, in 2015, the number of tiny annoyances, deliberate inconveniences, and questionable or convoluted design choices just adds up to me banging my head against the wall a little bit too often. Like the world's cutest dog that also won't stop sh***ing on the floor, it is a thing I feel compelled to love with all my heart but equally as often feel compelled to drop off on the side of the road.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Most of the people here seem to give their thumbs up because of nostalgia. I never played this game before, i never owned a console,so I am rather unprejudiced. I played FF 7 some time ago and actually liked it.FINAL FANTASY VIII plays very much like an interactive novel. While it is technically an open world game, this world is pretty much empty aside from the storyline. If you know that something like that will bother you, there is no reason to read on.You will only like this game, if you like its story:At the beginning of the game you are a young elite mercenary, who is just about to finish his final tests to become a full fledged member. This guy is antisozial, lacks understanding of his own emotions and has trust issues. The story is pretty much a coming of age story, with topics like taking on responsibility, friendship, first love, etc.. I would say the story is mostly aimed at 12 - 15 year olds. While it is certainly not an award-winning story it is not too bad either and it is always hard to treat those topics without getting too cheesy.I actually like the graphics and have the impression that the game aged pretty well. Sadly the port is not well made. If you decide to pick it up, i would advice you to get the roses and wine mod. This mod introduces better music and volume control for the music. And you will absolutley want this volume control after a few hours X).Now we come to the gameplay (running around and fighting) which is simple no fun. I will not go into detail. I am sure that this has already been discussed "in great detail aka with much swearing" somewhere else. I felt pretty OP from the start. The battle system is laborious, while not being complex. This is the biggest game design sin for me. It's a little bit like the game gives you a hundred buttons you can use and a big red one that says press me. Why press all the other buttons if the big one does the trick. The draw system makes this game extremly grindheavy and slow paced. What actually really infuriated me during gamplay was the way the game spams you with absolutly powerless and meaningless enemies. I would say 90% of all battles fall under this categorie. In the most extreme cases the enemies are so weak, that you could let the battle go one for 20 mins without doing anything and still win. If you played pokemon just imagine a game that constantly nags you with fighting safcons. This, combined with the fact that you often run around aimlessly, can aggravate even the most patient person. (I think the only reason why these enemies do exist is as refueling stations. Yes you actually heal yourself up by fighting them.)The last thing I have to say about this game is, that it does a pretty bad job at communicating what you can interact with. While I expect that some people will call this exploration, I think people should not have to go around clicking at and bumping into things in their spare time. This behavior is normally reserved to insects (flys and windows).I played this game only till the end of disc 2, so everything i wrote here does not inlclude the following chapters. All the issues i described here were present from minute one. I only played so far because i thought the game might get better at later stages. It did not up to that point. I can understand everyone that likes the game. The presentation is pretty much spot on, the gf animations are pretty cool and the story is not bad either. But the actuall gameplay isn't even mediocre. For me gameplay trumps everything else, so i give this game a thumbs down.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												After hearing about the unneccesarily complicated Junction system. The HORRIBLY annoying Draw system that has you STEALING magic from enemies because learning spells and using MP to cast them was too easy. I came to the conclusion that this is the second worst Final Fantasy game after Final Fantasy 13. After 20 hours into the game I can honestly say, that I will probably never finish this game.The characters are AWFUL. Squall starts off as an emo kid, he warms up later but he still whines the entire way there.Zell is a mental deficient, he has a tribal facial tattoo and he punches things. That's his character.Selphie is a brain dead stereotypical blonde.Quistis is best girl, she has a whip and I'm into that.Rinoa is the forced romance that is also your mortal enemy Seifer's sloppy seconds. (Spoony was here)And Irvine is the womanizer that no one cares about, he's also a sniper that doesn't have the guts to actually snipe someone he was HIRED to snipe.The characters, the progression/magic system and completely insane time traveling plot make this one of the worst Final Fantasy games out there. The only way you can defend this game is out of shear nostalgia. It's not fun to steal magic from monsters for hours just to have 100 magic spells for each party member that you need to not only CAST in battle. But to also JUNCTION them to your stats to make your characters stronger. Some people say "oh just play Triple Triad" Triple Triad being the game's obligatory card game that allows you to collect cards that you can later use to gamble for better cards or straight up salvage the cards into items and spells) If your answer to fixing an annoying and detracting aspect of a game, is to play a minigame that detracts further from the actual game JUST SO YOU CAN PLAY THE REAL GAME WITH SPELLS. content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Let me start off by saying, I love the Final Fantasy series, my favourite game series of all time actually and I'm proud to have them all. But VIII? Man... So much lost potential. Though there are a handful of people that will say otherwise saying its their favourite installment. But still.Lets start with the positives. The music, as with all FF's, is fantastic, honestly one of my favourite soundtracks in the series. The graphics, for the time at least, are beautiful, the FMV's are flawless and in this updated texture version makes it all the better. This game also has some of the most relateable characters in the series.However thats all the positives I have honestly. The negatives? Its such a slow game, like I've only just been playing 32 minutes and haven't had a single battle yet. Thats not to say later on there isn't a lot of battling, because there is. But still, on the subject of battling, this also has one fo the worst battle systems in FF (though not as bad as XIII). Unlike with, lets say, EVERY OTHER RPG, MP has been replaced with simple uses. So you have 6 uses of fire, then you need to get more. How does one get more? By taking (drawing as its called in game) it from monsters. This is one fo the most tedious processes I have ever had to sit through as believe me, you will be doing it, A LOT. There is far too much junctioning (adding magic to your stats to improve them etc) that makes it seem mor elike a math test than a RPG. The story is mediocre and... just my god. Then there is the fact that in this version of FFVIII the sound files are aweful as they currently use the Midi files from the original 90's release in the 90's. I also noticed some audio glitches in the opening cutscene. However FFVII had this issue and Square eventually replaced those, so I presume they will do it with this too. There are also A few minor, but noticible graphical glitches.So unless your a hardcore FF fan or your one of the odd balls that liked this game, avoid it, otherwise, wait for a 50% off or something.

After replaying it thrice, I realized that the whole thing ends up being an intentionally addictive and time wasting game with many flaws. -The characters are mostly 2 dimentional and forgetable (the main character has the charisma of a soggy french fry and is very, very unlikable).-Some pauses in the scripted scenes are tedious to endure (Lucky for many, there is a fast forward button that comes in handy every time)-The fact that you need to draw magic (up to 9 units every turn, if you're lucky) by grinding it from enemies, until you've maxed them at 100 each, or until you get around it by using GF abilities, adds HOURS to the game!-The game kinda makes you junction depletable magic to your stats, therefore penalising the use of most magic spells.-Even Chocobo World ends up being a tedious minigame that will have you wasting hours on the premise of gaining just a few items usable in FF VIII (Not that I was expecting much from a pocketstation game).-This isn't a dealbreaker for me, but the music quality has suffered a noticeable downgrade, and there have been many complaints about it. (SPOILERS... kinda)-The love story between Squall and Rinoa seems forced and contrived, and yet, the whole game revolves around it.-Don't want to play triple triad? go on... you'll just miss on a bunch of swell items, items that are necessary to beat late game monsters like Ultima and Omega weapon, that otherwise are a pain, if not downright impossible to beat without.-You gotta wait your sweet time to finally be able to drive the garden arround and explore the world, and you gotta wait even longer to get your hands on that shiny ruby red Ragnarok (and therefore being finally able to scout the entirety of the globe).I won't recomend this game, since there are better games in the FF franchise, buy it only if it is on sale or if you're a diehard FF fan. None the less, this old rascal still holds dear to me. and maybe that's saying something.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												Playing Final Fantasy VIII a decade and a half later reminded me how to cringe again.The story starts out with a pointedly anime premise--teenagers at school falling in and out of drama. Squall, who I promptly renamed, has the emotional capacity of a rock for the entire first disc. However, he actually develops as a character later in the game; including a funny moment when Rinoa (renamed Rhino) carefully explains that he needs to convey his thoughts aloud or the others won't understand him. That said, many of the side characters are forgettable, including Zell, who enjoys hot dogs and punching things. The game's love story almost works, but Squall spends most of his time oblivious to Rhino's desperate attempts to be noticed. Very cringeworthy. Around disc 4, the game takes a hit of acid and drops us into time compression, which kind of looks like a Salvadore Dali painting. Entertaining, but batshit crazy.I go back and forth on the gameplay. Triple Triad is excellent (nominated for a Steam award--best game within a game), but its distribution of rules around the world is crippling. Junctioning scratches my itch of watching numbers get higher, but the way information is visually presented is rough at best, and I found myself wishing for a more modern UI. The world map is huge, but largely void of content--especially compared to FFIX, which is full of glorious treasures. Guardian Forces are fun to hunt down for their unlockable abiliies, but the summons themselves don't do nearly as much damage as a normal attack, and they're unskippable. Yep. Maybe there's a mod for that.The music is excellent as always (thanks Uematsu), however the game defaults to ear-splitting midi unless you make a point of downloading the original tracks like I did. The 1999 graphics obviously aren't great, although many of the full motion videos are still quite entertaining, especially when you're able to control a 3-D character in many of the ridiculous battle scenes, such as when the enormous floating "garden" schools collide.Do I recommend this game? No, but that didn't stop me from playing it through. I expected a♥♥♥♥♥♥show, and that is what I got. Two thumbs up!

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Final Fantasy VIII was such a terrible game. I feel bad buying it on the Steam Marketplace (during the summer sale). It is just a nostalgia game, like how Dragon Ball Z is just a nostalgia anime; it sucks terribly, but we have fond childhood memories of it. Final Fantasy VIII had a combat system that made every single character the exact same, without any differences. None of them had any real differences, except limit breaks. The graphics were terrible, even for its time. Final Fantasy VII, its predecessor, had better gameplay graphics (less pixelated individuals and backgrounds; even though the models were much more simple). The game is more based on waiting than anything. It has no strategy, as the closest thing it has to complexity is "use the summon that does its weakness against the enemies". Your basic attacks do nearly no damage, and your summons will almost never die (unless you are really stupid), so there is never any point in doing anything (other than buffing your party with haste/debuffing the enemies); which each summon takes about 30 seconds to do its animation. The animation is so ♥♥♥♥ing repetitive that it is not even funny. You can't even customize your weapons or armor; past the tiny amount where you can find blueprints (maybe) to create slightly better weapons (barely a noticeable difference). The dialogue, transitions, story, and character connections are so badly written that I honestly have no idea what I am doing or what my motivation to do said action is half of the time. Literally, there is no reason, past working in the same organization, that most of these characters should be working together. They are all forced to gravitate around this annoying emo character, Squall. Literally he does nothing to show he is leadership material and only continues to push people away like an♥♥♥♥♥hole, and for some reason everyone seems to go "HEY LEADER! WE LOVE YOU. TELL US WHAT TO DO". The only seemingly proper relationship between characters that would make sense (friendship or anything more) would be between Zell and Selfie, but I am 14 hours into the game and I can not remember them speaking to each other even once (if they did speak to each other, then it was such small chat that it is not even registered in my memory bank), instead they just continue to go "Hey guy that is a complete♥♥♥♥♥hole to us and does nothing but mope around all day, you are our leader and we think you are just the coolest bean". There is not character relationship building, past Quistis and Squall, which seemed interesting in the beginning, because they seemed to have some sort of love interest type thing going for them, but it is suddenly dropped for no reason and never brought up again; it was mostly Quistis going "Squall, I was your instructor and I know you so well over the amount of time I have been teaching you. You act like a less talkative version of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I can't stand what so ever, but I think I will show romantic interests in you anyways", while Squall goes "Get the ♥♥♥♥ away from me, you don't understand my pain. CRAWLING IN MY SKIN!". By the way, I am so far into the game and I still have no idea why Squall is such an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who seems to be depressed all the time, he just is... It is his character, he is just an unlikable ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that people are FORCED into loving (for no explained reason).But seriously, this game is so ridiculously cringeworthy. I have not played a game worse than this in a while, but seriously. This is why you don't play games from your childhood; you will find out the game you used to love is actually a steaming pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥ There are so many discrepancies I have with this game that I have not even voiced. I really do not recommend this game; it is easily a 3/10 game. I may try and finish it, but only when I get extremely bored; it is not worth the ridiculous amount of time it takes to complete it.

												Don't buy this. Buying this encourages more of these hack ports by Square Enix.This is one of the worst ports on steam. Worse than stock Deadly Premonitions or Dark Souls. Hideous without mods, and the existing mods don't help much because there are apparently no high-res background renders in existence. Whatever you do, don't contribute to its sales. If you buy the game used and want so support Square Enix, write them a check, in no convince them that this is acceptable.Parts of the game have been upscaled, such as the character models.Other parts are left the same, such as backgrounds of areas. The world map is also hideous, despite being rendered exactly like the character models.Even with the worse overall graphics, you should play this on an actual PS1 or use certain non-steam-discussible methods to "emulate" that experience. The difference in quality between character models and backgrounds causes lots of shocking realizations, like the fact that any NPC that doesn't move is PART OF THE BACKGROUND and not an actual model.The core gameplay is here, no doubt. But this is the ugliest way to play the game. There are mods that attempt to fix it, but they aren't that great. Other games with similar technology from this gen like resident evil had PC ports with higher resolution backgrounds that can be patched into any version of the game. For whatever reason, this isn't the case here, and the only mod you'll find of "hi res backgrounds" is a photoshop gaussian upscaling.Oh yeah, and despite the game having 0 online elements, it includes a sub-GFWL quality always-online DRM system that won't let you play it or access your saves without a cloud account and internet connection. If you lose internet, it actually forces you to stop playing the game right then.Squall wept.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												I always enjoyed the idea of the final fantasy series. The Japanese design and story telling, the intricate combat systems. The last in the series that I played was FFX, probably the last in the I enjoyed. However, before everything went full 3D and went turbo serious, FF7 existed; and changed the gaming world completely. Clearly FF8 had a tough job to follow, and from what I have seen playing this game (again), it failed in my eyes.You see, the flaws are not apparent because of the differences in combat, or these intricate systems. It is the execution of nearly all aspects of this game that a sub-par.In FF7, you were gently lead into the complex systems (such as the Materia system). In FF8, they try to smack you on the head almost as soon as you take control of your character. People claim that the complexity of the combat 'Junction' system is why the game is hated so. But I don't think it is that simple. What I have noticed is that the UI system is clunky to use. Too many sub menus, so many things all happening on the screen; a 'downgrade' to the UI in FF7 which was very tight and compact. The Junction system itself doesn't really fit into the fantasy canon, nor does it blend well into the game world they created. It's just clunky like the control system it is built from.This design creeps into other areas, such as the characters and their visuals. They are simply too annoying. Ugly to look at (Zell's skinny legs?). Selphie is seemingly useless. Questis is the only decent character, combat wise, but you can't take control of her again until much later in the game.The only thing that makes sense in the whole story is... well.. none of it. There is a fan theory [1] that Squall actually dies at the end of act 1, and the remainder of the game is a fantasy where he gets to kill the superior fighter, Seifer; win the girl, and saves the world all in the last dying minutes of his life, in a kind of dilated dream state.If you don't apply this theory then the game can only be looked at as the worst story telling and plot in the FF series. However with the fan theory in mind, it may be a master stroke of story design; but this is totally lost on its own fans because it is far too subtle.The story wouldn't be so bad if the characters and their animations weren't so tedious. It is strange because FF7 had less definition, yet more personality. This time round, I made it half way in act 1, and had enough. For me this is a game that rested on high fidelity graphics and CGI. Sadly, it doesn't live up to an enjoyable experience because of the audio, story, characters, game-play, mechanics, and even the controls.[1] http://squallsdead.com/

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Ehhhhhh.I could probably just leave this review at that, but I should probably give you a little more. There is a reason I have no playtime thus far on this version. It's a struggle to convince myself to play it again.This game, for me, is one of the weakest in the series. People say that graphically it greatly improved on its predecessor but in all honesty, I PREFER looking at VII to looking at this. I understand they were going for a more "realistic" look, but this is a fantasy series after all. I just...don't feel like it worked. A lot of the environments are without a doubt beautiful, but I really don't like the character models.And speaking of the characters...oh boy. Flatter than cardboard cutouts, for the most part. There is virtually no development here (which is a crying shame in a series KNOWN for its well-written characters) and when there IS development, it is minimalistic and poorly-explained, solely for plot convenience (THAT scene that links the characters, anyone? Ugh.) Also, the majority of the characters aren't even that likeable to begin with - many are simply outright obnoxious. It made a lot of sense to identify with them when I was of school age, but I look back on it now and it has NOT aged well.The plot. Well, it's a headache. This is an example of time-travel done badly (if you want time travel done WELL, watch Dr Who or, better yet, play Chrono Trigger.) Nothing is explained clearly, or even in an attempt to clarify itself. It's hard to link any event or motivation for anyone in this game doing anything at all. And those flashbacks. I am all for flashbacks if they work, but these just seemed rather jarring. I have played ths several times on the Playstation with an attempt to make sense of it and I just...can't. I'm sorry.Since I've totally slated the game so far, I may as well tell you what I DO like. The music is a definite highlight, particularly the ominous villain themes involving piano and Latin chorus. The theme of the final dungeon gives me chills whenever I hear it. The environment themes do fit nicely, and they represent the mood of each area and event really well.The Draw/Junction system, whilst often a point of contention, is something that I actually enjoyed. It's very unique and lends an enormous degree of customisation to how the game is played through managing stats and abilities. Combat itself is fluid and pretty, and the summoning system is excellent.I struggled for a while over which thumb to click here. In my opinion, the fundamental flaws of poor characters and poor storytelling just overshadow everything else, so I'm having to click "not recommended." With that said, different people like different things, and I would still advise you to try it for yourself. FFVIII is not a terrible game, but it is also very far from being a great one.

Posted: June 18, 2016
												TL;DR:Cast Fire on Ifrit : Ifrit loses HP.2/10 bad game is bad.On the longer version, the quality of a Final Fantasy can be measured around 2 major things:1°) Quality of story2°) Quality of gameplayI won't be talking a lot about the story, it is what it is, as far as I am in the game, i'm still not really impressed, but I wasn't that much impressed with the VII, so...On the gameplay part though, the game is just plain bad. The whole system revolves around Geforces and associations. Which in parts is not bad, the general idea is good but in practice, it doesn't make for a good system.First, there are no real limits on the casting of Geforces, so you could just spam invoke them to win fights (you can!), and they will take damages for you, so it's a win/win.Second, the association system implies having specific spells in quantity in your inventory, so in theory, you shouldn't use them at all, otherwise you're just weakening your characters. If you do, you just have to draw the spells over and over again, which is a little tiresome.The limit system also is kind of a letdown, the system to acquire them is ok, but to cast them you need to be low on HP, which... Well, why would you want to? Worst part is, the system is not even very clear on what is "low HP", sometimes, the health bar is yellow but you can't actually cast the limit.There are a lot of those ideas that could make the game good in theory but just fail to achieve anything in the game.You would better consider practically any other FF game, VII, IX and X...

content:
Posted: April 3
												If you ask someone which final fantasy is there favorite, it's easy to see why 8 is almost never the choice. tl;dr: FF8 falls flat on its face in so many ways that it's very difficult to justify paying for it. If you're looking at trying out one of the earlier final fantasies as a first time player, do not pick this one. Start with 7 or my preference, 9. Spoilers below:First off, mechanically, the game is a complete joke. You have to first understand the junctioning system which is so unnecessarily convoluted, and once you do understand it your characters are insanely overpowered and there is no challenge to the game. Typically I like the idea of "The better player you are, the more powerful you are." but this game does it poorly. Then the story relies so heavily on deus ex machina plotlines that it's hard to take seriously(The hero being able to randomly pilot a giant boat/ship out of no where? The hero being able to pilot an alien ship that also just happened to be close enough to prevent them from dying of oxygen deprivation in space?), that coupled with uninteresting or bland characters just makes this an absolute shame when it comes to being labeled a final fantasy game. The graphics and story scenes would be great at the time, but simply doesn't hold up. I can't honestly recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played it and isn't looking for nostalgia. You're making a much better purchase with final fantasy 7 or 9, both of which offer a much greater story and much more interesting gameplay.

												Here is your game if you ever wanted a more random final fantasy game with hardey any enemy variety.  Do you like it when playstation games have stories that say to go to places with no clue to where they are and force you to use a guide to figure out where to go repeatedly throughout the story?  Then this the game for you.  An added special feature is you have to equip junk to all your stats and attack and defence instead of wearing gear, but the game repeatedly unequips all this stuff during story transitions and has you keep swapping characters after short levels and random nonsense flashbacks.  I guess it was good that I didn't play this long on the playstation because they did add speed up to the PC version which was a good time saver. 												I do not recommend this game for new Final Fantasy players or players who have played the other main series games. In short, I will list the pros and cons of Final Fantasy VIII PC with a short explanationPros:-Great cutscenes-Better resolution-Junction system-Battle System-GFs (They can give you abilities to help you progress through the game)Cons:-Junction (The reason I put this as a pro and a con is that if you understand the junction system you can breeze through the game with no challenge at all)-GFs (Another one that is on both pros and cons and for the same reason as the junction system too, it takes the strategy and challenge out of the game)-Music (To be honest I love the FInal Fantasy VIII...in the original PS1 version. The PC music sounds like it was made from the MIDI progrm and sounds very, very bad. You need to use mods to make it sound better)-Drawing (You're spending 20-30 minutes drawing powerful magic from a enemy/boss when it can only take 5-10 minutes to defeat enemy/boss only to find out the powerful magic makes your stats worse...yeah no thanks.)-Enemies/Bosses get stronger each time you level up (Remember whenever you get stuck on a boss you get out of the area and start killing a bunch enemies so you can level up so you can finally beat that boss. What if everytime you level up that boss gets stronger. Well, this game does that and it's not good.Well that's my review on Final Fantasy VIIII'll give this game a 4.5/10

												Always considered one of the worse games in the saga, and as a matter of fact, it is.The battle mechanics was original, yet that doesn't mean it's nice to play. Having to draw all the spells from enemies it's time consuming and BORING. Furthermore you need to save them if you are going to Junction the spells to your stats (which you totally are) so it makes the magic system useless, you practically can finish the game by abusing of the ATTACK command.The plot is plain and simple, you wont know what the hell is happening or what's gonna happen next because it seems totally random and pointless. Squall struggles to know what a SeeD is for half of the game when he was studying to become one. They sold us that Squall was gonna be a new kind of main character for the game when he is a cheap copy of Cloud Strife's personality (with a lamer past). It would be great if you could just spend half of the time just fighting and getting entertained with amusing battles, which you cannot. The game is very centered in it's story, pointless missions and absurd plot twists.What is worse, it's been more than 15 years since the game was released and the 'new' PC versions seems to be even worse. Lame music and no graphic improvement at all, they only added the possibility to cheat and add some magic spells that might come in handy. Buy it if you're gonna spend less than 5€, otherwise you're wasting your money.

												I was originally skeptical about this game. I had played 4, 6, and 7 before this, and watched gameplay footage from 10. The junction system was at first unattractive to me and I didn't like the idea of not having actual equippable armor. However, I got used to this system, albeit slower than I got used to materia in 7. After getting the hang of junctions and realizing the importance of drawing magic from enemies (or using the Magic Booster :p), the game was much more enjoyable for me, and I blazed through it. The love story between Squall and Rinoa was nothing short of heartwarming, as was the comraderie between all of the party members. The music was amazing, just like in every other Final Fantasy game (although the Roses and Wine Mod was useful). Also, Triple Triad was an extremely fun card game. Didn't use Chocobo World much, since I didn't really see a need to. All in all, this game, after initially seeming very lackluster and unneccesarily confusing, in time, revealed its true colors as an exceptional Final Fantasy game, just like its predecessors.

												Not as good as VII or IX and in my opinion the weakest of the PSX Final Fantasy games. The story is fairly good and I have always particularly enjoyed the scenes featuring Laguna. I won't say any more on the story to avoid spoilers.I have always thought that the battle system is flawed, so much so that I describe it as “broken.” I hate how monsters and bosses level up with the characters; the draw system and how the larger the stocked number of a junctioned spell the more the stat increases. I find this constantly makes me think about how and when I'm using magic; so much so that I tend to under use magic and rarely spend the time to stock-up on spells. I find that this method of only using physical attacks and Guardian Forces tend to make battles a slow and boring task.Another battle mechanic I absolutely hate is how only the current HP is displayed and there is no display of each characters total. I could list a few more examples on how the battle mechanics are worse here than in other FF games too, but it may become quite a list...I now remember why I used to use an Xploder cheat disc to hack 99 “The End” magics, just to escape battles and bosses on the PlayStation, I just wish you could do it here. The Steam version's “Magic Booster” helps, but only adds in a few of the lower end spells. I have however found that these are very good spells to junction to characters stats.I greatly enjoy the games story and this is the main reason I would recommend, buy and play the game.

												Years ago, I waited impatiently for the sequal to FF7.  What came out, FF8, was seen as a huge disappointment to many people.  However, years later, I now see what a gem FF8 truly is.  Sure, it doesn't have the memorable characters of FF7, but a part of me much prefers the junctioning system to materia.Hear me out!  I didn't think it could be possible to love a game more than FF7!  But the secret to FF8 is the CARDS.  You not only have the card game, but the cards give you your magic!  And your tools!  And your limit breaks!  In the first 3 hours of the game, you can get to over 3,000 HP through junctioning Aero or Blizaga (refined from cards) to your HP!This wasn't explained at all in the game and its tutorial system SUCKS.  But.  Replaying the game with an indepth walkthrough shows just how facinating the FF8 junctioning system is.  Replay this game again, letting go of FF7 and allowing FF8 be a game in its own right.  You won't be disappointed!

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Story: The story is pretty classic. You are Squall, an elite mercenary and member of Seed. The game starts out with you completing your final test to be a full fledge Seed. Shortly after you get your first assignment and you move out. From helping a small resistance, to fighting of a witch, to saving the world this game has it all.Appearance: FF7 may have been a revolution in going from 2D to 3D but this game improved upon that. With a more “realistic” 3D models this game is amazing. The world is huge and beautiful. Following the story you will see maybe half of what there is to see in the world. There is a few items/events that you can permanently miss which is sad but the amount of content and re-playability is amazing. Game play: This is a classic retake on the final fantasy game play. You have a four party system typically consisting of Squall and three others. You can choose from up to six permanent characters and five temporary characters. Its still maintains the turn based battle system with a few added bonus's. Over world and in world exploration is easy and reminiscent of most final fantasy games. You have an overworld that you traverse to go from town to town. Over time you gain different vehicles each having its own pros and cons. You are able to use a controller with this game. I was able to use both a corded xbox 360 controller and a PS3 controller. It was more difficult to use the PS3 controller but it was well worth the effort. Of course you can use a keyboard but its not really advised.Achievements: The achievements for this show an improvement over the FF7 achievements. Its nearly impossible to complete the game with all achievements in one go. Most of the achievements are simple and self explanatory but there is one or two that will make for a challenge.Bottom Line: The game averages for about $12. On sale it has been as low as $5. Even for full price its worth picking up for some nostalgia but at the same time I would wait for the next sale to pick it up. The game is a lot of fun even though nothing has changed in 15 years but its worth picking up.

												This was the first Final Fantasy game I ever played because it was on a demo disc that I received from Pizza Hut that also had Medievil and the original Tony Hawk game. In my opinion, the leveling system used in FF8 is probably my least favorite, but this is mainly because I feel that it is overly complicated. Although, this does allow a depth of customization that is only achievable in FF10, but even more so than the sphere grid. The music in this port isn't perfect, but those that are saying that it is unplayable because of the music must be some serious audiophiles because it isn't THAT bad. The game looks decent enough, but it is clear that it hasn't aged terribly well, albeit better than FF7 has due to the physical representation of the characters on and off the battlefield, but that doesn't change the factt that the foreground is. . . well. . . abysmal. That being said, the first time I summoned Shiva and watched her perform Diamond Dust, chills of nostalgia washed over me. (No pun intended) Having to sign up through Square-Enix's website is definitely a downside but mainly because it's just an added inconvience that shouldn't be necessary. Gameplay wise the only problem I have encountered is the ability to run away. The button combination didn't seem to work on my 360 pad and I couldn't remember for the life of me what the keyboard controls to run were, so I ended up fighting a dinosaur with 15k hp within the first hour of the game. The added magic booster feature makes the game absolutely trivial and you may as well be using gameshark codes, but if that's your thing then by all means, cheat away.If you have never played this entry into the Final Fantasy franchise and have no other means of doing so other than this port, then I would definitely recommend giving it a shot; however, if you can get your hands on the original, own a PS3, or something similar, then I would say to pass on this title. It's not the games fault that the port is poorly done.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I know a lot of people will say they got into gaming from early age with titles like Mario Brothers and so on. I was playing those games too. Sure. I was playing the early Mortal Kombats and so on. I loved going to the arcade. But if someone had to ask me to really pinpoint the one game that got me absolutaly fascinated with gaming as art form as well, I would say FFVIII. I know there were many other games of note before this - FFVII for example and other non Square titles, but I didn't get to play those. We didn't have a console growing up because my parents got addicted (HA!) and decided to get rid of it, and we were always just alittle behind with the technology to play the newest stuff on PC; I would hang out with friends and watch them play or play on their systems. This game we got when we finally had a PC then that could play it, and it was first time I played an RPG like this (although Zork Grand Inquisitor is my ultimate fave, there are differences here). This game is not something you can really bust your way through. It takes time to properly level your characters; you have to collect magic by either drawing it out from enemies or going around buying it, and I loved the concept that you could run out of the number of spells you had as opposed to mana; you have to really play through the environment to get the full experience. Okay, well, you can get through it faster by just sticking to the main story, but there are a lot of fun side stories and puzzles and bosses to deal with.Story wise, it's another romance tale, but I think Square Enix does them pretty well. You gave a broody, emo, angry male lead, Squall, but you learn why he's like that as you go on in the story. You're not really supposed to like him all that much until his character is further revealed, in my opinion. You have a bubbly, romantic, but motivated young female lead, who has other sides to her revealed as well. There's time traveling involved, and just don't focus on thinking about it too much because the storyline as a whole that involves a few twists and turns when a powerful sorceress makes a move on the world these characters inhabit is pretty interesting. It's character based too, and you tend to fall in love with a lot of them. The dynamics of gameplay is that you can design a your core group with up to 3 play playable characters. If you're not into custamizing characters often, might not be your thing, but they have a neat auto option that you can select and it does all the hard work for you. Combat is turn based, and it's not timed. I kind of like that, and it's almost more like chess (umm, just not the timed kind, I suppose). You can also collect guardian forces (GFs), which are powerful magical monsters that you can call upon and level up to create devastating attacks. Magic is, as previously stated, a collection game, and the most annoying thing can be spending hours fighting enemies to collect magic because stores sometimes only carry a certain amount of some magics. However, if you're into that kind of long haul game, it shouldn't bother you. If you're picking up this game as someone part of the new generation or just having gotten into gaming in today's age, you might think the graphics a bit backwards, but they were pretty spectacular from that time, and I still find them rather breathtaking. Cut scenes are pretty awesome and cinematic, as Square does. Also, I've heard the music for the game when bought and played through Steam is the midi stuff, and not the actual musical score originally played with. It's not that big of a turn off in my opinion, but might be for you, but for the price that FFVIII usually goes for, I'd say it's worth it to try and see. You can easily purchase the phenominal orchestra score on any web sites like amazon for example - and I highly recommend that (there is also a full piano album!). All in all, I highly recommend giving this game a try, especially if you are a fan of the RPG genre and haven't been able to play some of these older titles.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												This was one of my first childhood games so I am a little biased, but I do love this game. The story is good. Sometimes you want to slap Squall around for being such a little♥♥♥♥♥♥but he has a personality, and a character arc. All the characters have these things. The owner of a pub in Dollet has a backstory and he is not even in the main story. The story works, and makes sense, while still leaving a little to be read within the lines. It understands subtlety. For instance, Ultimacias final line. It was cut short for a reason, to make a point words could not convey. That was poetry. Like darksouls it takes a little sleuthing to work out some finer details, but they are there.Now the gameplay, while at moments satisfying, falls into farming alot. The magic booster in the PC booster attempted to address this, but instead of giving 100 of a few choice spells I thought it would boost any spells found to 100, eliminating unnecessary farming while still leaving explration and progression. I am also glad chocobo world was included because it's nice to know what I was missing out on as a child. It allows the item farming to do itself, I just had to edit the hex file to make it go faster. Farming like this did eliminate alot of the challenge that I faced during my original playthrough, so I suggest not bothering with chocobo world; it's a terrible game anyway.I like the junction system, it makes you choose what stats to focus on, what to be immune to, and how to flavour your attacks. It also fits the aesthetic of the game, which is more industrial than other Final Fantasies. It still does have its own fantasy mythos, but grounded in a world of science. This is an old style of RPG that rewards busy work, but if you are willing to put up with it there is plenty of exploration to be had.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Great game from the 90's with a decent touch up. The only problems i've seen so far are the environments are sort of pixelated on higher resolutions and the music is just hollow MIDI instead of the higher quality PS1 music. Other than those two gripes the game is still as great as i remember. I wont spoil anything here but the game is worth its pricetag as it was one of the greatest Final Fantasys in my opinion. As with its newer aged brethren FF8 uses the ATB system meaning the enemy can attack before your party and vice versa. Faster characters or ones with a higher SPD stat will see their bar fill up faster and thus get to attack more often. This iteration also introduced the Junction system which honestly is a love or hate change. With the junction system you link or "junction" magic to your stats to increase them further. The more magic you have linked to a stat the better the boost. However, some magic boosts other stats better than others and what stats are junctionable is solely determined by what GF's are equipped.Thats the next topic though. Your summons in this game are called GF's or Guardian Force. Most of the FF staples are here including Ifrit, Shiva, Alexander, Odin and so on. They level up seperately from the characters as well as seperate health bars and also gain AP or Ability Points. AP is used to learn new moves for them like SumMag+10% which increases their damage by 10%. Through this system they can also learn other abilities aside from health and damage boosting abilities for instance Quazecolt (unsure of spelling at this time) can learn the ability Card which will in battle turn a monster into a Triple Triad card. The separate health bar comes into play during summoning. For a set amount of time based off affinity with a GF (increased by use of said GF) your health is taken over by their health bars as an ATB bar ticks down. Once it emptys the GF is summoned to do its attack or whatever ability it may have (Support GFs are here) and then the players health bar is restored to its place. Any attacks suffered before the GF attacks during that time period though causes damage to the GF until it is KO'd and needs to be revived before summoning again. Its something i enjoy but newer audiences may not is that GF's can have summon animations lasting only a couple seconds to minutes (i believe the final summon has a length 4 minute animation but does insane damage).There's a lot more to this game as well but the last topic i'll touch up on here is the Triple Triad mini-game. Triple Triad is a card game played in-game completely optionally (it has its own line of sidequests as well) but is very well put together and is probably the funnest mini-game in any FF. The game updates itself as you explore new areas of the world by adding new rules and winning options (like getting to choose one card they used for yourself or taking their entire hand of cards) all of which can be changed by visiting the Queen of Cards who will with a small fee strike down rules you picked up and/or win rewards. The game is a load of fun and can make the main game even easier for you when mixed with Quezacolts "Card Mod" ability. Which is were his Card ability comes into play. You can earn all the cards by winning Triple Triad or you can turn real monsters into a card for use or even refine the card with Card Mod to turn the monster into a set item(s). Through this it's actually possible to get the Main Character Squall's ultimate weapon on the very first disc provided you have the patience or card battlling prowress.Well this reviews gone on long enough. I sincerely hope you consider picking this game up if you haven't played it before or if you're a returning veteran to FF8. Happy gaming everyone!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												Part of why I think this game gets so much hate, even from me, is that it came on the heels of one of Final Fantasy 7, of of the best selling and most well loved RPGs of all time. Final Fantasy 7 had a brilliant and customizable battle system, an engaging story with interesting characters and an awesome soundtrack. Final Fantasy 8 has... an awesome soundtrack, at least. To be fair, the story is pretty interesting all the way through the end of disc 1, but then things get so weird and hard to follow and major plot points are added and removed on a whim, as though the game has ADD and can't decide on what kind of story it wants to tell you. But the battle system is...oh god it's a total trainwreck.So one of the many flaws of this game's battle system is its "junction" system. In FF8, magic spells are treated as a consumable item. Kind of a weird choice, but I don't have a problem with that necessarily. What I DO have a problem with is that spells are a consumable item AND the game allows you to "junction" them to your character to improve their stats. The better the spell, the more the stat increase. If you follow this chain of logic, you'll realize that if you have a high level spell junctioned to your character and you cast that spell, your character's stats will actually decrease. So then what's the point of casting magic? There is none in a normal playthrough, especially when you consider that your summon monsters, called GFs in this game, can be called upon to essentially cast any magic spells you'd want anyway, provided you don't mind watching a 45 second cutscene of the GF appearing EVERY FREAKIN' TIME. There's lots of odd decisions like this that slow the battles down in FF8 and make them tedious. Even the way you get magic is a chore. You can "draw" spells from an enemy, but depending on a few factors the game doesn't really explain, you'll only typically get around 3-6 spells per draw. Which means you have to sit in a battle and farm draw for quite a long time if you want to get up to the maximum of 100. But really the most broken thing about this game is when you discover you can manipulate limit breaks. Your character's chance of limit breaks are actually random in this game, another odd choice. The less health you have, the higher the chance of the limit break. But if you cycle your turn order, you can keep re-rolling the calculation that determines your limit break, essentially letting you limit break whenever you want. Totally. Broken.Now that I'm done ranting about the battle system, on to the story (mild spoilers in this paragraph). It really does seem like it's gonna go somewhere for the first, maybe quarter or third of the game. But then we hit a point after disc 1 where the narrative has an identity crisis and starts grasping at different ideas and concepts and inserts them randomly into the story which results in a totally insane mish-mash of disconnected themes and gaping plot holes. I know Final Fantasy is a universe where characters get shot, sliced and burned in every battle, but the first huge narrative red flag is when one of the main characters is freakin' impaled through the heart with a giant icicle during a cutscene... and then is totally okay in the next scene. Like the game barely even acknowledges that it took place. Come on Final Fantasy 8! If you're not gonna take your story seriously then I can't either. The artwork and music are the huge redeeming factors of this game. FF8 features some of the most gorgeous hand-drawn backdrops in any RPG I've seen. And this might be controversial, but I think FF8 is Uematsu's best work. At the very least it's my favorite of his work. The relaxing "Breezy", the entrancing "Find Your Way", the mysterious "Under Her Control" and the nostalgic "Fisherman's Horizon" highlight the soundtrack. And of course "Man With the Machine Gun" does its best to keep the mindlessly tedious and broken battles from being too much of a nuisance.SummaryThis is far from the best Final Fantasy, and misses the mark on battle system design and storytelling. At best it's an average-ish RPG with a trippy story, some awesome music and inspiring artwork. Still there is something sort of intangibly alluring about playing this game. I must admit I've replayed this trainwreck at least 3 times now.For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

Battles are fun and engaging and the card game is incredibly fun and addictive to play (gotta-get-em-all.)
