content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Well, hearing it from a person obsessed with the FF series, it may not be as convincing to get this game. Let me just start with this: This game just so happened to be the first game I ever played. Back when it was on the PSone, I literally started with this, then moved to Mario, and so on. Crazy right? You'd figure that Mario would have been the first. Either way, when I first played this game, I don't even remeber what my innital take on the game was. I thought 'Why did I play this? What made me want to play it? How did it even play?" Well, I found the answer to that after finding it a second time on the PSone.The game is set up pretty well. You start off with just a base idea of the game, and don't even really grasp how it works in the beginning. However, as you progress through the game, things become much more understandable. You become so over powered that you feel like you're invincible. Still even with the game being a little confusing, it has both its up and downs.First, the good stuff. The main attraction; GF (if i remember correctly, that's for Guardian Force). These are the main mechanic in the game. Without them, all you can do is attack....... literally(more on this in the cons). Even so, they can become insanely powerful if you level them up, and they can learn new abilities that you can then use both inside and out of combat. Some are for making battles easier, some for making battles non-existant, some for making items like potions and elixirs; the list goes on and on. The GF's become the driving force behind this game, and it's really a neat mechanic to get behind.Next comes magic. Now this is both a negative and a positive, as the magic isn't really special. What magic can do, depending on your GF's, is be used like and equipment to increase your player's stats. Meaning, if you have the right magic for your character, their stats become so powerful that even boss fights feel like a walk in the park. All in all, it isn't really that bad.Now, the cons. First off, those GF's. As I mentioned before, without them, all you can do is attack. I mean it. You can't use items. You can use magics. You can't use anything accept for the weapon in your hands. It can really hurt in a lot of battles you aren't prepared for, especially a boss fight. And if you forget to equip the GF's to your character; it just makes the feeling even worse compared to when you do it on purpose. Yes, you have to remember to take care and equip all of your GF's before you go into battle, otherwise, suffer defeat. And speaking of care.... you remember those GF abilities i mentioned earlier? In order to get them, you have to grind for a while to get enough "AP" just to unlock these abilities. Don't get me wrong, that's the concept behind a lot of games, and it's completely acceptable. However, the issue is how many abilities these GF's have and how many you are able to use. Great! You've unlocked the most powerful ability in this GF. In order to equip it, you have to unequip the only ability saving your life in combat right now..... Even when you unlock the special GF ability that allows for four abilities to be used, most of the time, the abilities are so similar, that it becomes a personal fight with yourself on how you want to optimize this one character. What's worse is that, say you don't have that character in your party. Well, you need the GF equiped to them, so you unequip it from them. Unfortunately(if i remember correctly), you have to go through the trouble of optimizing that same character all over again. It becomes a hastle, makes you not want to unequip GF's for the sake of making it easy, then you end up in a situation where you are fighting a boss and needed the abilities of one of the GF's you can't use right now because it's equiped to another character somewhere else. Major pain, and I still love this game. Makes you wonder how.Next on the list of cons is magic. Like I said before, it's both a pos and neg when it comes to this. Firstly, magic isn't infinite. You don't have a mana pool to draw from in order to cast these spells. Instead, you use a system known as "draw" to take the magic from your enemies in the middle of a fight. Personally, I like this system because of the randomness you get from each enemy, meaning you can base your fight off of just the magic you can draw from them. However, the issue is how many time you can use it as well as getting rid of useless stuff you don't need or can't use(by "can't use", I mean it's pointless to use it to begin with. Like using a level 1 spell on a level 100 monster..... pointless). Being as you draw magic from your enemies, there is a limit to how much you would be able to use it. Understandable, it's just frustrating to have to suck it out of your enemy for and hour just to get enough to be able to really use it for your characters stats. Thing is though, that you get much better magic down the road(obviously). You only have 8 pages of magic with 4 slots in each, meaning you can only have a total of 32 different spells at once. Say you've filled up your slots. Finally! You've found the one spell in the game that will max out your characters stats..... But you have no room for it. Well, unfortunately, you can't just delete your magic. That would be too easy. You can give it to other characters though...... oh right! You made all of the other characters max out the exact same spells so that their stats would be awesome too. Well, there you go. You have two options. Either fight and use nothing but the spell you want to "delete",which you most likely have 100 copies of(yeah. you can have a total of 100 of those 32 spells), or ignore it and move on with your life. It really does hurt when I run into this situation. It sucks, plain and simple.Really, these little issues are that big of a deal. Yes, it's a pain to respec your character every time you want to use it. Yes, it sucks when you can't draw the magic you want. However, these are such obvious obsticles the we, as gamers, can easily overcome them in a heart-beat.... no; even faster than a heart-beat. These obsticles are nothing. Really, they just add to the experience of a well made(yet not really well told) story. And that's always the selling point for me in games. I don't care for your phanshy grafiks or your smooth lighting.... I want a story that will grab me by the neck, shake really hard, and then ask me if I'm okay. All in all, a rating for me on this game; it well deserves an 8/10 for me, though it would be 9/10 if I could, you know, use my items without the help of and almighty being.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Great game from the 90's with a decent touch up. The only problems i've seen so far are the environments are sort of pixelated on higher resolutions and the music is just hollow MIDI instead of the higher quality PS1 music. Other than those two gripes the game is still as great as i remember. I wont spoil anything here but the game is worth its pricetag as it was one of the greatest Final Fantasys in my opinion. As with its newer aged brethren FF8 uses the ATB system meaning the enemy can attack before your party and vice versa. Faster characters or ones with a higher SPD stat will see their bar fill up faster and thus get to attack more often. This iteration also introduced the Junction system which honestly is a love or hate change. With the junction system you link or "junction" magic to your stats to increase them further. The more magic you have linked to a stat the better the boost. However, some magic boosts other stats better than others and what stats are junctionable is solely determined by what GF's are equipped.Thats the next topic though. Your summons in this game are called GF's or Guardian Force. Most of the FF staples are here including Ifrit, Shiva, Alexander, Odin and so on. They level up seperately from the characters as well as seperate health bars and also gain AP or Ability Points. AP is used to learn new moves for them like SumMag+10% which increases their damage by 10%. Through this system they can also learn other abilities aside from health and damage boosting abilities for instance Quazecolt (unsure of spelling at this time) can learn the ability Card which will in battle turn a monster into a Triple Triad card. The separate health bar comes into play during summoning. For a set amount of time based off affinity with a GF (increased by use of said GF) your health is taken over by their health bars as an ATB bar ticks down. Once it emptys the GF is summoned to do its attack or whatever ability it may have (Support GFs are here) and then the players health bar is restored to its place. Any attacks suffered before the GF attacks during that time period though causes damage to the GF until it is KO'd and needs to be revived before summoning again. Its something i enjoy but newer audiences may not is that GF's can have summon animations lasting only a couple seconds to minutes (i believe the final summon has a length 4 minute animation but does insane damage).There's a lot more to this game as well but the last topic i'll touch up on here is the Triple Triad mini-game. Triple Triad is a card game played in-game completely optionally (it has its own line of sidequests as well) but is very well put together and is probably the funnest mini-game in any FF. The game updates itself as you explore new areas of the world by adding new rules and winning options (like getting to choose one card they used for yourself or taking their entire hand of cards) all of which can be changed by visiting the Queen of Cards who will with a small fee strike down rules you picked up and/or win rewards. The game is a load of fun and can make the main game even easier for you when mixed with Quezacolts "Card Mod" ability. Which is were his Card ability comes into play. You can earn all the cards by winning Triple Triad or you can turn real monsters into a card for use or even refine the card with Card Mod to turn the monster into a set item(s). Through this it's actually possible to get the Main Character Squall's ultimate weapon on the very first disc provided you have the patience or card battlling prowress.Well this reviews gone on long enough. I sincerely hope you consider picking this game up if you haven't played it before or if you're a returning veteran to FF8. Happy gaming everyone!

												A blast from the past now on steam, but defenitly has some issues. As I spent a great deal of time playing this game when I was younger I've certainly noticed some differences with the steam release, and the major one was also present in Final Fantasy 7. The music is once again poor quality like FF7, the difference being is the lack of outrage toward the FF8 release may not persuade those working on it to change said poor music quality as FF7 has the more rabid and certainly larger fan base. On a lesser note(and certainly more opinion based)is the lack of a vibration function for those using controllers. As I mentioned I spent a lot of time on this game, and a small problem in combat is Squall's gunblade mechanic not having the difinitive confirmation of critical strikes. Again this is a small issue, but having the visual queue flash on the screen I feel is not enough for some players, especially those who have never played the game before. I could go on about the games highly angst driven plot based on a love story. I could go on about the silly draw mechanic and the metric tonne of time it will waste but you could easily watch Spoony's review for that. The drive for buyers here is content with a capital C. There's months worth of gameplay for newer players here and I can recommend it for that alone really, even if the price is a little steep. Regardless it's still a decent port that I'm going to play to completion for sure.

Posted: December 9, 2013
												This was the first Final Fantasy game I ever played because it was on a demo disc that I received from Pizza Hut that also had Medievil and the original Tony Hawk game. In my opinion, the leveling system used in FF8 is probably my least favorite, but this is mainly because I feel that it is overly complicated. Although, this does allow a depth of customization that is only achievable in FF10, but even more so than the sphere grid. The music in this port isn't perfect, but those that are saying that it is unplayable because of the music must be some serious audiophiles because it isn't THAT bad. The game looks decent enough, but it is clear that it hasn't aged terribly well, albeit better than FF7 has due to the physical representation of the characters on and off the battlefield, but that doesn't change the factt that the foreground is. . . well. . . abysmal. That being said, the first time I summoned Shiva and watched her perform Diamond Dust, chills of nostalgia washed over me. (No pun intended) Having to sign up through Square-Enix's website is definitely a downside but mainly because it's just an added inconvience that shouldn't be necessary. Gameplay wise the only problem I have encountered is the ability to run away. The button combination didn't seem to work on my 360 pad and I couldn't remember for the life of me what the keyboard controls to run were, so I ended up fighting a dinosaur with 15k hp within the first hour of the game. The added magic booster feature makes the game absolutely trivial and you may as well be using gameshark codes, but if that's your thing then by all means, cheat away.If you have never played this entry into the Final Fantasy franchise and have no other means of doing so other than this port, then I would definitely recommend giving it a shot; however, if you can get your hands on the original, own a PS3, or something similar, then I would say to pass on this title. It's not the games fault that the port is poorly done.

												I actually enjoy FF8. I'm not enjoying this edition of the PC port.Why is that? You should never lose a game because the controls are awkward. And yet, FF8's re-release seems to succeed in this regard.If you use a gamepad, the game still displays the keyboard controls in-game. So if you're trying to input codes in the stupid train mini-game (which is a fine example of how Square tried to innovate by sucking the fun out of the game, but I digress), you're struggling to remember what the default X, C, S, and V (Seriously, Square Enix? No WASD? No space bar? No Enter key? Did you just pick a bunch of keys at random?) map to on the gamepad, and this is fatal when you're trying to enter 4-digit codes. At least the original PC port allowed you to use a gamepad seriously, displaying the buttons instead of the keys-- by contrast, this revisit is a joke. FF7 didn't have this problem, of course, because they used keywords for each button regardless of how you mapped the buttons. Awkward at first, but then, you weren't confused by the time you were doing squats in Wall Market or rifle drills in Junon. That they didn't put forth the same effort for FF8 is unacceptable, as they decided to always show a disclaimer about seizure risk before the game is launched, and always show the keyboard map every single damned time the game starts like FF7. Who designed this port, anyway? A barrel of monkeys?So, gamepad users, here's a workaround for this annoying feature: Map the keyboard keys to numbers representing the buttons on your gamepad. Hopefully the game will now display those numbers instead of the default keys. You'll still need the keyboard to get past the insanely annoying key map reminder.To add insult to injury, the keyboard and gamepad button maps don't line up in the config screen, which makes one wonder if they really hired monkeys to develop it.I'd much rather find my old FF8 discs and play that instead...

												Story: The story is pretty classic. You are Squall, an elite mercenary and member of Seed. The game starts out with you completing your final test to be a full fledge Seed. Shortly after you get your first assignment and you move out. From helping a small resistance, to fighting of a witch, to saving the world this game has it all.Appearance: FF7 may have been a revolution in going from 2D to 3D but this game improved upon that. With a more “realistic” 3D models this game is amazing. The world is huge and beautiful. Following the story you will see maybe half of what there is to see in the world. There is a few items/events that you can permanently miss which is sad but the amount of content and re-playability is amazing. Game play: This is a classic retake on the final fantasy game play. You have a four party system typically consisting of Squall and three others. You can choose from up to six permanent characters and five temporary characters. Its still maintains the turn based battle system with a few added bonus's. Over world and in world exploration is easy and reminiscent of most final fantasy games. You have an overworld that you traverse to go from town to town. Over time you gain different vehicles each having its own pros and cons. You are able to use a controller with this game. I was able to use both a corded xbox 360 controller and a PS3 controller. It was more difficult to use the PS3 controller but it was well worth the effort. Of course you can use a keyboard but its not really advised.Achievements: The achievements for this show an improvement over the FF7 achievements. Its nearly impossible to complete the game with all achievements in one go. Most of the achievements are simple and self explanatory but there is one or two that will make for a challenge.Bottom Line: The game averages for about $12. On sale it has been as low as $5. Even for full price its worth picking up for some nostalgia but at the same time I would wait for the next sale to pick it up. The game is a lot of fun even though nothing has changed in 15 years but its worth picking up.

												I seem to be the only person I know who actually likes this game. I have no idea why - it's by far my favorite Final Fantasy game, and the only one I've bothered to play through all the way to the end. I found the story captivating, the characters were memorable, and the gameplay was great. My favorite thing to do was just walk around and play Triple Triad with random NPCs, collecting more and more cards as I progressed through the game. Although the technology of the day caused this game to have somewhat limited graphics, Square did a great job in trying to create a more realistic looking gameworld, including properly proportioned human characters rather than deformed little sprites. If you never played this game back in the day on the Playstation because of its bad reputation, it's worth giving it another shot now and considering how revolutionary some of the ideas used in this game were in retrospect. I can only hope that this game gets a reboot in the future with some updated graphics, so that a new generation of gamers can be turned on to the great storytelling this game has to offer.

												Final Fantasy VIII is one of my favorite games of all time. I ignored the criticism that VIII got in comparison to VII and in the end fully enjoyed the game. I felt that its Junction system was much more fulfilling than the Materia system ever was, allowing you to really customize characters for battle. Yes drawing magic from enemies can be tedious, but its not required to always have 100 casts per spell so the tedium was brought about because of people being stubborn. The story, though sometimes cheesy, is overall very enjoyable. Character development is failry weak as a whole, but really strong for certain characters. The music is beautiful but beware PC buyers, you won't be hearing it like I had 14 years ago as the PC version has horrible low-quality midi music. Download the Roses and Wine mod to add the original PS1 score, or even add in the orchestrated stuff that sounds absolutely beautiful. Graphically, the game hasn't aged well. Of course, it was originally a ps1 game. The pc version has SOME enhancements, if you can call it that. running it at a higher resolution is pointless as the pre-rendered backgrounds are very low quality, and the new in game models are nice but for some reason the world map looks very bad. I turned on the original graphics to get the original feel back. Yes its pixelated, but its beautiful pixelation. Overall, I feel that FFVIII is one of the best in the series. Yes the junction system can seem convoluted, but if you pay attention to the tutorials and just tinker with it, you can see just how much power comes out of it. NOTE: THE MAGIC BOOSTER IS GAME-BREAKING. You can use it from the launcher. it requires a save file, and it breaks the game. It gives you 100 casts Cure, Cura, Curaga, Fire, Fira, Blizzard, Blizzara, Thunder, Thundara, Sleep, Blind, Silence, Berserk, Bio, Esuna, Aero, Confuse, Break, and Zombie which are all very powerful and mid/high level spells, meaning that you can junction high magic for extremely high stats early in the game. I thought it'd just fill up spells i already owned from the list above, but it actually GAVE me the spells I didn't have. Keep that in mind, as once its used you can't undo it on your save file.

												TL;DR: Crappy port, don't buy.Back in 2000 they released a PC version of Final Fantasy VIII. Back then, it didn't compare very well to the original PSX version of FFVIII. The music sounded a lot worse than the PSX, and the visual quality when compared left a lot to be desired. This steam edition that has been released has changed..... nothing. It's almost like they re-released the exact same game from 2000 with the same crappy MIDI music and worse graphics. In fact, I'm pretty sure that is exactly what they did, which is a pretty low blow to fans everywhere.In addition to that, the game doesn't support thumbsticks on your controller, so you're stuck with the very choppy 8 direction movement without much fluidity to it.Now originally my review was a bad review, however in light of the previous aspects, you can however modify the game to have better FMV sequences, and better (or even custom) music. I have done so and the game is much more tolerable. This is the kind of stuff the developer should be doing anyway, but maybe they'll fix something in the future. If you know how to mod this game, the port isn't that bad after all.

A Guide for FINAL FANTASY VIII
By: Osaka

												Alright I have seen both positive and negative reviews on the version released on Steam.Here is my take Limitied SpoilersYes they messed up the bio about the game.  Final Fantasy 8 follows the lone wolf Squall on his journey to become a SeeD member. SeeD is the elite mercenary force of Balamb Garden. Seifer is pretty much Squalls rival in all regards. The game begins with Squall having to pass a GF exam to participate in the offical SeeD mission for cadets. After he passes that he along with 12 Seed and 12 Cadets must save Dollet from a Galbadian takeover. That is all I want to reveal as the storyNow most reviews talk about how the MIDI music adversly affects the gameplay. Now while I agree the music isnt that extremely different from the PS1 Version.  SE could have taken the time to add the original ST in but it wasnt needed. I am sure there will be a mod for the game that fixes it, however I personally like the music. It is uniue to the PC version.Now another aspect that reviews hate on: MAGIC BOOSTERThis is a neat little feature to the game but it isnt needed at all. Just click PLAY and never touch the BOOSTER icon if you want the original play style, having to draw and junction magic, as well as refining it from items. I started playing and my old PS1 instincts kicked in, never having to think about MB. I had Card, Card Mod, HP-J and 1000 affection with Quezacotl before even leaving for the Dollet Mission. You dont have to use MB but its there if you want it.Finally the GF summoning sequences and soundsTHe only GF that is horrible is Quezacotl but it is endurable because his sequence isnt long, every other GF has been accurate to the PS1 Version.  If you dont like Quezacotl then dont use him but that again doesnt diminish the gameplay experience. Everything you had to do on the PS1 version you need to do hereAnyway I recommend people who have never played FF8 to play it on Steam. It is worth it considering everything from the storyline to mechanics are the same.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Without a doubt one my favorite Final Fantasy games; FF8 sports an interesting leveling system unique to the series where the enemies level in power and skill based on your level.  This makes it so every location you visit, regardless of its original level, a challenge every time.  But this does not mean that you need to be on even ground with the monsters you are fighting due the interesting, and very strategic, Junction system.  This system allows you to use magic, and your summoned creatures to not only tip the field of battle but to completely throw it off and allow you to dish out massive damage, while at the same time turning you into a damage sponge.Off the top of my head, I believe, the game has about 16 summon creatures called Guardian Forces.  These GFs work as an augmentation device, as noted above, but also serve a number of other useful positions.  With a GF attached you will be able to equip your normal system, items, summoning, and the most important being draw.  I’ll talk about that in a moment though.And although the GF can equip these basic skills, at first, there is a medley of other things that it can equip as well, which would include stat buffs outside of the magic junctions, special attacks, enemy avoidance, the ability to turn enemies into trading cards, and many others.  Most of these skills are learned through fighting battles while other, more powerful ones, can be purchased at pet shops or can be found later in the game.  Now we move onto the magic system.  Again, it is interesting, different, and happily strategic.  There seems to be a little more strategy in this normal FF title than there seems to be in your average tactics game, but I digress.  Players do not have the ability to outright use magic, instead, they Draw magic from specific draw points or from any enemy in combat (tedious but preferred) and storing it for your junctions or using it.  I normally just kept them for the junctions since most bosses have something that will dump the scale in your favor (You can use and take whatever they can use).A little added piece would be to always draw everything you can from every boss you find.  This will often give you powerful magic and hidden GFs.Now above I mentioned that you could turn enemies into trading cards and this doubtlessly raised an eyebrow or two.  This is for the card game Triple Triad, a game found in this particular world.  Now normally I avoid these mini-games like the plague but this one actually has a useful purpose.  Aside from a few achievement unlocks, a good number of the many cards in the game will give you items if you use one of the GFs special abilities to convert cards into items or powerful magic.  The game itself is also pretty fun as the matches are quick and the rules and play-style change as you go to different places.  Also the rules and play-style of other areas will dynamically switch with others.The story is interesting, it has evolving characters, aside from the obligatory emo lead character that Japanese games seem to love so much, and it will keep you invested and engaged along with some side missions and story tied secret bosses thrown in for a bit of fun on the side.The big reason to play this game is for the strategy involved in it and how it will hook you just from the into movie.  And although it is a little dated for today, and some of the characters and story elements are sort of stale and overused in the genre, it really doesn’t pull too much on the overall impact of the game.  Final Fantasy 8 is still an 8/10.  It’s a really good game and should be a part of any RPG fans library.

												A blast from the past now on steam, but defenitly has some issues. As I spent a great deal of time playing this game when I was younger I've certainly noticed some differences with the steam release, and the major one was also present in Final Fantasy 7. The music is once again poor quality like FF7, the difference being is the lack of outrage toward the FF8 release may not persuade those working on it to change said poor music quality as FF7 has the more rabid and certainly larger fan base. On a lesser note(and certainly more opinion based)is the lack of a vibration function for those using controllers. As I mentioned I spent a lot of time on this game, and a small problem in combat is Squall's gunblade mechanic not having the difinitive confirmation of critical strikes. Again this is a small issue, but having the visual queue flash on the screen I feel is not enough for some players, especially those who have never played the game before. I could go on about the games highly angst driven plot based on a love story. I could go on about the silly draw mechanic and the metric tonne of time it will waste but you could easily watch Spoony's review for that. The drive for buyers here is content with a capital C. There's months worth of gameplay for newer players here and I can recommend it for that alone really, even if the price is a little steep. Regardless it's still a decent port that I'm going to play to completion for sure.

												Part of why I think this game gets so much hate, even from me, is that it came on the heels of one of Final Fantasy 7, of of the best selling and most well loved RPGs of all time. Final Fantasy 7 had a brilliant and customizable battle system, an engaging story with interesting characters and an awesome soundtrack. Final Fantasy 8 has... an awesome soundtrack, at least. To be fair, the story is pretty interesting all the way through the end of disc 1, but then things get so weird and hard to follow and major plot points are added and removed on a whim, as though the game has ADD and can't decide on what kind of story it wants to tell you. But the battle system is...oh god it's a total trainwreck.So one of the many flaws of this game's battle system is its "junction" system. In FF8, magic spells are treated as a consumable item. Kind of a weird choice, but I don't have a problem with that necessarily. What I DO have a problem with is that spells are a consumable item AND the game allows you to "junction" them to your character to improve their stats. The better the spell, the more the stat increase. If you follow this chain of logic, you'll realize that if you have a high level spell junctioned to your character and you cast that spell, your character's stats will actually decrease. So then what's the point of casting magic? There is none in a normal playthrough, especially when you consider that your summon monsters, called GFs in this game, can be called upon to essentially cast any magic spells you'd want anyway, provided you don't mind watching a 45 second cutscene of the GF appearing EVERY FREAKIN' TIME. There's lots of odd decisions like this that slow the battles down in FF8 and make them tedious. Even the way you get magic is a chore. You can "draw" spells from an enemy, but depending on a few factors the game doesn't really explain, you'll only typically get around 3-6 spells per draw. Which means you have to sit in a battle and farm draw for quite a long time if you want to get up to the maximum of 100. But really the most broken thing about this game is when you discover you can manipulate limit breaks. Your character's chance of limit breaks are actually random in this game, another odd choice. The less health you have, the higher the chance of the limit break. But if you cycle your turn order, you can keep re-rolling the calculation that determines your limit break, essentially letting you limit break whenever you want. Totally. Broken.Now that I'm done ranting about the battle system, on to the story (mild spoilers in this paragraph). It really does seem like it's gonna go somewhere for the first, maybe quarter or third of the game. But then we hit a point after disc 1 where the narrative has an identity crisis and starts grasping at different ideas and concepts and inserts them randomly into the story which results in a totally insane mish-mash of disconnected themes and gaping plot holes. I know Final Fantasy is a universe where characters get shot, sliced and burned in every battle, but the first huge narrative red flag is when one of the main characters is freakin' impaled through the heart with a giant icicle during a cutscene... and then is totally okay in the next scene. Like the game barely even acknowledges that it took place. Come on Final Fantasy 8! If you're not gonna take your story seriously then I can't either. The artwork and music are the huge redeeming factors of this game. FF8 features some of the most gorgeous hand-drawn backdrops in any RPG I've seen. And this might be controversial, but I think FF8 is Uematsu's best work. At the very least it's my favorite of his work. The relaxing "Breezy", the entrancing "Find Your Way", the mysterious "Under Her Control" and the nostalgic "Fisherman's Horizon" highlight the soundtrack. And of course "Man With the Machine Gun" does its best to keep the mindlessly tedious and broken battles from being too much of a nuisance.SummaryThis is far from the best Final Fantasy, and misses the mark on battle system design and storytelling. At best it's an average-ish RPG with a trippy story, some awesome music and inspiring artwork. Still there is something sort of intangibly alluring about playing this game. I must admit I've replayed this trainwreck at least 3 times now.For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

												What can I say about this game? I remember the day I bought this gem and if anything, this game has matured like a fine wine. It's not often I can say there are games which I have played for several years and can still find new things to do when I already thought that I had turned the game completely inside out. After a few years without playing this game it still felt brand new to me and it certainly didn't feel too heavy to play after several hours like I have found with some other classic games.For those of you who have never played this game - I really don't see what is stopping you! It has everything any RPG fan would want. Story rich, relatable characters, comedy, side quests. Triple Triad itself is such an enjoying time killer that I often found myself playing the card game more than the actual main quests. That's not taking anything away from the main story though. Although I wouldn't say this is the best Final Fantasy by a long shot, it still has 40+ hours of gameplay to whet your appetite, and an addictive enough story that you might just start a new game right after you finished it just in case you could have done things a little differently.The Junction system also deserves a little praise, I think. It's reasonably unique compared to other games in the Final Fantasy franchise, but it's also very simple to master, making this Final Fantasy a better choice for those who are new to these kinds of games. It also leaves a lot of room for experimentation, which unfortunately a lot of the other games seemed to lack. Basically you can tailor your teams abilities to how you want to play and not have skills restricted to one person. Though it should be noted that this comes at the cost of the usual various armours and robes you could buy in their place.The only major discrepancy I would have with this version of the game is the sound. There is no in game option to turn off or even lower the BGM to an acceptable level. It is just constantly blaring in your ears unless you turn off sound completely on your system. I can understand how it may not bother some people. but it just felt like it could have been put together in a more appealing way if the sound were better as a whole.In terms of gameplay my only real dislike is the way you get paid. Although admittedly getting paid for a job you do makes more sense than monsters having a coin purse on them, money doesn't really come into play in this game because of the item drops that enemies make. Perhaps you can buy a few potions or synthesize your weapons, but beyond that you will have an excess of money that is only there to look pretty.

												I played this game ages ago on the console and it was never really one of my favorites - as much as I love the Final Fantasy games, this one was only slightly higher on my list than FFX. It's just the game overall that sort of drives me insane on this one, with the card game, obnoxious characters, and the incredibly stupid battle mechanics.That being said, it's more than playable still. It's a time killer for me, more than anything, but this is still faithful to the game, at least as far as I've seen so far. The graphics are decent enough, pretty much on par with what I remember from the Playstation and not on par with more recent games, but still good. I believe there's a skip feature on this for cutscenes, but it's convoluted to access, so I just kind of twiddle my thumbs through them if I have to watch one more than once. But the controls are easy enough to reconfigure and use quickly.Really the only faults here for me are ones that already had existed in the game to begin with.That card game that is nothing but a massive waste of time. It's pretty much impossible to win any games at the start anyway after you're given your first few cards, because they are useless and everyone around you has much better ones. So it's not even worth playing against anyone until a bit later in the game when you've had a chance to gather some new cards. And even then, it's really not worth it unless you just like to drag your game out for no real reason.Drawing magic is tedious and annoying, and while it's more convenient than an MP gauge that runs low constantly, draw points are often unpredictable and not always the best plan. Luckily, the game comes with a cheat you can access upon start-up of the game that rids you of this problem by maxing out your magic, but if you don't like to play with cheats on, it wears on you after a while. Waste battle moves to gather magic from enemies, or hope you find a few draw points for what you're looking for while you're out wandering around the map; it was a neat idea, but not terribly practical for the long haul.Then there's the GF system, which requires you to attach a summon to a character to have any battle options other than 'attack'. Again, it's an interesting idea, to an extent, but then simply giving you the option to assign summons to certain characters and leave it at that would have been fine. The way this is done, you literally HAVE TO assign one to a character or they can't even use items during battle, and that is just ridiculous. It forces you to constantly re-adjust your set-up any time a character joins or leaves the party, which while that tends to happen anyone in one of these games, this entire system makes it beyond ridiculous.Granted, there is an upside - every character has the potential to summon during battle, and for boss fights, or just higher level creatures you probably should have run away from but don't want to, this can make things go quickly when you have three characters just constantly summoning their GF for their turns. There's also the benefit of being able to swap magic around between characters for the optimal set-ups, which, while I do hate this system overall, they did at least do it effectively.And as for the story, well... It's Final Fantasy, what do you want? It's big, wartime-related, and that's about all there ever is to them. Obviously there's other little elements, but at the end of the day, it's what every Final Fantasy game boils down to in the storyline.So all of that being said, the game is still *good*, it just depends heavily on your taste in Final Fantasy games. VII, VIII, and IX were all relatively different in set-up as they gave some new things a try, and that's good. It's helped sort out what does and does not work for the current games. This one is never going to be my favorite, and I certainly wouldn't even really count it in the top 3 for the franchise, but it's worth playing if you enjoy the games as a whole. Just prepare for some frustration with some of the mechanics.

												Pros: - You can enjoy it for months. At this price, there's not much to complain.         - CG is not so bad. Compared the new games, of course, there's a lot to be desired, but really it isn't so bad.         - The story keeps you moving. It's not repetitive.         - GFs are cool and so fun to use.         - No MPs to limit your GF or magic use.         - Limit breaks of each characters vary greatly and are all interesting.           - Insanely beautiful characters. Every single-one of them. Cons:         - It can be so corny and cheesy at times. The romance between Squall and Rinoa takes up so much time and is just lame. I almost puked when Rinoa jumped to his lap and the sappy romantic song started to play. Seriously! I'm a woman and a fan of romantic comedies, but this is just too much and is not so tastefully done either.        - Rinoa can be really really annoying. She's so freakin nosey and always acts so self-important.         - GFs can be so powerful that it takes some fun out of the game.         - Limit breaks that can only be used when the character is about to die is quite pointless. You have to choose between saving that character or using the limit break. Can easily end up dead if you choose the latter. Some limit breaks can do so little damage that it's worthless. What's the point of a limit break if it does less damage than the simplest spell.         - Equipment cannot just be bought. You need to acquire certain items before you can buy it and god knows where you can obtain those items. All in all, you can't go wrong with Final Fantasy. Despite all the cons, it's still way better than most other RPGs out there. I turn the sound off and just hit the button randomly while reading a book or looking at my phone to get through all the cheesy love scenes.

												tl;dr version: Do I recommend this game? Yes, but...Longer version: Full disclosure, I'm a Final Fantasy purist, and was a full-on fanboy going waaaay back in the day. So, I might be a little biased here. Be that as it may, I thought for a long time about whether or not I can recommend this game, and I settled on a yes. Overall, the positives outway the many, many negatives. Let's break it down bit by bit.Graphics: Well, they aren't good by modern standards. The FMV sequences have aged very well. The battle sequences look alright for their time - bear in mind that this game came out in the distant time of 1999. The overworld and otherwise walking-around parts have not aged well at all. Honestly, I always thought that Final Fantasy VII did a better job on these parts. Conclusion: Graphics aren't bad for a 16-year-old game.Sound: The PC port has really awful midi music. The fact of the matter is that if you want this game not to sound like♥♥♥♥♥ you're going to have to mod it. Fortunately, modding the sound is super-easy, and there's lots of stuff on the forums that can help you in this regard. Once you're up and running, bear in mind that you're playing a game loaded with classic FInal Fantasy jams. Uematsu is kind of a genius. Conclusion: Sound good after modding. Really, you shouldn't be the one fixing this; it should sound good out of the box.Gameplay: Well, it plays pretty much the same as any Final Fantasy-series game between about #5 and #9. That is, it's genre- and era-defining JRPG faire. You'll spend a lot of your time in this game in dialogue, so if you aren't into that sort of thing, you're not going to have a good time here. Battles are quasi-realtime/quasi-turn-based - the famed ATB system. Battles are actually a lot of fun - you'll control a party of three heroes and beat the snot out of colourful, fun monsters. I do have a few complaints on this front, though: Unlike other Final Fantasy games, there is no job/class system this time around. Your characters' abilities are based on their "GFs" (basically, the equipment and magic systems combined). Every character can use every GF, and every character can therefore use every ability. The only differences you'll see for the most part are in your characters' limit breaks. This makes the characters all kind of feel the same from a gameplay perspective. My other complaint is that this easily the easiest Final Fantasy game I have played (having played numbers 1 through 10) - seriously, difficulty is kind of a joke. Conclusion: If you're really sold on the mid- to late-1990s JRPG formula, you'll probably have fun, but the characters are very generic from a gameplay perspective.Story: Well, it's a JRPG, so story is almost the most important part. Personal opinion, the story of this game flat out sucks hard enough that I could use it to vaccuum my apartment. Your main character will spend most of the game muttering to himself. One of your main nemeses is a full-on angsty "no one understands me!" type. The secondary party members are virtually devoid of personality. Of the PSX-era Final Fantasy games, I can confidentally say that this game has the worst story. Hell, even when I WAS the angsty teenager this game is probably geared towards, I thought the story and characterization was a little too out there on this front. Conclusion: Easily the worst part of the game.Anyway, as to whether or not I recommend the game, given the price versus time you'll get out of Final Fantasy VIII, it's a darned good investment. Still, though, if you haven't played virtually every other Final Fantasy game between 1 and 10, you'll have more fun with basically any other in the series. #7 is even available on Steam.

Posted: March 27, 2015
												There are already thousands of reviews for this game that discuss the pros and cons of this game in great detail. I'd instead like to highlight some of the more glaring flaws of this re-release.Nothing has been changed. It looks, sounds and plays just like the original PC release. Considering the lack of work that has gone into this re-release, it's not worth the price if you already own a previous version. A character booster has been added, which I doubt very few people would bother with.Some achievements have also been added; they're shallow attempts at artificially lengthening the game. The most time-consuming of these achievements is "10,000 kills" - as the title suggests, one must kill at least 10,000 enemies. In a game where killing too many enemies can be detrimental, this is a silly achievement. I finished the game with only a couple of hundred kills, as do most players. Anyone who sets out to achieve 10,000 kills will likely use some king of key-pressing software. I would have preferred some achievements that require the player to use skill, perhaps more like the "Contrived Finish" achievement (wherein one must finish the game without the protagonist leveling up), as these kinds of achievements at least encourage the player to play the game differently.Anyway, it's Final Fantasy VIII. I recommend it so long as you pick it up when it's on sale.

Posted: August 20, 2014
												While it is not one of the most popular Final Fantasy games with most people, this is my favourite title so far. A lot of the things that many felt let Final Fantasy VIII down are, in my opinion, what makes it so great. The unique junction system, different to any other Final Fantasy, is brilliant. The concept of having stocks of magic is a little off (how.... exactly?), and grinding to get those magics can be a struggle but it makes you appreciate them a lot more, especially when to be the most powerful you can be you have to have stocks of the most powerful magic in the game. But then if you use that magic, your junctioned stats will get less powerful. So then you have to weigh up what matters more. Many couldn't get used to the junction system, but I found it just as easy as the materia system from FFVII.The music is brilliant, some of my favourite music in any of the games. Also some of my least favourite... But that's a hit and miss with all the games. But honestly, some of the music had it nailed down.The story is excellent. A lot simpler in concept than FF7, but a lot more character driven than other titles. This is where most people either decide on their love or hate for the game. I personally love the storyline, think it's much easier to relate to than other main characters through the series and the characters are more real. Although Squall, as a main character, has to be the most emotionally unavailable person in history.I would recommend this game to everyone if I could, but I understand you may not like it as much if you're as hooked on the styles of the other games.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I know a lot of people will say they got into gaming from early age with titles like Mario Brothers and so on. I was playing those games too. Sure. I was playing the early Mortal Kombats and so on. I loved going to the arcade. But if someone had to ask me to really pinpoint the one game that got me absolutaly fascinated with gaming as art form as well, I would say FFVIII. I know there were many other games of note before this - FFVII for example and other non Square titles, but I didn't get to play those. We didn't have a console growing up because my parents got addicted (HA!) and decided to get rid of it, and we were always just alittle behind with the technology to play the newest stuff on PC; I would hang out with friends and watch them play or play on their systems. This game we got when we finally had a PC then that could play it, and it was first time I played an RPG like this (although Zork Grand Inquisitor is my ultimate fave, there are differences here). This game is not something you can really bust your way through. It takes time to properly level your characters; you have to collect magic by either drawing it out from enemies or going around buying it, and I loved the concept that you could run out of the number of spells you had as opposed to mana; you have to really play through the environment to get the full experience. Okay, well, you can get through it faster by just sticking to the main story, but there are a lot of fun side stories and puzzles and bosses to deal with.Story wise, it's another romance tale, but I think Square Enix does them pretty well. You gave a broody, emo, angry male lead, Squall, but you learn why he's like that as you go on in the story. You're not really supposed to like him all that much until his character is further revealed, in my opinion. You have a bubbly, romantic, but motivated young female lead, who has other sides to her revealed as well. There's time traveling involved, and just don't focus on thinking about it too much because the storyline as a whole that involves a few twists and turns when a powerful sorceress makes a move on the world these characters inhabit is pretty interesting. It's character based too, and you tend to fall in love with a lot of them. The dynamics of gameplay is that you can design a your core group with up to 3 play playable characters. If you're not into custamizing characters often, might not be your thing, but they have a neat auto option that you can select and it does all the hard work for you. Combat is turn based, and it's not timed. I kind of like that, and it's almost more like chess (umm, just not the timed kind, I suppose). You can also collect guardian forces (GFs), which are powerful magical monsters that you can call upon and level up to create devastating attacks. Magic is, as previously stated, a collection game, and the most annoying thing can be spending hours fighting enemies to collect magic because stores sometimes only carry a certain amount of some magics. However, if you're into that kind of long haul game, it shouldn't bother you. If you're picking up this game as someone part of the new generation or just having gotten into gaming in today's age, you might think the graphics a bit backwards, but they were pretty spectacular from that time, and I still find them rather breathtaking. Cut scenes are pretty awesome and cinematic, as Square does. Also, I've heard the music for the game when bought and played through Steam is the midi stuff, and not the actual musical score originally played with. It's not that big of a turn off in my opinion, but might be for you, but for the price that FFVIII usually goes for, I'd say it's worth it to try and see. You can easily purchase the phenominal orchestra score on any web sites like amazon for example - and I highly recommend that (there is also a full piano album!). All in all, I highly recommend giving this game a try, especially if you are a fan of the RPG genre and haven't been able to play some of these older titles.

												Overly I enjoyed the pc version of Final Fantasy 8. There are buggy issues at times which others have mentioned in some of the negative reviews, but I didn't encounter them (or notice them at least) until the very end of the game. The problems at the end being the death animations of the final boss.The magic booster, which was added to the game, I like. Others call it cheating because it gives you a number of basic magic spells (including such late level magic like curaga) for free, but I personally don't feel like it gives you any magic which wasn't easy to obtain anyway. In my opinion, one of the drawbacks of ff8 was the grind in drawing 100 of each spell (especially if you try to have 100 of each spell on all your characters for various reasons such as refining it later) and I think that adding the magic booster was a good thing. The FMV's of the game held up well enough to me against the test of time, and hardly seemed that outdated (especially considering the game was released in 1999). Others have reported problems with the music, but I never had a problem with it, though maybe I am old school enough not to care. Pretty much, the music stood up to how I remembered it when I played it when it was first released.As far as the controls for the game go, they were on ocassion problematic. An example being Zell's limit break which requires you to type in keyboard combinations or the Timber Train Hijacking which required you to do the same thing. Overly, it seemed to me that the keys chosen for these types of tasks were poorly chosen by Square Enix, but I am playing on a laptop and consequently my keyboard may be different than others. Still, in the end, it really wasn't that hard to adjust. As far as the story and writing go, that didn't hold up to how wonderful I thought they were when I first played it (C'est La Vie), but it was still good enough to finish and having now replayed it as an adult, I can safely say I caught things which I had missed or forgotten.I do recommend the game as a solid RPG and as a classic for any fans of RPG's. The issues I've talked about in this review really were pretty minor to me and overly I enjoyed replaying the game.

												While there are some complains here and there from me about the PC port of Final Fantasy VIII, I will admit that taking a trip back down memory lane was and still is a great feeling. Even though that trip brings me all the way back to when I was in about the third grade and stumbled across our family's copy of Final Fantasy VIII for the PlayStation.Personally, the updated sounds are annoying, though there is luckily a mod in existence that brings back the even more nostalgic PS1 soundtrack back into the fray for anyone that is willing to extract it in. I enjoy the partial controller support as well, especially since that partial controller support can be edited back into the original PS1 set up of how one was introduced to the Final Fantasy controls.There is actually much neutrality in this post about actually recommending this to someone that is interested. I would say that if you have a PS2, or even a PS1 (or if it's available off of the PSN), to start from there instead of jumping the gun and buying it off of Steam. For someone that has not played the game and is unsure that their computer will run into the same snags and bumps in the road everyone else has, it would ruin a really good game that has a storyline that makes you sit and wonder about the reality of what is actually happening.As for me, I've come to grin and bear the outcome of what is going on with my game (and even ended up finding a solution that worked for me!). After clearing some data off my computer and verifying the integrity of my game cache, I'm quite pleased to say that the game is running for me. Though, this is a solution that may not work for everyone; if it does, then kudos to you! I hope you enjoy Final Fantasy VIII!Overall, I am personally happy with the game at this current time, and I'm even more happy to have Final Fantasy VIII officially show up in a collection of mine somewhere since my original PS1 copy cannot be found, and hasn't been able to be found for quite some time now.

Posted: December 19, 2013
												Memories... So many memories of childhood remembered from playing this game... This game, when we look back from the present, is a masterpiece. It's not always these days that a game developer would decide to bring and remake an old game for the present to enjoy. And sometimes, it can truly be depressing. We don't respect the old games at times, and we go for the new ones. What do we get these days? What do people decide to improve? Graphics, graphics, and more graphics. But I say a huge NO to that. Sometimes, people get too carried away on the graphics of games that they lack the most essential parts of games. The gameplay. The story. These two have been carried on by Final Fantasy in an astonishing way. They truly have created a game worth celebrating for years to come. We should not care only for graphics, but also the gameplay. Anyway, this FInal Fantasy, compared to other Final Fantasies, is still a masterpiece but I think Square Enix is starting to lose some of their touch as they progress onto the new ones such as A Realm Reborn. But I think they should always remember that the gameplay is most important, not the graphics. Excellent graphics but bad gameplay is still a bad game. I suggest Square Enix to look back at their previous titles, and keep up their previous great work. FInal Fantasy VIII is great, however I think it is too focused on one character, which is the protagonist, who is Squall. Final Fantasy VII did a great job in not only focusing on one character, but gives every character in the party a role to play, side quests, secrets, and many other things that makes the game truly worth playing and exploring every corner for. But a positive point I would raise up is the character development in this game. Square Enix explains in detail how Squall changed, but in an indirect but very detailed way. Squall, from a very unexpressive, lonely person, becomes an expressive, social person from just spending time with Rinoa. And that development is throughout the whole game, with 40+ hours of playing. Square Enix truly did a great job with this game. I reccomend this to anyone who likes RPG games, especially old school gamers who miss their old school games. If you're not one with RPG, I suggest you try it too, as you will find yourself slowly drawn into the Final Fantasy world with the story slowly engulfing you.

												My favorite out of the ones originally released for the PS1. There are so many possibilities for challenge runs from low level to no Junctions to no GFs, or if you're in the mood to breeze through just use the Magic Booster to Junction insane stat boosts early on. Understanding the story requires being a fairly well-rounded nerd (world religions, time travel theory, military duty and honor, literature, and more), but is well worth working your brain to enjoy. It's worth the price for the Triple Triad minigame alone. A very well-constructed JRPG with a fair bit of replay value for those into self-imposed challenges.
